Got this game after hearing good things abt it. I heard it had an issue with crashing, but i didn't worry since i have a very high end pc. game has how crashed twice within 20 min. I installed zone reclamation project cuz i heard it was supposed to fix said issue. safe to say it didn't. expected nearly 20 year old game to be atleast playable but my gaming is interrupted by the game crashing out of the blue. Dont buy this game!

NOTE: I played the vanilla game on Master difficulty, only using the Zone Reclamation Project mod to fix bugs and make the game more stable.

S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl takes a very long time to get going. For the first 6 or 7 hours I was using INCREDIBLY inacurate guns, where only 1 out of 10 shots actually hit where I aimed (not even kidding). This quickly gets really frustrating. I know that this is done to make the game more realistic and immersive, but in reality it only forces me to play the game in the most unrealistic maner possible, by charging large groups of enemies with a double barreled shotgun, hoping to not get killed in the process, this way you will at least hit your shots in point-blank range.

However, the game gets much better once you start aquiring better guns with higher accuracy and better armors that almost works as a metroidvania style progression system that now let's you explore a few new areas that previously had a too high radiation level etc.

There is certainly a lot of freedom given to the player in this game in how you want to aproach the games many different obstacles. Kitchen-sink design and Immersive-sim elements, with a more or less open-world for you to explore make this game very different from the much more linear Metro series for instance. 
Despite the large freedom the game gives you there are a lot of things that are just a lot less viable than others. Stealth for instance is basicly useless or at least incredibly difficult to pull off in a way that actually works.

On master difficulty i had plenty of healing items and ammo through the entire game and i wish it was a bit harder to come by, but the guns a bit more accuarate. Money also seemed completely useless, and by the end of the game i didn't have to really buy a single thing from any of the traders in the game.

The more i played of Shadow of Chernobyl the more i liked it tho, despite the games many glaring flaws. This is certainly one of those games where mods can give you a much better experience than the base game (The modding scene is also pretty crazy for the Stalker series)

This game is excellent, its a challenge and while difficult it is not overly punishing or unfair. it is an older game and as such the graphics aren't the best. but it is not any worse for the fact. While its combat can be a little frustrating due to the AI's Tendency to start homing in on your position, It's lean system and arma style controls are nice. It's mechanics are Pretty good, with the exception of the stealth, which is irrepairably poor. the Story is Pretty alright, but slow to start and only picks up at the end. Honestly my fun was exploring, and just playing to play. the side quests are pretty much just money makers, and it doesnt have too much story. Its a nice FPS with an amazing atmosphere. Especially for the 2000's. Its insanely immersive and can play like a horror game, which was done quite well. This game isnt perfect, but is fun and worth the price

[h1] UNPLAYABLE WITHOUT MODS! [/h1]
As a kind of guy who is not really into mods and tries to enjoy games as they are, this really hit me hard!
kept telling myself this may just make the game a bit more challenging and that's good, I would enjoy a little bit of challenge! but it wasn't just a challenge, it was downright broken! setting crashes and minor AND MAJOR performance and graphical issues aside, the thing that drove me nuts was the broken hit box system, it was like the guy was in the point-blank range and I shot him three times in the face but he keep comin' as if nothing happened because no hits were registered! 
so make sure to install at least one essential mod to not have your whole experience of the game ruined!
Also I'm not sure the modding would fix these things that i'm about to mention but let's just say it! (because i only had one mod installed myself)  
first) since most gun fights happen in open spaces this wouldn't occur very often but sometimes enemies can shoot through walls! I noticed it in the last mission [spoiler] since it took place in Chernobyl NPP, it's an enclosed area, most sections are separated with walls [/spoiler] and it kept on happening! and man, you have no idea how disappointing it was! it probably had happened before but I didn't notice it because there was some distance between me and the enemies, unlike the mentioned level!
second) you can't even save scum in most areas! especially in the last mission (yeah just like the other bug that I mentioned earlier I noticed it in this very level because things get out of hand pretty easily! I'm not that big of a scum!) because when you reload them enemies re-spawn and there's a high chance that they do it right next to you 0_0
P.S. I know some of you would probably say it's a old, clunky game made by a small group; I know that too but had to say it for those who don't know.

"S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl" received generally positive reviews upon its release, praised for its atmospheric design, unique setting, and immersive gameplay. Here's a summary of key aspects from various reviews:

Positive Aspects:

Atmosphere and Immersion: One of the most consistent praises for the game is its immersive atmosphere. The desolate and eerie landscape of the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone, combined with dynamic weather and day-night cycles, contributes to a hauntingly realistic environment.

Open-World Exploration: Critics and players appreciated the freedom to explore the open-world setting known as "The Zone." The nonlinear structure and a sense of unpredictability in encounters with mutants and anomalies added to the overall immersion.

Faction System: The inclusion of different factions within the Zone, each with its own agenda and territories, added depth to the narrative and gameplay. Players could choose to align with a faction, affecting the story and missions available to them.

Realistic Survival Elements: The game's attention to survival aspects, such as managing resources, dealing with radiation, and staying vigilant against mutants and anomalies, added a layer of realism and challenge.

Multiple Endings: The multiple endings based on player choices were well-received, encouraging replayability as players could experience different outcomes by making different decisions throughout the game.

Criticisms:

Technical Issues: Some critics pointed out technical issues, including occasional bugs, glitches, and performance issues. However, many of these were addressed through patches and community-made mods.

Learning Curve: Some players found the game's learning curve to be steep, especially for those unfamiliar with the survival-shooter genre. The lack of handholding and the complex inventory system could be initially overwhelming for some.

Graphical Presentation: While praised for its atmospheric design, the game's graphics were considered somewhat dated even at the time of its release. However, the modding community has since provided graphical enhancements.

Despite these criticisms, "S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl" has stood the test of time and gained a dedicated fanbase. Its impact on the gaming industry is evident in the continued interest, modding community support, and the subsequent success of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series. It remains a classic in the genre, known for delivering a unique and memorable gaming experience.

Excellent story, holds up very strongly even to this day. Gameplay is very fun once you get used to it; the most balanced difficulty is also the hardest, so the game revolves heavily around headshotting enemies with good positioning. You'd think that would become a tedious or annoying system, but it just adds to the satisfaction. Enemies aren't bullet spongey but neither are you; even with the strongest artifacts I found myself dying several times in the more intense firefights.

It's absolutely absurd how drawn into the game you get. It's wildly immersive despite its dated appearance. I'll admit, it was a little tough to get used to it all in the beginning, and the keybinds were a little odd, so there was a good amount of configuring I had to do. But it was beyond worth it, because STALKER Shadow of Chernobyl might genuinely be one of my favorite gaming experiences (I swear it's not the recency bias talking).

Despite having the key story and lore elements foolishly spoiled to me in a lore video (I initially thought I wasn't going to play the games and just wait for STALKER 2, but I now realize that was my biggest mistake!) the game thoroughly surprised me time and time again, with its masterful environment and ambiance. 

I also appreciate that each faction has its own unique take on the zone, and isn't some bizarre, ridiculous binary between some wild hedonist sex cult and a megafascist chudtopia.

PS: don't let the time played fool you; I've played the entire game and done every side quest using a bugfix mod because my computer was bugging out a lot playing it otherwise. The mod is Zone Reclamation Project, and it runs standalone, but you should still support the devs and buy the game!

S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl is a true masterpiece that immerses players in a haunting and atmospheric journey through the eerie landscapes of the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone. From the moment you step into the worn boots of the protagonist, the game envelopes you in a sense of isolation, danger, and intrigue that is rarely matched in the gaming world.

The atmospheric storytelling is where S.T.A.L.K.E.R. truly shines. The desolate landscapes, dilapidated structures, and the ever-present threat of anomalies and mutated creatures create an environment that is as captivating as it is foreboding. The nonlinear narrative allows for a deeply personal experience, with player choices influencing the outcome of the story, adding layers of replayability.

The attention to detail in recreating the Zone is remarkable, capturing the eerie beauty and danger of the real-life Chernobyl region. The day-night cycle and dynamic weather contribute to the overall sense of realism, enhancing the immersion and making every moment feel tense and unpredictable.

The survival elements, including resource management and the constant need for caution, add depth to the gameplay. The gunplay is satisfyingly realistic, and the scarcity of resources forces players to make strategic decisions, creating a tense and immersive atmosphere throughout.

The A.I.-driven characters and factions within the Zone add a layer of complexity to the gameplay. The interactions with other stalkers, mercenaries, and hostile factions create a living, breathing world where alliances and betrayals are part of the harsh reality.

While the game has a few rough edges, they become part of the charm, showcasing the dedication of the developers to deliver an authentic and immersive experience. S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl is more than just a game; it's an atmospheric journey into a post-apocalyptic world that will stay with you long after the credits roll.

Truly a nightmare to get it to play. First time launching it, game wouldn't open. After 30 minutes found out a singular file was set to hidden and the game couldn't launch because of it. This one ill take the blame for but I don't recall ever hiding any files. Next, I finally get it to open and I instantly shut it down and installed a no head bobbing mod because it was so god damn nauseating. Next, every single god damn time i launched the game, it never remembered my settings, so after getting sick of redoing the settings after the 7th time, I did some research and found out I needed to code the game my fucking self and add a line in fsgame.ltx that make it save the settings. Next, the guns are incredible inaccurate, truthfully i was using the first pistol, but after getting an smg I kid you not I would spray an enemy no farther than 3 feet from me in the chest and only 1 out of 20 would hit him. It is quite literally useless to shoot anywhere but the head as it seems the developers only made the hitbox for the head. Found it frustrating that the combat is suppose to be realistic, yet the bullet spray is anything but realistic. The fact that there are guides in the community that help you fix the combat speaks for itself. All this work just for the game to be extremely boring and no incentive to continue playing. Maybe I just didn't play long enough but the hook wasn't even there for it even be able to set in for me. Had no motive to speak with npc's as they were extremely boring and consisted of fetch/errand tasks. Honestly I feel like i could've been a fan of the game but it is so old and just a fucking chore to even get it to run that I lost all desire to play it. The only reason I even played it was to get familiar with the lore before playing the new one but ill be better off watching a yt video and save myself from balding.

Janky beyond belief and perhaps a little too ambitious for the time it which it released, Stalker: Shadow of Chernobyl is a post-apocalyptic RPG-ish FPS game where you take the role of an amnesiac stuck in a nuclear wasteland. Your goal is to figure out the secret of the wasteland, and maybe figure out who you are along the way.

It’s kind of like Fallout, but more atmospheric, and a bit like Half-Life, however nowhere near as refined, and then mashed together in a sort of half-and-half chimera. It’s not bad, not excellent, and very unique. The shooting gameplay can be a little frustrating as it feels like most of the weapons in your hands have a wide spread while the enemies can headshot you from 30 feet away, and it isn’t uncommon to fail a quest because a guy you need gets eliminated from someone that you can’t even see.

It’s overly ambitious in the way that some 2000’s games are, and considering how this was once vaporware, it’s not only neat that it actually made it to release, it’s genuinely pretty cool how atmospheric and enjoyable the whole experience is. It’s definitely a little broken and sometimes frustratingly buggy. One good example of this that I experienced involved a mid-game “help us defend this barrier” mission where, upon completion, the guy I needed to talk to in order to turn the quest in decided to go on a full sprint across the map directly into a minefield in front of another faction’s main base. Neat.

Exploring the zone is a ton of fun though, but this game definitely isn’t for everyone. You have to be ready to accept a somewhat broken experience that feels overly strange at times.

I would recommend adding in the Zone Reclamation Project mod, which basically acts as a bug fix and adds the ability for you to tweak certain things if you feel the need to, which, with a game this old and strange, you might be inclined to make a few changes like adjusting how inaccurate weapons can be or maybe increasing the carry weight a bit, and if you get tired of going back and forth across some areas, the fast travel feature is nice to have.

I like all the Skulls and Skeletons, and the fact that everyones character photo is just a low res screenshot of them in-game from like a few seconds earlier is really funny, would have played this game like 3 years ago with my friends but it has absolutely no Controller support, according to the community this is for a very good reason, claiming that the game rrquires really fast reflexes when fighting enemies and controller players could just never keep up, maybe thats true, but I think its far more likely the studio that was too lazy to make actual character images for dialogue was also too lazy to add controller support.
Thankfully I only really wanted controller support for the convenience of playing on a couch with friends, and 3 years later I got that experience (minus the friends) via my wireless keyboard/mouse couchpad setup. I will admit fast reflexes are required, and some game mechanics are very strange, wasn't prepared for the Open World to be level based thats kinda strange. Only real thing that bothered me in the whole run is the Weight system, ammo was just too heavy all the time or maybe I just looted too many heals? regardless I felt heavy at all times, always hovering around 47-50kg at all times dropping things just to pick things up constantly, maybe with more exploration I can upgrade inventory so I cant complain too much but that really was driving me crazy, dropping guns to pick up a gun with a compatible ammo, then dropping half my ammo because this new guns too heavy.

I really liked the atmosphere people were right its pretty immersive with the sound effects, unfortunately the game is old and doesnt support anything over stereo so surround sound was out of the question, also the ui scaled pretty bad on my 80inch 4K TV, all text was microscopic, but atleast it was crisp.

overall good game, with excellent history, feel bad for the people near Chernobyl, still cant believe this really happened, looking forward to the new game more now, glad I played this.

(side note: having bolts in your hand as your unarmed default is a strange choice, made me feel like I was playing TF2 Engineer for whatever reason, idk.)

It's definitely a bit dated, but I think it's still pretty good. 

Gunplay is solid enough, though random spread on guns can be a little maddening.

But to go with the gunplay, the game has some resource management for you to consider which helps keep things a little refreshing.

If you can look past the aged graphics, you can see that there's a commitment here to a gritty and grounded aesthetic that really helps immerse you into the Zone.

This game is BRILLIANT, however, it is certainly not everyone's cup of tea, the base game is quite hard to get on with, the accuracy of the weapons in the early stages is awful which can be very off putting to new players. This can be helped slightly by turning the difficulty up to a harder setting so your shots do more damage but in turn that means enemies gunfire does more damage to you too. It can be unforgiving even on easier settings but the sense of reward when you survive a large ambush is very high.

The story is a bit odd and hardly compelling, but it's enough to keep you interested. With it's real life disaster backstory mixed with a novel it's a nice blend between fact and fiction. All around a fun and immersive horror/shooter.

I would definitely recommend playing the Vanilla version first, or you could go to MODDB and download mods to make the game look prettier and add newer weapons, which is what i do a lot of the time nowadays.

Really good game, the following release's in the series: 'Clear sky' was decent enough in my opinion and 'Call of Pripyat' was great too. All 3 games are worth the time.

Here's a few things that make this game not fun to play.

- Bullets don't go where you aim, even when ADS and fully crouched. Idk who made this design choice but they should be fired. It doesn't make the gunplay 'realistic', it makes it tedious and boring.
- Walk speed is really slow and sprint doesn't recharge unless you are standing still. Another strange decision considering the world is decently big. This makes getting from point A to point B is a slog.
- Exploration isn't rewarding. You'll find ammo, generic weapons, or meds. Every enemy carries this stuff and your carry space is very limited so it's a good chance you already have plenty.
- Game is buggy.
- Story is not very interesting. At least not in the 6 hours I played, which is likely as far as you'll get before everything aforementioned wears you down.

If I'm looking for something positive to say about this game, it does atmosphere well. There were a few sections that were eerie to traverse. If that's something you're really into, I'm sure there's better games for you to check out. Don't play this one unless you intend to mod it to make it playable.

This was a load of fun to play from the running and gunning to the hiding in a corner because of a spooky mutant creature.  The ending felt absolutely abrupt and some things were left without resolve (but probably explained in later games) but I still liked it nevertheless.  I'd still recommend playing this as it is a good game (first in franchise). 8/10

pretty much the best horror survival game i’ve played.
when i was buying the game, i thought to myself “oh this game was Into the Radius’s inspiration, maybe i’ll like it!”
i was right.
the gunplay feels realistic, the terrain feels perfectly dystopian and ominous, and the mutant enemies made me shit myself repeatedly. the designs for the characters are great, and the maps are explosive with beauty… uh, visually.

some parts of the game you may like a little less, however. such as the horrible gun animations and less than perfect hud, and the certain bugs and glitches you will face sooner or later, but it is a game from 2007, what did you expect? (please forget about half-life 2 and far cry 1 when i said that).

a solution to what i said before, the bugs can be easily fixed via googling it, and this game is not difficult to mod and make animations, hud, and graphics better.

Yes, absolute classic, will never forget the first time I played it back 2007. Great Ukrainian Developer!

Although crashes will happen this game is very intriguing. I don't want to be a hero I just want to be a man. My own goals I create and my own ideals to be taken into the zone. Don't let the old games go cause you can tell that this ambitious project and it's ideals was way ahead of it's time. Enemies will flank you, rush you when you retreat, supress you while their guys will move up or fall back. Truly a remarkable feeling to be distracted by one dude and another comes right behind you and domes you i the head execution style (Yes this happened I was very impressed). This game is incredible and their is two more and a ton of mods for each of them to make this slavic jank masterpiece into something more incredible and a little more modern.

Owned this game almost since it was released, and been an absolutely massive fan since then.  Due to it's age, it will run on most systems (including my Windows 11 with GTX 680 card).  I remember one quote from an early review, that it feels like a living world, and this absolutely feels true.  There are many mods out there, but I still manage to rock along with the vanilla version.  Obviously it doesn't look as pretty as a modern AAA title, but don't let that out you off.

Rest in peace Volodymyr Yezhov, you will live on in our games, Stalker!

Ukrainian Developer of S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Video Game Killed Near Bakhmut. Volodymyr Yezhov was killed defending the city of Bakhmut in Ukraine's Donetsk region on December 22. He was one of the developers behind the successful video game S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky, which was released in 2008. One of the game's characters, Loki, was based on Yezhov's face.

Volodymyr Yezhov was born on August 1, 1984 in Lubny, Poltava Oblast. He graduated from KPI with a degree in electronics engineering. He was also one of the most famous Ukrainian e-sportsmen — played StarCraft under the nickname Fresh. In 2003, he joined the GSC Game World company, which was the developer of such cult games as Cossacks and S.T.A.L.K.E.R.

He was also involved in the creation of several RTS games: Alexander (2004), Cossacks 2 (2005) and Heroes of Annihilated Empires (2006) and World of Battles: Morningstar, Call of Cthulhu, and Sherlock Holmes: Devil’s Daughter.

Viacheslav Yezhov, brother of Volodymyr, on Facebook:
"Today, my brother, a father of two, a faithful friend with a sincere heart, died defending Ukraine. He used to say that a happy future for our children is being forged through the fight that the Ukrainian people are currently waging. I hope you have arrived at a better world, brother," Viacheslav Yezhov posted.

The fact that he is the face leader of the Freedom faction in game makes this hurt even more, in the end he really died fighting for the freedom of his country.

This is a great game that does very well at what it sets out to do despite it's quirks & bugs.  The atmosphere is on point, the story is compelling, the pacing is good, & it's just challenging enough to push you around a bit & force you to be thoughtful without being overly frustrating.  

I've seen lots of complaints about the vanilla experience & urges to play with mods, but I can say that the overall unmodded vanilla experience was really good for me.  I didn't experience anything game breaking.  

Some bugs were annoying, like having a period of time where all the hidden stashes I was opening were coming up empty & the map markers wouldn't clear off the map without me taking items out of them.  😂

One thing that did bother me a bit was the sequence-breaking that can happen if you don't take the intended path in certain missions.  Some of the sequence triggers were not very well thought out imo.  

Regarding the shooting mechanics in this game,  RNG is not the problem & you don't need mods to experience fair play.  This isn't doom & it wasn't meant to be, lol.  If you want to hit your shots you need to use weapons from the appropriate distance, crouch more often, & ADS.  Do yourself a favor & disable the crosshair because point shooting in this game is inconsistent & inaccurate on purpose.  Always ADS if you want to hit your shots, & aim for the head if running out of ammo isn't your thing 😂.  Crouching tightens up your accuracy and crouching lower tightens it even more.

I played through from the beginning. blind on master difficulty and re-played the final section on novice.  The only differences I noticed were in the AI behavior & damage taken by the player.  Headshots were still just as effective as Master, but the AI was less agressive, slower to shoot, had worse aim, did less damage & caused less bleeding.  

For those who care,  the best way I found to consistently save Yuri is to sneak around the right side of the trucks, run up & backstab the closest bandit before switching to guns.  It matters to me,  OK!?  😂

I had seen some you tubers talking about this cult classic game and I figured I should give it a shot based on their words on it. I absolutely do not regret it! while the story is interesting and keeps you moving forward,, the survival aspects of existing as a relic hunter around Chernobyl is so compelling. I recommend this game just for that. learning about the different factions and what they are doing in the zone is fascinating. You very quickly get a sense for who you want to support.

tl;dr: Game is great!

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

A very atmospheric FPS. The setting and general feel of the game are quite unique and it is worth checking out for those. The story is a bit weak, it mostly serves as guiding thread – a tool to show off the Zone to the player.
If you like sandbox, post-apocalyptic games, Metro 2033, it is worth.

TLDR;
- Game is harsh and wants to punish you really bad, that's part of the old school survival horror game athmosphere. Play this game only if you can deal with that and the frustration that comes with it.
- Make a lot of saves, and incremental saves (don't always overwrite), otherwise you'll most likely regret it towards the end.
- Don't bother too much accumulating stuff, even if it's to sell it, it's not worth it. All the useful equipment you need can be found or obtained for free, you only need to buy ammunition and the rewards from the quests are enough to finance it. Otherwise you might have too much money on you and the game might punish you for it.
- Don't skip the Guide or get trolled.

---
Mixed feelings about this game. Back in 2007 it must have been great but it hasn't aged very well.
Graphics are not great but it's ok, there are glitches but it's okay, you get used to it. Sounds are kinda cheap, that is harder to get used to though.
However the gameplay and game design are often frustrating or disapointing in ways you wouldn't accept for modern games.

There is little characters development, story is only scratching at the surface despite the massive lore potential.
It all relies on the survival & horror gameplay, which is well developed and perhaps a little "too realistic" for its own good.
At time it felt like a dangerous hiking simulator, main concern being the management of the content of your backpack and the huge distances you have to cover. At first you want to explore and accumulate stuff you find, but eventually you have to face the reality that your weapon, suit and ammunition take most of your load capacity.
Guns are massively innacurate at range and you rarely can get too close without dying quicjly, so you waste a lot of ammo that you can't really stock up too much in advance, so you also have to worry constantly about finding the balance about saving and refilling your ammo.

Gun fights are frustrating all game long. At first you get shit guns but lots of ammo, so you spend lot of time killing anything. Then you get a decent rifle and kills more efficiently but you struggle to maintain a sufficient stock of ammo. And to finish, you get better guns but face so many brutal enemies that you might get plenty ammo but you need to heal a lot all while reloading your save over and over because you keep dying. There is a sense of progression in all that, so it makes sense, but at the cost of a lot of frustration.

But the worst of it all has got to be the endings. I don't know if it's genius or an insult but I've rarely been so frustrated by a game ending. Not spoiling anything but basically if you intuitively progress through the game, you'll eventually reach the end only to realize you've failed it, game stops and laughts at your face.
To reach a real ending, you need to spend a lot more time going back to several early places you've visited to complete an optional questline which only looked like a side quest, especially since it is listed in the middle of several irrelevant side quests. Had I not checked the internet for alternate endings I would not have known that a troll ending wasn't all of it.

Stalker is what you get when you take Fallout, put it in Russia, and give more focus to survival mechanics rather than your typical FPS. This game does not hold your hand, and I'll admit I struggled at first with the shooting as it's not like COD or other shooters alike. Once you get a hang of the gunplay, the game becomes a fun blend of intense battles with a mixture of horror elements to keep you on your toes. The story is also really interesting with your choices determining what ending you get, and giving the player more agency on how they want to go about their adventure. If you want an FPS with realistic gameplay and survival mechanics, then look no further.

I feel like this is a game that's held up specifically because of nostalgia and how different it was for the time. Is it terrible? No, not at all. Is it great? Absolutely not. Keep in mind I'm writing this review based on the vanilla experience, not modded, not repaired, not "fixed." It crashes way too often, the guns having what seems to be random shot patterns, most of what you use will miss shots even if you're right on target, it's basically pointless to ADS because your accuracy remains the same regardless if you're ADSing or hip firing. The story is okay, i like the faction system, I think the world is well made and immersive, but this is a game that really feels very "of the time" if you will.  For the time this is like a 9/10. In 2024 though? I'd give it a 7/10 at the most. I hope when S.T.A.L.K.E.R. 2 comes out it really improves on a lot of the things I don't like about this game. The stupid shot patterns, ADSing being essentially useless, most artifacts are useless junk, the graphics are really ugly even for the time. It has positives, but it's just so dated.

First what I'd like to say is, yes, this game is AWESOME. Even despite the fact it’s missing a lot of immersive and QoL features it holds its own even against the later games.
Second, even though a lot of people say to play to play Pripyat and Clear Sky before this, I ask you still play this game before the others. It's a really good introductory to the simple elements that the other games will begin to expand upon (examples being artifacts, factions, guns etc).

Setting:
     The game is a little interesting, as it has both sci-fi and alternate history in its lore. The story revolves around the 10 km radioactive exclusion zone (which is referred to as ‘The Zone’ ingame) that was set up after the 1986 disaster at the CNPP. The story has it that soviet scientists began experiments within the Zone far from the public eye. As experiments continued, even after 1991, more and more unusual events occur within the Zone however the Ukrainian government does not interfere because of anticipation of international backlash for potentially harming scientists. Anomalies continue to mount until the eventual ‘Second Disaster’ near the CNPP. Between March 4th and June 12th of 2006 began a series of strange, unnatural disasters. An unbearable light illuminated the sky and the clouds evaporated all the while a 6.9 earthquake shook the land. Something only described as an “energy disturbance” which is later named an “emission” began making waves over the zone, immediately killing all personnel hit by it. As the disasters subsided, it certainly left its mark. Strange and physics defying anomalies perspirated the area within the exclusion zone, puzzling the scientific community and preventing the military personnel from getting to the CNPP. These anomalies have formed strange artifacts that have positive and negative effects on the human body, and (a few) were even able to be replicated by scientists. Some soldiers within the zone defected, starting their own faction. The members of the new faction (known as Duty) are arguably the first ‘S.T.A.L.K.E.R’s. S.T.A.L.K.R is an abbreviation for Scavengers, Trespassers, Adventurers, Loners, Killers, Explorers and Robbers. This name, is appropriately applied to the now growing population of the Zone. In the eyes of many, the Zone is the last frontier. Hundreds from all around sneak into the zone to prospect for artifacts, battle mutants or simply enjoy a free life in the anarchy. 

Premise:
     S.T.A.L.K.E.R is a post-apocalyptic, survival horror, open world, atmospheric shooter which takes place in the radioactive exclusion zone of Chernobyl, which, after the (obviously fictional) events of 2006, is now simply known as ‘The Zone’. You assume the role of a S.T.A.L.K.E.R who has lost his memory, knowing only that he must kill ‘The Strelok’, whoever that is. In his journey to accomplish this mission, the player will slowly but surely expand his arsenal, make allies (and enemies) and reveal the secrets of the zone.
Aesthetics: - 10/10
     This is basically the one thing people hold the highest in the franchise, so I think it's appropriate to get this over with first. The atmosphere is fantastic, think of the eerie moments from Fallout 3 and New-Vegas but without the breaks. The game bathes the player in second-to-none ambiance and even long time players are often put on edge. Shadow of Chernobyl is the smartest with their music, each area has a single track that's hard to discern from actual music and just ambiance which (IMO) is how it should be. The only proper songs are in the menu and guitars that stalkers will play in game. Every once in a while when you're figuring out your inventory or trying to catch a breath you'll break out for a moment and take a moment to try and figure what direction a certain sound is coming from. I've heard from 'Slavic' players that the environment perfectly replicates the landscape and feeling of Eastern Europe, and gives them a sense of deja vu or nostalgia because of how accurate it is.  Ultimately, it does the job *very* well. It helps make game feel alive and sets the tone for the player appropriately.
     I really do not care about graphics as long as visuals are accurately represented (especially since I have a potato pc, so lower graphics are the norm for me). There is an insane amount of mods for graphics which make the game look amazing, so if you’re worried about that then the modding community is there for you.
     Besides that mods and *my* subjective opinion on graphics, the game actually holds up in some areas. First, the environmental textures are pretty good, at least if you aren’t looking at it too hard. Not only that but the lighting is absolutely incredible, and when used correctly, helps conceal the age of the game. What doesn’t hold up are the character models, (some of the) gun textures and animations. The character’s limbs look kind of goofy and the ragdolls are pretty stiff but are serviceable. A lot of the reload animations are choppy and some of the guns, specifically the ones that are supposed to look shiny look really crappy texture wise however I think the base models are fine and all of these are standard qualities for graphics from the time.
     The game has very few of what we’d call cut-scenes, but rather it has some cinematics that play. (IMO), cinematics will always be friggin amazing. I’ve always enjoyed old game cinematics from the late 2000s to early 2010s because they seem less “realistic” in quality and more.. artistic? They were trying their best to look real while using only digital tools at the time but it looks like its own artstyle and looks a bit dream like. The problem with cinematics however is they take a while to load and they don’t really fit the games graphics or art style which gives the players a bit of whiplash. But I think the devs understood this, and intended for the cinematics to be dreamlike in the first place. I won’t spoil anything, but some of the first couple cut scenes in the game actually work well.

Gameplay and Mechanics: - 9/10

     In gameplay, I think S.T.A.L.K.E.R is a jack-of-all-trades here. When I say jack-of-all-trades I don’t mean that it’s not good at any elements, but rather it’s a bit shallow on each but just because its shallow on certain areas doesn’t mean it’s bad at them.

Survival: -8/10
     Nowadays when people say ‘survival’ in a videogame setting what comes to mind is foraging which is more like gathering and building bases but its not quite like that. Rather than gathering it’s going to be more like scavenging for scraps. In early game you will will be picking up everything you see, every bullet will count. You’re going to be so down bad for ammunition (which is quite scarce) that you will be picking up every single gun and manually unload them (You can unload guns which I’m sure was mind blowing for 2007) just for that extra boost which some may find meticulous, but I find it immersive. Next to scavenging for ammo, you’ll be scavenging for guns too. Every weapon (except for the knife) has a durability bar. And as the durability meter gets lower and lower, the overall performance of the weapon is reduced. This means you’ll also be swapping out your old guns for newer ones to make sure you are performing at your best. This rarely affects the gameplay in a big way, but it contributes to the feeling that you are a scavenger who’s barely scraping by with the bare minimum.

      Though not too advanced, there’s a medical item system. There are three main items, food, bandages and med kits and while in the game, you want to make sure to use all of these correctly or else you’ll be wasteful. Food is easy to find, and replenishes a little bit of health upon being used, however it doesn’t do a whole lot and cannot stop bleeding. Bandages on the other hand, can stop bleeding however they aren’t that great in numbers and are not practical for health replenishment. Medkits, do a lot for health replenishment, but

The mod I used didn't log hours for the game, but I probably put over 40 into it. I used Memories of the Zone; allegedly the most vanilla friendly modpack according to forum searching, so my recommendation is based off of that because I did not play the game vanilla. That is something to note though, that this game has many mods for it and the general consensus is that the game is way better and amazing with mods.

This series will likely see an influx of players because of the hype around Stalker 2 and the new gamma mod, which is what drew me in. I just want to put it out there that even with mods, this is a very annoying game. It's a very "fuck you" game because of how quick you can die and how sneaky enemies can be. If it weren't for quick saves I'd say some of the bs is a waste of time and save scumming is the only way I managed to beat this game.

The ending(s) are a joke and the story is... there? Metro has way better world building, lore and story if you're looking for that.

I guess what makes this game worth recommending is even though the game's attitude and design is very much "fuck you" the game gets a lot better when you learn to say "fuck you too" and come out on top. Getting chain headshots and winning a fight without taking a hit when dying happens so quick raises the feelings of satisfaction and victory.

It's always dirt cheap and the mods are good, try it out. It's hard as hell.

This game is incredible


Stalker SoC is one the greatest "Open World", what set's Stalker apart from other so called living and breathing game worlds is the over tone of cosmic horror, the game was inspired by a book named roadside picnic. Stalker unlike let's say Ubisoft, or basically any modern OPEN WORLD GAME. it feel's alive, the a-life systems allows for the AI to live, breath, roam, scavenge, fight, trade(they can on their own i think). The human AI all have some unique dialogue, why their here, what they want, how they feel, what they fear. Sometimes the humans AI when shot will sometimes down and lie on the floor dying an you and your comrade to chose what to do with them. the monsters will bite the meat off of dead bodies to survive, they try leave and retreat when they their all alone. the missions are well done, and take you all over the zone. Anomalies which are the most dangerous things in the zone,they can kill you and cannot be killed, and they activate when you step near thus you have to focus where you walk, anomalies are based on location as well. And the greatest thing about all of this is none of this is scripted.

(edit) I just finished the game. The multiplier is pretty OK, Arena at the bar is a cool way to get cash. The ending bit is great.

I thought this would be a game that provided high octane shootouts, instead I got another silent, monotonous tactical shooter. What do people see in this game?

In the first game of the series, the player takes on the role of an amnesiac stalker referred to as the "Marked One", tasked with killing another stalker named Strelok. During the game, the protagonist uncovers clues to his past and true identity while helping other stalkers and encountering dangerous mutants. He also learns about the nature and origins of the Zone by exploring mysterious underground laboratories in the area. Shadow of Chernobyl features seven endings which are dependent on multiple factors such as money earned during the game, supporting certain factions, or how much of the protagonist's memory was pieced together.

To make the game more enjoyable: 
1. turn $game_data$ to true in \fsgame.ltx 
2. unpack the db (including dba, dbb, dbc, dbd) files using "STALKER Data Unpacker" 
3. copy the "config" folder to /GAME_ROOT_FOLDER/gamedata 
4.1. enter /gamedata/config/creatures 
4.2. change actor.ltx: 
- hit_probability_gd_master = 1.0 (and the others similar lines above to 1.0 too)
- disp_base = 0.0) 
- disp_aim = 0.0). 
4.2. enter /gamedata/config/weapons. 
4.3. change weapons.ltx 
- hit_probability_max_dist = 1000

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

[h1] What to Expect from an Early 2000s Classic [/h1]

I heard a lot of hype about STALKER and I'm sure you have too given the massive cult following of the game. When I first got it, I expected something similar to Fallout, but more hardcore. What I got was a good game with a few unexpected twists. Here is an overview of some of the things you need to know before you buy.

[h2] The Setting [/h2]

STALKER takes place within The Zone, a post-double-disaster Chernobyl. The landscape is barren, inhospitable, and generally depressing. There is little to look at save for some trees, roads, destroyed buildings, and rubble. The world is somewhat sparse and [b] all travel is done on foot, there is no fast travel in this game. [/b]

The landscape is populated entirely by men and monsters. There aren't any misc items such that you would find in a game like Skyrim or Fallout. There are no containers to open, mainly there are just boxes to smash to get some ammo drops or a medkit. There are a total of 3 or so food items (so far as I can tell). So, don't expect a ton of loot to find.

Also, and this is important, [b] the map is NOT open world, it's a vast landscape that is divided into sections. When you travel from section to section, you have to wait through a loading screen. [/b]

The map is dotted by "anomalies." these are essentially pockets of areas that you don't want to be in. Some crush you instantly, some zap you with electricity, some are made of acid, some explode. You can see these all over the world as you walk down the road. These anomalies cause "artifacts" to spawn, which are essentially shiny rocks that give you stat boosts and that you can sell for a good chunk of change. They give you effects like +3 bulletproofing and -5 radiation, etc.

Generally, there isn't a whole lot to explore or look at in this game world. However, where the game shines is the atmosphere. It's depressing and quite frightening at times. The sound design is exceptional, very immersive and captivating. You will be unnerved at times, I guarantee it.

[h2] The Missions [/h2]

Now, we have to talk about the missions. I'm still in the process of working through the main story, but generally missions are given via dialogue with NPCs. These are provided in the style of Morrowind, wherein some dialogue is voice acted, but most is simply reading a text box. 

The vast majority of missions seem to be fetch or kill quests. Go here, kill this guy, get this document, etc. There isn't a whole lot of variety or creativity there.

[h2] The Gunplay [/h2]

Another important thing to point out is the gunplay. The battles in this game can be lengthy due to most enemies being bullet sponges. I mean, you can shoot an entire clip into an enemy at point blank range and the guy will still be alive. On top of this, enemies appear to respawn after a certain period of time. I had an instance where I had to defend an area from a wave of bandit. Once I killed the wave and got the mission complete notice, another wave came at me. My guess is that the game didn't register the mission complete or otherwise just reset the area to add a new horde, I don't know...

Anyway, [b] I HIGHLY recommend playing the game of the hardest difficulty, master. [/b] Why? because the way difficulty works in this game is that it adjusts the amount of damage that bullets do across the board as opposed to messing with NPC stats. This means that at higher difficulties, you are more vulnerable, but enemies are easier to kill. Weird, right?

[h2] Survival [/h2]

This game includes several survival mechanisms. You have to eat occasionally, you have to keep your radiation exposure down, your guns tend to jam in the middle of firefights, and you have a depleting fatigue bar. While you have a ton of inventory space, your character can only carry 50kg. If you go over this limit, you can still walk and run around, however your fatigue bar will deplete faster and once its depleted, your character becomes momentarily immobile. This is terribly annoying, especially because the distances you have to walk are vast and due to this mechanic, you simply can't sprint from point A to point B, you have to take your time.

[h2] The Mods [/h2]

Perhaps the worst anomalies in the game are the bugs. This game's code was scripted on a sheet of toilet paper. The game crashes for several random reasons. If you eat food directly out of a dead enemy's inventory instead of putting it into your first -- game crash. If an NPC spawns at the other end of the map with a disrupted code -- game crash. [b] I HIGHLY recommend getting the ZRP mod which updates the game and fixes some of these issues. [/b] There will still be issues with the mod, but at least the game will be somewhat playable. There are other mods as well that update graphics and completely overhaul the experience, so be sure to explore Nexus or simply google some STALKER mods.

[h2] The Verdict [/h2]

STALKER is a kind of curiosity. It's an early 2000s game that, despite its flaws and bugs, was undoubtedly a masterpiece for its time. Today, the game is somewhat dated when compared to newer games like Fallout that basically offer similar experiences in a more optimized and grander way. However, STALKER has a unique and unmistakable atmosphere that grips you from time to time. This game gets intense and the environment has a tendency to provide you with unexpected situations that almost seem like they're scripted, but are actually fully organic and random. 

It's a game worth checking out and definitely a game worth modding. At the core level, STALKER is an excellent FPS RPG that has a lot to offer. With a few mods installed, it can make for an epic experience and all at a fraction of the cost of a Bethesda title.

I have to say stalker is one of the most if not THE most immersive world I've ever played through, after playing everything except Clear sky FTM (SOC, COP, and ANOMALY). It absolutely Astounds me at how much lore and little tidbits there are, If you're in the crave for an INCREDIBLY realistic and difficult post apocalyptic FPS this is it. Using your artifact detector and collecting/selling artifacts is so fun to me. Guns are sometimes a bit weird, ammo is rare, It's challenging with things like bleeding, radiation, elements, high damage enemies, and mutants that are varying in many ways, you have to work and progress for the cool armors you want. Certain zones and enemies you come across as well as anomalies require certain protection. Anomalies in these have all kinds of different types and there's even like hanging grass that smacks you if you get too close. There is a Freaking Message Log in your PDA (basically a pad that allows you to see achievements, Relationships with other factions, Every Word Spoken In The Game and the time/date it was said, as well as types of mutants, etc.) Not to mention there are plenty of factions to come across and learning about all of them is Wack. Now I have to say these games (Before HOC comes out) can be VERY linear (with some cool plot twists), It's really about what you do while playing that makes it fun. Take Care Stalker. The zone is a hard place to overcome.

The best place to start with the STALKER Series.
If you're a newcomer to the series I highly recommend playing this and its sequels (Clear Sky and Call of Pripyat) before you go jumping into mods like Anomaly.

Yes the SoC is dated,  yes SoC is buggy and there are two reasons for that

Shadow of Chernobyl was originally intended to be released in 2003. GSC was too ambitious and it got delayed multiple times until THQ stepped in, the game got scaled back and was finally able to release in 2007. Judging by the textures in some of the areas of SoC I wouldn't be a bit surprised if those are the same textures used in builds from '03 and '04.

As for the bugginess, X-Ray engine has been a absolute nightmare even in development, however SoC and its sequel CoP are both stable enough to be played without mods. However if you do want to patch some existing bugs there is a mod for this came specifically called Zone Reclamation Project which cleans up many bugs in v1.0006 while keeping the game vanilla.

This game is pretty neat, has a somewhat interesting story that takes inspiration from Roadside Picnic, difficulty isn't as bad as everyone says it is. I highly recommend this. I wont spoil the story for you just go and play this. 

I give it an 8.5/10, SoC might be janky at times but do I care? Not really, STALKER's entire setting  and plot is great and I cant wait to see what GSC has in store for Stalker 2 Heart of Chornobyl/Chernobyl.

Silly game, but way too outdated and buggy for someone like me that didn't grow up with it. I've tried finishing it both with and without ZRP, but it feels like I have to brute force my way through every area with trial and error rather than strategy and mechanical skills.

A lot of blockades have gaps in the hitboxes so the enemy can shoot straight through them even if there's nothing that visually indicates that they should be able to do so. Wooden boxes and such are obviously breakable, but concrete walls and metal containers shouldn't be.

I understand how the aiming works. You need to wait some time between each shot for them to deal full damage at max accuracy or whatever. This is just annoying and doesn't really work when there are enemies right up in your face. It would make more sense if your camera would sway or have it move with recoil, but it might not be supported or whatever with this engine since the game is from 2007. I don't mind the range limit of weapons so that isn't exactly a problem for me, but I'd rather be able to hit literally any of my bullets from close to medium range.

The story isn't particularly interesting. The atmosphere is cool though. A bit too dark sometimes and the flashlight doesn't exactly make it easier to see a lot of the time since it removes all contrasts. Kind of like driving in the city at night for someone that has astigmatism except for the massive lines shooting out from every light source.

Metro 2033 feels pretty similar to this game. That game has a more linear story without open world, but it feels way better to play and I actually care about the story somewhat. The stalker trilogy is pretty cheap on sale so it won't be a major setback for you if steams 2 hour return policy isn't enough for you to form an opinion, but it's not worth it at full price.

I might come back to this game at some point with aurora or maybe even anomaly. The base game still sucks by modern standards though.

Stalker: SOC is to FPS games what Morrowind is to RPGs. The graphics are terrible, the combat is clunky and the game at times feels fundamentally broken. BUT! at the same time, Stalker is a game that oozes a unique atmosphere and style that is unrivalled. There is a reason why it has maintained a cult following after so many years.

MODS: Now one thing I can't really stress enough, after my own recent experience is you really are better off just playing the game vanilla if it is your first time, now I was one of those people who played GAMMA and then came to the original trilogy looking to replicate the same experience. Put simply, it doesn't really work with SOC, any modpack either changes too much about the game so that you are not getting the original experience, or simply doesn't change enough to make it worth it.

Stick to vanilla for your first time, or you may regret it like I did.

Liked it but suffers greatly from it's age and even feels older than some of it's contemporaries. Don't get me wrong I enjoyed this game but the Jank was unending. Intriguing atmosphere, concepts, game systems and an ambitious amount of content, but all undercut by bugs or poor design. Plenty of the classic random difficulty spikes of older games which I guess is neither here nor there if you know what you're signing up for, but still most times I died I felt annoyed by the inconvenience rather than sufficiently challenged. Gunplay often felt clumsy and rng based. I could fire at an enemy's head dead on with a whole clip and not get any feedback or the same scenario could result in a crispy one tap. 30 hours and I was never sure iron-sights gave me any mechanical advantage over hip-fire (scopes notwithstanding) and with the recoil animations often obscured the view so I found I was hip-shotting far more than felt right. I will say the enemy Ai made for interesting engagements and was just smart enough and perhaps more importantly the right kind of dumb for a game that gets more arcadey towards it's climax, however I signed on expecting stealth and there is little real stealth on offer here. That and there is a bug with stealth where loading a save in enemy territory would alert everyone in the area  putting the player in danger of a soft or hard-lock. Several of the faction quest givers I came upon were killed repeatedly on their first mission preventing me from what I can only assume was a decent chunk of optional content unless I would repeatedly backtrack through saves. I found that my usual survival horror instincts of hording useful or valuable items resulted more in overloading and impacting the already cumbersome movement mechanics, keeping me managing my inventory more than was fun or ignoring vast amounts of goodies on the ground. Tbf I ended up with hundreds of thousands of Ru which apparently was way too much given the greed ending only takes over 50k and there was little on sale more useful than new armor. Admittedly I played slowly and carefully, but having to be economical with resources didn't feel very rewarding or necessary given that guns and ammo only become more powerful and plentiful as you progress. The secret stashes mechanic was fairly interesting but sort of disincentivized exploration unless there was a marker on my map. Anywho definitely a game with potential. Some re-balancing and quality of life adjustments would work wonders here. Might check out the sequels or one of the various popular mods Like Gamma given I really wanted to like this one, but I cannot in good conscience recommend this to anyone without an immense amount of free time and an extreme curiosity for odd old games.

This is one of the best First Person Shooters ever made. Loot works very much like battle royale games in that you open the inventory of the downed person and transfer what you want back and forth - I suspect they originally stole it from STALKER. Prior to STALKER a downed enemy just shat weapons or whatever on the ground for you to pick up. There are no RPG stats, just better equipment, and the best part of that is that the equipment matters.A soft target is a soft target but some aren't as soft as others, and they know it. A bandit wearing a leather duster will keep there distance unless you act skittish and stay back waiting for them. You do that with military or other more heavily armed and armored types and they will push straight to your hiding spot.

The story is decent if you care about it, otherwise you can ignore it and just talk to a few people when safe and follow mission points on the map, and at times it is f***ing unforgiving. Guns don't have pixel perfect accuracy for starters. You use the starting pistol at any range beyond about 50 feet and you're never going to hit shit. You spray and pray and you'll never hit shit. You take your time and aim, and you're going to miss some because every gun in the game is old soviet hardware (and some made up) that has been through the wringer already. Groupings aren't always the tightest, but if you take your time and learn the ones you have, then head shots still drop most like flies, once you get some decent hardware.

You'll see some goofy mutant critters in the wild a bit, nothing crazy. 
Til it gets weird.

If you've never played STALKER, I highly recommend it. While the series is very similar in theme to the Metro series, this is due largely to the fact that their source material, or the original inspiration, is the same - the 1979 S.T.A.L.K.E.R. movie by Andrei Tarkovsky.

Even at its age the game holds up really well imo, and you should absolutely get it.

Real-world elements blend seamlessly with fictional anomalies and mutants, making the game a fun open-world exploration FPS.

To use mods with STALKER , you will first need to edit your fsgame.ltx -file found in the games install folder 
Open this file with a text editor like Notepad , and find the following line
$game_data$ = false| true| $fs_root$| gamedata
Change the false value to true , save the file
Now all you need to do is copy the mods gamedata folder into your own stalker dir
To merge or patch mods , keep overwritting the folder.

This is perhaps one of the very first desktop games I discovered, if not THE first one. My dad played this when I was six or so, hence I wasn't allowed to play it, but I watched him play over his shoulder and I vividly remember being fascinated by the graphics and gameplay. I can say the same for Clear Sky, too. But he never played Call of Pripyat.

Now, two decades later, I finally bought my first PC and the first game that came to mind when thinking of what to play was STALKER. There's nothing quite like the Zone and its atmosphere, even after all these years later with refined horror and better graphics. The story definitely felt kind of short, but if you're working full time and only have a bit of spare time in your week, like me, then the length of the game is satisfying; I completed it after two months of installing it. With this game done and knowing the story of Clear sky, I'm excited to start that, and still have a third game that I've never played as dessert.

I recommend this game (as well as the rest of the franchise) to anyone who grew up with games before the 00's, or if you're an enjoyer of crappy graphics and fun-bad gameplay.

Distinguished as a timeless masterpiece, this opus has transcended the boundaries of mere entertainment to etch a cultural legacy across the expanse of Eastern Europe. Beyond its geographical impact, this magnum opus has left an indelible and ever-lasting mark on the global gaming community. Its narrative prowess and immersive gameplay have not only captivated the hearts of players but have become a benchmark for excellence in the ever-evolving realm of interactive entertainment. Through its influence, this monumental creation stands not just as a testament to its artistic brilliance but as a cultural phenomenon that stretches far beyond the confines of the gaming world, enriching the cultural tapestry of Eastern Europe and claiming it's place in history.

This game is the reason I started playing on PC from scummy console. I had an interest in Chernobyl and that brought me to this game. My crappy laptop could barely run it but boy did I have an experience because it was terrifying. At the start the game seems quite bad. The game is very buggy and you will find the first mission doesn't go away after completing unless installing a mod. After you leave the first area all hell starts to break loose. Every now and again the games physics will break or crash unless you have a miracle. You almost create your own story from that point as every firefight you encounter will be different. The main story is very vague and there are many different routes that you can take to get around the situation. Walking as weird sense of tension that no other game brings. The randomness of firefights and mutants make sure you have a panic attack mid game. The level of immersion is absolutely astounding. Most people just leave the game after it breaks as they probably didn't give it a second chance. But do try to give it as many as possible, try out different mods and see what works for you. If you want a less buggy experience look for Call of Pripyat or wait for STALKER 2. But give this game as many chances as possible because it may be the best experience of your life because it sure is mine. This game isn't for everyone and will take time to love, but trust me, play it. There are many reasons not to play this game like the buggy engine or the air headed AI. With mods, the game comes together. PLAY IT it may be the time of your life. It might be difficult but i do adore it.

I had always been told that STALKER is an awesome series dripping with style that outdoes most other post-apocalyptic shooters. I had always been told the truth. Old as the games are, they are still extremely fun and feel great to play. I'd recommend SoC to anyone looking for a captivating, shorter narrative shooter. Can't wait to play the next!

"Get out of here, STALKER!"

This game invoked memories of playing the original Half-life game.  It's filled to the brim with story, atmosphere, and gun-play.  This isn't a run-and-gun game like Call of Duty or Battlefield, as it requires some thought and strategy.  It's a survival FPS, so if you run out with guns blazing ... you'll die over and over.  It's a great prelude to the Metro series and requires similar tactics of scrounging around and trying to make every shot count while conserving your ammo (kill or be killed).

The Eastern European crowd have managed to push the engine to its limits and come up with some wonderful and often "hardcore" mods.  If you want to experience pain, desolation, and despair ... look towards Misery, Last Day and Dead Air.   If you want to enjoy the open sandboxness of the Exclusion Zone, try Anomaly.  There are quite a number of other mods out there, but I can't speak Russian and  can't comment on them.  

Stay "Cheeki Breeki!" and remember to always carry some spare vodka, ammo, and medkits/bandages; you never know when you'll run into a camouflaged bloodsucker or pack of blind dogs.  Lastly use your bolts, as you don't want to wind up running blindly into some anomalous area and die a painful death.

Excellent game and worth all your time, all the way up to the last hour or so.. The game is amazing, the atmosphere and ambience S.T.A.L.K.E.R brings to the table is just unmatched and there are very few games even now that capture the bleak post apocalyptic vibe that stalker does. A lot of people complain about the gun play, and yes, the guns are pretty inaccurate and enemies are pretty spongy, but honestly once you get your hands on your first AK the combat really starts to pick up. As long as you keep progressing, you'll start to feel pretty overpowered closer to the middle of the game. The world feels really alive in a way that no other game from that era could have matched, and although the AI definitely shows its age, it never really felt dumb. I fully recommend this, apart from the very end of the game which falls apart a bit, the rest of the game is a real passion project. Already bought clear sky and am moving on to the next one

[b]SPOILER AHEAD[/b]

Like I said, the last hour or so once you enter the CNPP really sucked for me compared to the rest of the game, it focuses on the worst parts of the game as it basically dissolves into a hallway shooter with TONS of really tanky spongy enemies just thrown at you one after the other. And although ammo is definitely not in short supply here, and you do get an exo suit of your own if you choose to go for the secret lab canon endings, I found myself having to spam auto save because of bastard RPG troops blasting me from obscure angles and one shotting me. I definitely feel like the portal hopping section goes on for far too long and the game would have been better having the entire last part of the game after refusing to help the c-consciousness cut. 

[b]SPOILER DONE[/b]

Anyway, go buy these games, play them, and then jump into stalker Anomaly, which is a free combination of all three games' areas, with a very dynamic world and completely fresh take on the world of stalker from the perspective of someone who isn't the main character :D

Have I told you before? What is a bug, huh?
Bug... is the exact repetition of the same action every time,
In the hope of a feature, that's what a bug is.
The first time I heard it, I don't remember who said this shit, I BOOM, I killed it.
That's the point hahahaha... Okay? He was right,

No, no, no, no, no, no, please, this time it's going to be different.
I'm sorry, I don't like the way... You're looking at me.
Okay? Do you have a problem with your head? You think I'm pulling your leg, I'm lying.
Fuck you, okay? Fuck you.
It's okay, hahaha.
I'll calm down, bro, I'll calm down.
The point is, okay.
The point is, I already killed you.
And it's not that I'm a fucking idiot, okay?
It's like water under the bridge...

STALKER: Shadow Of Chernobyl (or "Chornobyl" if you'd like the ucranian romantization) is a majestic game. Yeah, it's pretty hard, yeah, you'll die a lot, yeah, maybe you'll rage up a bit. But, overall, it's fantastic. The artstyle and worldbuilding is pretty unique, if you look at one screenshot you'll easily recognize it. The gameplay and atmosphere, with the story, which I'll talk about in a minute, are the strenghts of this game. It's really rare for a horror game to continue being scarry after 15 hours, however, STALKER: SoC can do that for 40+ hours straight. And God, the atmosphere, it's superb, amazing really. 
The story is actually amazing too, it's simple, but it works like a charm. And the multiple endings are pretty neat too, even though there could be some better implementation. That's because, basically, the choices that alter the ending are kind of pretty late in the game, so you can just reload a save 5 hours prior to the ending and repeat it, following a guide from the wiki or whatever, and then boom, you've done all the endings. 
Now, the only negative aspect that I can point at is the late game. When you reach the final area things feel... rushed. Don't get me wrong, I enjoyed the final part, but it just felt... idk, off. It seems like the devs just spammed strong enemies for no reason at instances, and there's times where there's a room with like 8 dudes staring a wall or some shit. I'm aware of the dev hell this game went through, but still, I cannot ignore the fact that the end segment is worse than the rest of the game in those regards. 
Alas, this game is pretty good, very good tbh. 
8.5/10

THQ made this game a legend.
I can't imagine people loving it today, if the devs continued with their original "solyanka".
Everything in this game is paced perfectly. The lore, that people still talk about. Every little stash is a story. The Zone is a living and breathing organism, with mutants and stalkers roaming about, doing their things. Exploration is rewarded, as well as doing quests, giving you powerful tools for progression. Music is great, and gives an additional layer to each area. Each track gives you the perfect descriptive feeling of the respective area. The graphics are photorealistic and pleasant to look at.

This game stands the test of time. I played it totally vanilla, no mods. It has native 4K support!! What?! And it really does look terrific. The characters, the story, the gameplay still feel very fresh. The immersion is top-tier. The horror elements remain highly unsettling. Great ballistics modeling, plenty of guns and the tactical component to survival and battle is a potent blend of deliberate strategy and unmitigated chaos.

Yeah, still some CTD's now and again. Couple glitches, a bit of jank, nothing compared to the dumpster fires some AAA publishers put out. Stalker still runs fine in 2023. It's worth exploring everything, this game rewards curiosity. I never spoiled any of the story for myself in all these years, but it's terrific, in my opinion the plot totally delivers on the mystery and darkness of the Zone.

The plant itself is fantastic, surreal and epic. The endgame pays off nicely. I played on "Master" difficulty because this is the game that GSC originally created. It's a very hard game, however, so the publisher, THQ, made them implement difficulty levels at the last second, so players wouldn't be turned off by the game. You take less damage and do more damage, at various scales, on the lower difficulty levels. The hardest difficulty level is the game that GSC developed and playtested, and while very challenging, it's still quite surmountable. Don't wimp out, play it on Master!

S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is a game which I've attempted to play in the past but I never got particularly far. This time, however, I was determined. The start of the game is quite rough. Your armor most likely couldn't protect you against paper cuts. Your gun and the sawed-off shotgun you can pick up in the first "mission" wouldn't be able to hit an enemy even if it was lodged inside of their skull. But I marched on, as the atmosphere and general intrigue was enough for me.

Once I got to Rostok, however, things changed. Guns could hit things. My armor did something, sometimes. The tactical gameplay suddenly became incredibly engaging as it no longer felt like I was fighting the game mechanics. I became a real fighting force in the Zone that bandits would fear. I looked forward to firefights.

The more atmospheric and claustrophic areas remain my favorites, however. You get really immersed in the story and setting, wanting to figure out what the hell is happening in the Zone as you progress through the story. The final few areas are also incredible. There's something about the feeling of [spoiler]walking through Pripyat and Chernobyl for the first time[/spoiler]. It's a very powerful, emotional feeling.

To mention some things I'm somewhat indifferent on, the UI can be somewhat clunky at times. A lot of side missions resort to "go to X, kill/find Y, return". Lots of backtracking. Luckily they aren't necessary. I ended up doing a few that ended up being on the path towards main objectives.

Overall, the game is a masterclass in making an incredibly atmospheric and immersive experience. The general gameplay also feels good (once you get weapons that can hit things). The game does show its age at times, but I found it to be mostly endearing.

It's a semi-broken game with frequent crashes, but I found the visuals to really hold up (especially for having come out in 2007) and the story to be surprisingly engaging. I got about 16 hours out of it from meandering around and pursuing side gigs near my next objectives, but with all the little missions and unmarked areas I never even touched, I could see others easily doubling that.
It's an FPS, but is not standard at all. The S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series places a heavy emphasis on slow-paced combat, teaching you (through death and terror) the ideal ranges for your weapons, how to clear corners, and when to just run away. When in the Zone, you'll quickly learn that you're close to the bottom of the food chain, and you'll be smart to fight like a coward.
The story is an above-average amnesia tale that sees you jump through hoops to learn who you are, but pays off in a big way. Though the game isn't flush with memorable characters, those who you do meet really stick with you for their wonderful (if repetitive) voice acting and lively dialogue.
If you're looking for a weekend survival shooter that might get you into a series (and possibly GAMMA which I love), then give S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Shadow of Chernobyl a shot.
