This is a game full of dense atmosphere and nailbiting combat encounters with elements of resource management and some inventory juggling depending on your playstyle. This combination of art and gameplay direction creates an immersive experience that to an extend can only be found in this game series.

Now the elephant in the room, "Shadow of Chernobyl" has some hilarious bugs and in my experience is prone to crashes during the latter half of the game. I didn't experience anything gamebreaking, but your mileage may vary. Examples of bugs I encountered were stashes that became empty if not looted immediately and remained marked on the map forever. There was also a bonfire that became cursed and started killing NPCs that chose to gather around it, seemingly pulling their bodies inside it.

I would still recommend the game, because in my opinion it remains a very unique blend of Horror, Survival and FPS and at least for me the overall experience outweighed the somewhat annoying parts of it.

Holds up relatively well since I last played in 2012 (per Steam) though the graphics have never been particularly great.

I'm not sure how it's classified, but I think of it something like a survival horror lite FPS - some of the environments can be creepy (IMO) with various sounds from soldiers to various beasts and anomalies.  You have gear that degrades and gets worse, you have a hunger system (it seems it's only once a day).  For the most part, enemies (and you!) can go down with just one headshot no matter what difficulty (contrary to popular belief the difficulty levels aren't broken where Master is considered the "easiest/fair/whatever) so fights can get tense - add to a bleeding mechanic where you have to be careful.  Anomalies around the world can hurt you as can Radiation.  You have a weight limit so you have to basically manage everything properly - ammo, health items, gear, etc.  There is a night system where the dark can be dark (though humans use flashlights which can make it easy to spot/target them. 

It's not without issues.  I find the game to be quite buggy even with the Zone Reclamation Project (unofficial patch which I recommend even if you don't use any other mod).. The game crashed a couple of times without warning. I had to restart once because everyone disappeared.  Now, its a living world and a lot of people can move around and get killed by something, but when I say everyone disappeared, i mean it - I would go to say Bar where not even the Barkeep was there.  You can find stashes which contain goodies, but only if you get the coordinates by checking the bodies of the fallen, however even this had issues with stashed being completely empty. I've seen people online say this happens if you open a cache before getting the coordinates, but this happened with ones I know I didn't open them.

Combat can be a bit annoying as well because human enemies can get staggered which means after the first bullet, you can't hurt them right away until they finish being staggered .  Of course, this doesn't apply to you and enemies can easily stunlock you.

The item degradation system is also annoying because there's no way to repair without enabling it (a Duty and Freedom guy) with the Zone Reclamation Project so you don't get to attached to the good stuff. There are plenty of replacements and you could technically repair armor with 4 or 5 artifacts of the same type of an anomaly (i.e. 4 or 5 Electtro Batteries and stand in an electro anomaly).

For the most part, the optional quests weren't special.  You get items and the quests that ask for a mutant part or artifact usually gives you as much as it's worth which is nice as Sid/Barkeep only buy them at a fraction, but eventually you meet Sakahrov in Yantar who will buy mutant parts and artifacts for full price and your money issues go away.  Early on, you just need to take advantage of the fact that items don't really disappear if dropped on the world (i.e. not in a body or certain boxes which do disappear) so early game is mostly just gathering the guns of the early enemies and carrying as much as you can to a trader.

I'e also always thought the game basically drops in quality once you get the Brain Scorcher quest and go to the Red Forest which basically leads to the end game.  At this point, the game basically just becomes a weak FPS IMO.  You go from exploring a living world as you battle small groups of foes here and there to fighting Monolith in large battles where you have to dodge Snipers (who you don't face until this point), radiation, and anomalies.  I guess I also started getting tired by the time i went to Lab-X-16 in Yantar when Snorks or whatever these four legged-human-zombie things were as they were more annoying to fight than anything.  End game basically just felt like a tedious slog compared to what came before as you go through areas fighting the soldier (and snipers) and later even helicopter as a timer counts down.  By this point, I just used Zone Reclamation Project to cheat in an invulnerability artifact. I  honestly started having fun again as i knifed the enemies while immortal.

It's hard to describe a game that just vibes with you through and through in words. I remember getting it back when it was released and how blown away i was by how awesome it looked when i first booted it up (altho the animations were awful even for the standards back then), and how cool the atmosphere was.

And that's one of the biggest strengths of Shadow of Chernobyl (SoC) and really the whole STALKER game series: The atmosphere. Even after having played it more times than i can count, probably around a dozen times, i STILL get chills when i walk into certain areas. And even knowing exactly when and where certain enemies will spawn, i will still freak out, and i will flinch and get adrenaline spikes. No game gets to me quite like SoC.

I will probably fail miserably explaining what makes up the awesome atmosphere in SoC, but i will try anyway:
The setting (inspired by the 1979 movie Stalker / the book Roadside Picnic) is inherently pretty unsettling, with the world essentially having gone weird and dangerous in "the Zone". The music and sound effects absolutely contribute to that eery feeling of danger (shoutout to all the squeaky rotating lamps, you know who you are). And danger is everywhere, if not from enemies then because of potential radiation or anomalies that will simply kill you if you walk into them. Just going from one area to the next, you need to always be on the lookout. Which also adds a neat way of progression: The more you learn about anomalies and how they look and what they do, the better you will be as a "STALKER". Add to this a lot of armed conflict, and you'll be stumbling from one hazard into the next. You also have very limited carry weight, meaning you need to really think about how many weapons, ammo and meds you want to take with you. This is not one of those games where you can carry a whole arsenal, more than 2 or 3 weapons and you will struggle with being overburdened a lot.

All in all, if that's your kind of thing then the atmosphere is just fantastic and i can't think of many games whose atmosphere is even remotely as good. But atmosphere is also not the only thing the game has going for it, this can obviously be subjective but i think the gunplay in this game is exceptional as well. The guns just feel (and sound) good, you have a decent selection of different guns too. There are also a couple different ammo types (as in, regular and armor piercing ammo for the same caliber) and you can modify weapons too.

All that said, I'll be the first to admit that on a technical level, this game has issues, and a lot of them. There are tons of bugs, and the game also lacks polish. It's overall a pretty raw experience. To get to certain endings, you pretty much have to make use of walkthroughs.
That said, the game also has a pretty healthy modding community and various mods will help fix some of the bugs and issues. Even if you pick the game up for the first time, i would recommend to get at least some mods that keep the experience close to vanilla but fix bugs. And if you want to change the game more, there are plenty of mods to choose from as well.

Overall, what it boils down to is this: Do you like the atmosphere? If so, then that helps a lot in looking over some of the issues the game has and enjoying it anyway. Because if this is for you, it has the potential to be frikking amazing. And if you don't like the atmosphere, if you can look at screenshots and/or gameplay footage and be "meh", then it's probably not worth it and just not the game for you. For me personally, i have spent hundreds and hundreds of hours on this game and i keep coming back to it even more than 15 years later because nothing else can quite scratch the same itch. It's not perfect, but i still love it wholeheartedly.

*Spoiler-free*
I had been hearing a lot about the S.T.A.L.K.E.R series for a while, especially because of all the Anomaly (and GAMMA, to a lesser extent) content floating around on YouTube and other places. Finally got around to playing it after having bought it more than half a year ago, and I didn't regret a single dime, or a single second I spent on it. As suggested by everybody on the subreddit and on YouTube, I played it on the highest difficulty (Master) and disabled crosshairs. Also, worth noting is that I played it vanilla, in spite of everybody suggesting that one should at least install ZRP (bug fixes mod). In the almost 37 hours I played the game, I did not encounter a single bug, but I'd rather attribute that to my luck than the game being polished, because most players who went vanilla seem to have encountered at least a couple.

I'd start off by saying that its reputation as being a tough game is not without merit. The first couple of hours of the game are an absolute nightmare no matter how good a gamer you are, and that's an intended design choice. The ballistics are realistic, taking into account bullet drop and the fact that guns aren't accurate 100% of the times even in real life. The guns also take into account their range, which makes bullets disappear after they surpass their intended range. But that's as far as realism goes.

In Shadow of Chernobyl, there exists a complex RPG-style tier system for weapon calibres, which starts at your standard 9x18 mm pistol rounds, to 9x19 mm SMG rounds, to the 5.45 mm Warsaw Pact rifle calibre, to the 5.56 mm NATO calibre to finally, the heavy 9x39 mm subsonic rounds that only a few weapons chamber (not included 7.62 mm sniper rifle rounds and 12 gauge shotgun). Almost each ammo calibre has 2-3 variants as well, such as sniper rounds or armour penetration rounds. 

There also exist artifacts, which grant various kinds of buffs to the player such as electric or chemical protection, usually in exchange for an almost equivalent sacrifice the player has to make in another one of the 10-odd statistics, such as bulletproof cap or explosion protection. These artifacts are birthed in anomalies, which are pockets of phenomena formed as a result of the Zone's corruption of the laws of physics.

I describe the beginning as a nightmare because you'd be lucky to kill anything with the pistols, which feel like literal peashooters against even the weakest of enemies. That is, if you do actually manage to hit anything with them, because owing to SoC's game mechanics, you intentionally miss most of the shots you take with the cheaper, initial calibres, which sort of forces you to switch to NATO weaponry in the late game. It also strongly encourages you to aim down sights, and use optics as much as possible. Once you get a scope and get hold of your first rifle, the game mellows down in terms of difficulty and actually opens your mind up to the wondrous atmosphere it possesses.

I'm not much of a gamer, but I'm pretty sure that the atmosphere that the game builds is almost unparalleled. The way the world goes on without you, witnessed by the fact that almost any NPC can die no matter how important they were to the quests, and how they're just as fragile and prone to dying in the Zone as you are makes the world actually feel real. The game does a remarkable job of making you feel lonely and desolate while at the same time be on your toes. Mutants spawn randomly, and exhibit realistic behavious such as hunting in packs if they're dogs, sleeping, scavenging, etc which brings the world together. Daytime in the Zone is still doable, but nighttime will have you constantly on edge, and will make you want to sit by the warm campfire of a loner camp, or while your time away in one of the handful of friendly factions' bases, and wait for the night to pass as you stock up on ammunition and meds for the next excursion in the Zone.

All of this is up until you're above ground. Once you go to one of the few underground locations in the game, such as the Agroprom Underground or one of the X-labs, the entire equation changes. It doesn't matter if you're armed to the teeth with a PSZ-9Md Universal Protection armour and a G36, (both being some of the choicest of armours and guns in the game) the game ruthlessly does not allow you to lower your guard even for a split second, be it a Bloodsucker or a Controller, or the odd invisible poltergeist hurling boxes and barrels at you, or a human enemy lurking in the shadows before suddenly opening fire and killing you in a flash. The rewarding feeling that I experienced after making it through each of these areas was stupendous, because the game never makes you feel like a God. It rudely awakens you to the fact that no matter how well-kitted you are, even the most basic enemies can shred through you if you don't take a pragmatic, well thought out approach.

The lore is deep if you dig into it, and almost all of the factions seem logical if you adopt an unbiased perspective. Almost none of them are extreme enough for you to write off right away, and actually make you ponder over which one to support because they all seem valid choices.

Finally, I want to end this overly long wall of text by saying that that developers originally intended for a myriad of features that weren't in the retail release, like the ability to join factions which was added in the later games, (at least to my knowledge, because I've only just begun Clear Sky) and much more advanced mutant AI. The human AI is already way ahead of its time, with enemies exhibiting advanced tactics such as a few members of a group pinning down the player, while others flank them while they're not looking. The AI can be cheesed, of course, but that doesn't take away from the fact that it's superior to that of most other games even today. The dynamic lighting is beautiful. To conclude, to anyone who has patience, and who doesn't play games for the sake of simulating a power fantasy should give it a try. All you need to keep in mind is that you're an ordinary dude, and also need to overcome the aforementioned initial hurdle of having pathetic weapons. After that, the Zone shall mesmerise you with its eerie but addicting allure, something that'll want you to spend a lot more time exploring instead of rushing the main quests, which I did, which is why it took me 37 hours to complete the game. Good hunting, stalker, may the Zone bestow the best artifacts upon you.

I've finished all three games now. These games are gems, but have a really awful coat of rust (bugginess and bad balancing and progression) that you need to scrape off using mods. Particularly Clear Sky, to the point I would recommend skipping that game entirely unless you enjoy having a bad time, and only play this game and Call of Pripyat instead.

For all three games, start by installing the "_RP" mods at a minimum to get the games functional and remove most all the game-breaking bugs and fix other issues when possible. That is ZRP for this game, SRP for Clear Sky, and PRP for Call of Pripyat. Refer to this guide after installing https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=302750759&searchtext=modding
Some overhaul mods aren't compatible, so if you really want to be playing modder's megalomania then skip this, and lookup the file extractor to get whatever config files you need for further tweaks if necessary. 

These games have very active modding scenes, but mostly in Russian/Ukrainian, and for some reason STALKER modders tend to avoid the nexus like the plague and only use moddb, which is horrid in my opinion and makes it much harder to find the good mod(s) you're looking for.

The "_RP" patches tend to leave two/three problems in the vanilla game unfixed or half-fixed: Horribly inaccurate weapons, bullet spongey enemies, and (more debatably) carry weight.

To fix the inaccurate weapons, you'll need to find the dispersion values in three places and adjust them accordingly. Base dispersion is a value added together and measured in whole degrees, and if you tweak dispersion to end up in the negatives then you'll essentially start re-introducing it.
-The player character's several "disp_" values in gamedata > configs > creatures > actor.ltx
-Each individual weapon's .ltx in gamedata > configs > weapons
-And also the ammo used by the weapons (why???) in gamedata > configs > weapons > weapons.ltx
The ones in actor.ltx are tricky and seem to use some odd formula which also seems to vary between games. In this game - SoC - "disp_aim" seems to be multiplicative off "disp_base", so setting it to a low number like 0.0167 (1/60, essentially converting the whole degrees of dispersion into arcminutes as it should be) seems to be enough to fix the issue with no further changes.

Bullet spongey enemies is a surprisingly, weirdly multi-faceted issue in SoC that I don't fully understand. The simplest way to fix it is to go into ALL weapon .ltx files and set "time_to_aim" to 0, and then in-game always aim for the head - which does 10x damage. Doing more than this is complicated, but I'd also go into gamedata > configs > creatures > m_dog.ltx (the file for wild dogs) and reducing their health to 50, because they somehow survive 3 headshots otherwise.

And the last (debatable) issue usually untouched by the _RP patches is carry weight. It's in gamedata>config>creatures>actor.ltx and gamedata>config>system.ltx as several terms involving "weight" and "mass". Make sure the walk weight is the higher number while the others are all the same.

And with that you're ready to start having a much smoother experience. I'd personally suggest playing both SoC and CoP "vanilla" (with just these modifications done) as a first playthrough, and skipping Clear Sky because it's a fucking mess.

But all that adds to the gameplay, it’s simply an amazing game, despite the outdated graphics. 

Tip, play on Master difficulty, even if you suck. Find the Merc suit hidden in the starting village. Try to find an AK as early as possible. Use the box in the bar to store items. Game gets easier quickly. Final missions are highly radioactive, so wear an appropriate suit. 

A high replayability due to the multiple endings and the fact that already very early game you influence the game’s outcome without actually realising. 

I hope STALKER 2 won’t ruin the experience.

I highly recommend the entire S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series and many of its mods. Weirdly enough, Shadow of Chernobyl might be my least favorite to play out of the main-line trilogy. Many believe it is the best game out of the bunch. I do not necessarily disagree, but to me the campaign feels a little too long and the gameplay mechanics are a bit thin. However, those comments do not stop SoC from being an absolutely essential experience. Anyone who can withstand some endearing jank and is interested in the origins of modern titles like Metro, DayZ, and Escape From Tarkov should take a look at S.T.A.L.K.E.R., starting with Shadow of Chernobyl. The Zone simply provides an experience unlike any other in gaming. I was glad to be back with the first of the series and I know it won’t be long until I return again.

[h1] Atmosphere.
This is the type of atmosphere I like in a game.  [/h1]

Review as a first time player in 2023:

Truly one of the best "live-in" FPS I've ever played. You can just idle at times, do your own side things for people and be part of the world. You feel so small and unimportant. Few characters will ever fully trust you. They all can die. Even on easiest settings you can be deleted almost instantaneously if you're ambushed or out of cover from a single enemy, and they're usually in numbers.

It's magical and held together with sticks and twine. Jankey, some dialogue is misspelled, stuttering when loading in area objects due to outdated X-Ray engine, crashes, map markers that stay after finishing quests, or in the wrong location, objects that take up inventory space after quests that you can't remove, bullet and enemies clipping through walls, items through floor, etc. I got soft locked in a wood attic once.

Mechanics:
Weight limits, grid inventory, ammo types, weapon attachments, weapon jams, durability, hunger, radiation, electricity/fire damage, day/night cycle, pda log, separate heal and bleeding bandages, belt slot for artifact perks, independent npc routines, etc.

Despite the bugs, despite the age. 
[i]Fantastic. [/i]
New one is very close to release, but this is absolutely worth the play
if you like older, harder games.

I got all three games for $9.99 when it was on sale. I can certainly say that I got my money's worth on this game alone. I really like it. I honestly don't understand all the comments about how the game has not aged well, poor gun play, it needs mods, etcetera. I think we're too spoiled, but even then ... this game from 2007 does the environment and gun play better than most modern games in my opinion. 

We never were some "savior of the world" like in Bethesda games, nor do we have to progress the main story in any way until we want to. After all, why should we rush blindly after we got "killed"? We are just trying to survive in the zone like everyone else. I really like how the game is not centered around the protagonist (or complete thunder c-nt if you choose to be lmao), as you can be walking around and see some place get raided or NPCs fighting one another. A good example of this is usually the Garbage or Agroprom. 

I actually like the graphics. I may be biased, since I grew up with Halo: Combat Evolved and Counter Strike: Source, which look very similar, but after looking through the negative reviews I thought it would be much worse than it was. 
Another thing that I really liked is how the guns actually feel different than one another. A 7.62x39mm will actually "feel" different than a 5.45x39mm or a 5.56x45mm. 

The game is not without its issues though. It is pretty unstable at times. I've crashed multiple times in certain areas which is annoying ASF. It's not game-breaking level of crashing - I would say it's a bit better than unmodded Fallout: New Vegas (One of my all time favorite games), but annoying and breaks immersion sometimes. Sometimes, artifacts will glitch in the ground, especially the circular ones. Also, it's really annoying to be given random quests without talking to anyone (usually defend or wipe an area) since they are timed and the OCD inside of me hates failing them. I have not seen anything truly game breaking yet though, but I am sure there are a lot that I have simply forgotten about or missed.

Overall, I honestly wouldn't buy this game for $19.99 or the bundle for $39.99. They are too old to be priced so high imo. I would wait until it's on sale and then buy it then.

It is old game and there´s plenty times where you can see it. However it is fantastic old game. I played vanilla game so no mods to ``enhance`` experience. 
Atmosphere is fantastic, graphics in 2023 is nothing special but it is old game after all so can´t take any points there. 
Some side missions are a bit boring but you don´t have to play those unless you want more money. Game is hard. (not like new games where normal = easy, it´s more like normal = hard.) (Which isn´t bad thing.)
There´s multiple endings so replayability is there. I loved mechanics of game (and it is impressive considering it´s age), lean, weight, specific ammo type, food etc all made game much more immersive. Add anomalies, different factions of npc (which can be enemies if you make mistakes), different types of enemies and monsters plus radiation zones make this game quite enjoyable. It takes little bit to get into it but once you are warmed up you are hooked up. Story is slow and nowhere close to best I have played (similar would be Metro franchise and I enjoyed those game much more than this one. (but those games are very hard to beat and I still think this game is very much worth playing))
I would suggest this game to anyone who likes post apocalypse games. It was enjoyable experience.

regardless play stalker buy it and support GSC enjoy the world and come back to it after a while and enjoy it a second time. there's nothing on the market like stalker, those that compare it to fallout i believe compare this game unfairly. try and play and form your own opinion and i promise you will have a unique enough experience you wont forget it.

The Ukraine war reminded me about this game because the game is Ukrainian and it takes place in Ukraine as you can guess from the name... Unless you thought Chernobyl was in Belarus or Russia, in which case you should probably look it up on a map.

This, along with Deus Ex, and the original Half Life would have at one point been strong contenders for best single player FPS games of all time. Though time has brought some stiffer competition, S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is at worst a very good albeit flawed game. 

Story? Uh, well you awake in a fictionalized version of the exclusion zone which has fantastic threats such as anomalies that kill people in brutal ways and mutants with psychic powers. Any more details than that are firmly rooted in spoiler territory. The game has open world elements including randomly generated side missions, shopkeepers, loot to sell, respawning mobs, etc; but I never found most of it worth messing with and just rushed through the story. The actual writing for the story isn't particularly interesting, but the build up to actually setting foot in Chernobyl was amazing, and the lorebuilding around the setting is pretty neat. Reaching a new location is a big deal because each new location feels very different, with very different hazards, mutants, and factions inhabiting it. You can't just run straight to Chernobyl either, as there's several story bottlenecks you have to deal with either in order to proceed in that direction or in order to proceed in that direction safely.

OK, gameplay. It's a shooter alright. Although more specifically it's the "everyone has low health" type of shooter. Guns are also fairly inaccurate and get less accurate and reliable as their durability deteriorates, which can make firefights either very tedious at long range or very sporadic quick affairs up close, depending on your weapons.  Armor also has durability to keep track of, in addition to offering different types of protection. In the unmodded game you can't repair durability outside of abusing a glitch using equipped artifacts. Oh right, artifacts. The hazards in the game, called anomalies, often have artifacts near them which have a variety of passive buffs and penalties if you equip them. These aren't just items you equip or sell, they actually are the entire reason why people are in the exclusion zone to begin with so there's some neat integration of gameplay and world building.

There's also several different factions and a variety of unique mutants to fight. Some factions will be friendly to you, others not. They also use different equipment and represent highly variable challenges. Early on you mostly fight poorly equipped bandits, but then later on you'll fight factions of well equipped mercenary/military forces whose body armor actually absorbs a lot of bullets. The mutants vary from blind dogs that attack you, to ghostly enemies, to mostly invisible monsters that take most of your health out in a melee strike, to even a few mutants that use psychic powers.

The game also has fairly good AI. Enemies will take cover, occasionally reposition or even sometimes advance on your position, and NPCs will attempt to fight off hostiles if they encounter them on the road or they approach their camps. They do not use grenades though, and you should be very thankful they don't. 

This game has 2 spinoffs and a proper sequel on the way despite, ya know, the country the studio is in being hit by artillery strikes. There's also a few fan projects to create mods to improve the visuals of the game or change a number of other gameplay factors such as improving enemy AI.  So even if you beat the game, there might be a reason to come back to it.

People have trouble playing this game as a result of its unclear difficulty settings and expectations set by the community.

This title has quite the reputation as the "post-apocalyptic survival simulator", which is due to the overwhelming amount of realism mods in the community. Should you go into this title thinking you are going to play a single-player Tarkov without any prior understanding, you're going to have a bad time.

Take my word - Play this title on hardcore. This is the true "realism" gunplay that everyone is talking about. The difficulty mostly modifies damage and health, meaning that it is often EASIER to play on Hardcore than it is Normal.

-Playing on Normal, every enemy will be a bullet sponge, and you will find yourself frustrated more than anything. Gunplay will feel more like Fallout 4 on Very Hard, you will always be low on ammo, and you will probably have to take awkward bold-faced approaches.

-Playing on Hardcore, enemies will die in around 1-3 well-placed shots, but so will you. You are forced to take this game at the pace it was intended, which may sound like an insult, but is actually it's strong suit. You will have to think tactically to overcome the enemy, making almost every encounter satisfying.

However, if you ARE looking for something that feels closer to a single-player Tarkov, the Radiophobia 3 mod will meet your expectations.

So although Steam has only records ~20 hrs playing time i've actually played hundreds of hours on this game and the series. This game is based on the book "Roadside Picnic"by Arkady Strugatsky who has wrote many Russian scifi novels in the 70s, many censored by the Russian government. I highly recommend reading the book since it will give you background on stalkers (why stalkers do what they do and the consequences of their actions), organizations involved, why the government is hostile to stalkers. Is the game accurate to the book? No, it's very different but the concepts are all there.

I've owned this game since it came out and is by far my favorite game of all time (I started playing video games on an IBM PC DOS 1.0, "Decathlon" and "Zork"), the environment, ambient sounds, game play and overall experience is like no other. To be clear its a Ukraine built game so its not easy or forgiving, progress through this game can be a grind and demoralizing at times. At times you will need to guess at what you need to do because the directive may not be clear, that can be typical of games coming out of the former Soviet Union, just refer to online content to help you through. Be prepared to run out of ammo, health, and death comes with little explanation or warning. With that said you do not have to engage every enemy, if you engage everything you will run out of ammo, sneaking is very key in this game. Explore everything, even if some places look impossible to reach most likely you can reach it, again nothing is easy in this game. In the very beginning of the game if you are a good explorer you will find items before you start venturing out that will help you immediately. The best loot is in the toughest spots!

The game is best played at night with no lights on, it will help you to be fully immersed into the game and the environment. 

FYI - their is an updated version for better graphics if you are willing to search the internet for.

I beat this game in about 16 hours, including a lot of messing around with sidequests. There are a lot of mods that will change how things work, how things look, and add some additional realism, but for the first full playthrough, I thought the vanilla experience was quite solid.  The gun play is initially frustrating, but then you realize how accuracy works in this game, and you adapt.  The atmosphere is rich, the voice acting is good, the story is solid, and the horror elements of the underground labs cannot be overstated.

I've heard a lot about this game over the passed decade, and finally took the time to try it out. This is my first play through on Master difficulty with a simple bug fix mod installed. Although it's an older game, it plays well and the atmosphere is very immersive. Similar to Fallout 3 or New Vegas in that sense. Its not as risky as a dark souls game, but the quicksave feature can really mess you up if you're not careful. You either forget to save and get set back a large amount of time, or you save too quickly and end up getting yourself stuck in a tough position. The world feels very alive and out of your control for the most part. You can have a quest where you need to go meet somebody, just for them to get killed right in front of you (Completely unscripted.) and now your game is screwed up. So again, be careful with your saves. I'm not that far in, but it's been a lot of fun and would easily recommend it to somebody looking for an open world survival game. With the amount of quicksave you're going to be using and falling back on, I would definitely just go straight to Master difficulty.

Great game, totally recommend it. You'll have to install ZRP to fix a handful of bugs though, since the game hasn't aged very well, and continues to decline with newer hardware. One notable issue I had is when scripted enemies refused to spawn until I reloaded my save, and even then it was a 50/50 chance of it working. Stealth is also kind of janky, and enemy alert states are seemingly preserved across saves, so I don't recommend trying to stealth the Agroprom mission until you're able to mostly work around the bugs.

The main quests are also kind of repetitive, mostly amounting to [spoiler]going to a location, picking up documents, and fighting off military/monolith as you escape[/spoiler] but the story and world building are super cool so it's forgivable.

Two quick disclaimers:
1 - I played with the Memories of the Zone mod which made the game run outside of Steam which is why it shows such a low hour count.
2 - This game is only recommended to people who like a challenge. Enjoy stuff like the ArmA series? Then this might be for you. But if you are looking for a fast paced arcade shooter then you will not like this game.

Pros:
Worked out of the box with my 21:9 monitor at 3440x1440 and ran smooth. Not sure if that was the mod's doing but I love not having to tinker with a game to get my ultrawide to work.
The character movement is some of the best I've encountered in an FPS before. Looking around with a mouse is somehow smoother than anything I recall playing and you can see the character readjust his aim with lateral movements. It feels very real without coming off as sluggish.
The combat is quite punishing. Even on the lowest difficulty setting, getting shot by an enemy 5 yards away is pretty much a 1 or 2 hit and quit. Be smart and use cover. The game features a normal crouch and an even lower crouch which is a nice touch. Would be nicer to go prone but oh well.
Medkits aren't magical cure-alls. It is more like an RPG where it causes your health to rise by a certain number of points per second or something so the effects are delayed. While using one or bandaging a wound, you can't use your weapon which adds to the immersion and the importance of valid cover.

Cons:
New people coming into the series will struggle so you must have patience. There is virtually no tutorial at all so much of the game is figured out the hard way.
There is a minor semblance of stealth in the game but it is primitive by today's standards. Basically you can sneak to make it easier to not be detected but if you shoot someone with a suppressed weapon, even if it is a 1 shot kill to the head, every else will be alerted and start running around trying to figure out where the shot came from. I can see it being a realistic thing if they were in the same room but people outside a building while it is raining? That's a bit much.
Trying to figure out where to go next is frustrating sometimes. The locations on the map don't always update. Probably bugged from getting my butt killed and having to load up a save but still.

Neutral:
The sound effects are pretty good for the time. Not sure if that is due to the mod or not, I haven't played the vanilla game in so long. Though many of the sound effects for minor things like walking/jumping etc are weaksauce.
Probably just a result of using that mod but none of the voicing was in English. You can read most conversations in text but sometimes there is no text and someone is simply speaking to you so I have no clue what is going on. I didn't see an option to change it in the settings and people online said workarounds to fix it caused other sound issues so I didn't mess with it.
The game world is very drab and samey with grainy textures that don't suit to my liking but I get why they did it. Just a personal preference so I won't fault them for that.

Overall:
This game came out during my college days so I didn't have the money to get it until many years later. I only briefly played it but it was buggy and crashed a lot. Years later, with the mod mentioned above, the game is much better and way more playable.
Yes.

Best game in the series, especially with modern community mods. Atmospheric, brutally unforgiving and always engaging. The slow start is the tutorial. By the time you reach Agroprom, the gloves will be well and truly off. A must play for any imsim or action-horror fans.

It took me more than the average player to complete the story (thus completing the game), about 80+ hours or so, since I didn't steamroll through the Story, so I have to talk about it.

If you enjoy any modern Fallout, Metro, Half Life as well as Survival Horror, Sci-Fi and Open World (who doesn't?) then you should totally play Shadow of Chernobyl. You need to have a knack and love for older video games to truly enjoy it but regardless it is a very enjoyable experience. The hardest difficulty possible is recommended for everyone. If you've been spoiled, play it anyway, there's nothing like it.

The gameplay is very junky and clunky and the gunplay is horrible unless you're in the late to end game sections where you can blast everyone's face off at point-blank range, but the world and atmosphere that keep on delivering are worth the struggle and effort it will take to power through the early and kind of annoying sections of the game. There's a huge variety of armor and weapons, and although the game is in First-Person only, you won't be able to see your character but the right setup will make you feel the effects of whatever you're using, and while the game doesn't offer anything substantial in the department of customizing your weapons, there are Unique variants and certain firearms that have attatchments available for use. Artifacts are one of the main attractions of loot and currency, and if you don't go exclusively for the story you will be able to simulate the simple scavenger and hunter experience of being a Stalker, it is a viable pastime and the game can go on for a lot longer than usual if you choose to interact with the factions and people of importance in the Zone. Exploration is also always rewarded and most of the time it is done so handsomely. most of the gear in the game can be acquired and experienced by simply looting dead enemies and revealing stashes around the Zone. These activities as well as radiant-type quests that have little next to zero lore are what the game offers aside from doing the story, but you can also do more important quests for bigger players of the Zone, breaking the monotony, allowing for small breaks between story missions that might have drained you of resources or seemed too difficult. That doesn't mean that the story doesn't supply you with gear much better than what you might currently have. This way you can focus exclusively on the story, although it is much more preferable to roam the Zone and see what you can scavenge, it will make the game and the world feel a lot bigger, although it is safe to say that for a game of it's age it has handled and performed very well within the world it is generating. There''s a variety of horrors and stories to be found within the Zone too and that keeps the intrigue growing and makes the setting a lot richer without saying much, I wouldn't consider it an exposition dump either since the messages you receive or the cutscenes you see are either sparse and/or brief.The game can be difficult but everything mentioned really redeems it. There's a heavy military feel to it and a great story and faction system that make the Zone feel a lot less alien, moments of returning to The Bar or being aided by Duty soldiers in the area lift you from the deafening loneliness of the Zone and remind you that the place is desolate and strange but somewhere nearby there might be a friend but also a sprawling enemy checkpoint. Mutants also stalk your shadow, and the right buyer will pay for the right monster-mash, so treading on Skinwa- I mean Bloodsucker territory can prove deadly but also rewarding, allowing you to access more jobs and quests for things you may already have. In short to that, there is no shortness of jobs and offers and loot to be had in the Zone alongside a futuristic and mysticist tale. With every step, every military base, every lab you come out alive of you will feel even more powerful having learned much from your endeavors, this game will keep rewarding you with the feeling of the conquer constantly, even if you choose to mostly play the story. Graphically it has it's own early 2000s aesthetic polygon look and I'd say that while not fancy it is kind of timeless to me.

Este jogo é algo bem complicado de se avaliar, então vou dividir isso em 2 partes: A parte artística e a parte mecânica.

Como obra de arte esse jogo é uma das coisas mais maravilhosas que já vi em termos de ambientação, da escolha na paleta de cores, vegetação e efeitos até música ambiente, é simplesmente sensacional.

Como software é a coisa mais quebrada e desbalanceada que eu já vi na vida, é muito inferior a Fallout 4 (sim, é sério!), o gunplay é de longe o pior que já vi, nunca vi nada tão ruim e nem mods vão salvar esse jogo (acredite em mim, eu tentei todos eles).

Se você é um fã da série esse jogo é obrigatório, se você não conhece S.T.A.L.K.E.R. e quer tentar algo novo nem beira isso aqui.

S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl, developed by GSC Game World, is a haunting and immersive first-person shooter that takes players on a harrowing journey through the haunting landscapes of the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone. With its atmospheric world, intense gameplay, and engrossing storyline, Shadow of Chernobyl stands as a masterpiece in the realm of atmospheric shooters.

One of the standout features of S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl is its atmospheric and meticulously crafted game world. The game captures the eerie and desolate beauty of the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone, creating a haunting and immersive environment that is as captivating as it is dangerous. From the decaying buildings and overgrown landscapes to the hauntingly realistic lighting and weather effects, every step in Shadow of Chernobyl feels atmospheric and laden with a sense of mystery and foreboding. The world feels lived-in and authentic, with various factions, anomalies, and mutated creatures inhabiting the Zone, adding depth and tension to the gameplay experience.

The gameplay in Shadow of Chernobyl is a challenging and intense blend of exploration, survival, and combat. As a Stalker, a lone adventurer seeking artifacts and answers within the Zone, players must navigate treacherous environments, scavenge for supplies, manage radiation exposure, and engage in deadly encounters with both human foes and mutated creatures. The game's unforgiving difficulty and realistic mechanics, such as weapon degradation and limited resources, add a layer of tension and strategic decision-making. Every encounter feels dangerous and meaningful, rewarding careful planning and precise execution.

The storyline in Shadow of Chernobyl is engrossing and filled with intrigue. Players unravel the mysteries of the Zone, uncovering the truth behind the disaster at Chernobyl and the secrets it holds. The game's non-linear structure and multiple endings provide replayability and encourage players to explore different paths and factions, adding depth and variety to the narrative experience. The game's rich lore and well-written characters further immerse players in the dark and mysterious world of Shadow of Chernobyl.

Visually, S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl delivers a gritty and realistic aesthetic. The game's attention to detail, from the environmental textures to the character models, adds to the immersive nature of the experience. The sound design is equally exceptional, with haunting ambient sounds, realistic weapon effects, and a fitting musical score that intensifies the atmospheric journey through the Zone.

Furthermore, the modding community surrounding Shadow of Chernobyl has further extended the game's longevity and replayability. The passionate community has created countless mods that enhance the game's visuals, add new content, and expand the gameplay possibilities, ensuring that there is always something new to discover and experience within the Zone.

In conclusion, S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl is an atmospheric and unforgettable first-person shooter that immerses players in a haunting and treacherous world. Its atmospheric game world, intense gameplay mechanics, and engrossing storyline make it a standout title in the genre. Whether you're a fan of atmospheric shooters, post-apocalyptic settings, or simply seeking a game that combines challenge and immersion, S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl delivers a haunting and captivating experience that will leave a lasting impression. Prepare to enter the Zone, embrace its dangers, and uncover its secrets in this atmospheric masterpiece.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

An absolute must-play for anyone into first-person shooters.

Despite its notorious amount of bugs (which are easily fixed with well-known mods and community patches for the game), the mechanics of this game and its rather considerable difficulty (at least when compared to other first-person shooters) make it very entertaining to play through. Don't come into this game expecting some masterfully crafted plot or anything of the sort. The story does just its job of giving you a reason to move forward, while also staying out of the way so you can take in everything the Zone has to offer.

Loosely based off of an old Russian movie called Stalker, which I did watch first and recommend as a good movie, the setting of this game called The Zone is more like Skinwalker Ranch on coffee than it does on the peaceful Chernobyl in Stalker. Have you ever wanted to experience being at the crossroads between the Backrooms, Metal Gear Solid 3, and Missing 411? Maybe the average person would run away, but this here is where I belong. 

The gameplay feels a bit like Ghost Recon during shootouts, except you constantly horde up items from the dead so you can create your little AK-74 blackmarket. It's such a pain because you can't hold that many items, but free guns are nice. Early in the game, you mostly come across AKs, Makarovs, and shotguns, but later on, the firearm selection grows. Grenades are real effective. My favorite gun was the G-36. 

If you like guns and the paranormal, with a slight pinch of survival horror, this action adventure shooter is a must play. I must sound so late to the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. experience, but I think I'm here at exactly the right time. It's too bad there is no gun cleaning kit in the game, so it's like Fire Emblem style weapon life spans. The recoil and gun spread feels so good though, even though the pistol is too accurate, but overall it feels far closer to reality than your average shooter game. They even included gun jams. The enemies are pretty good too and have pretty realistic swarm tactics while keeping a safe distance, for humans with guns that is. The tunnels underneath The Zone are just the stuff of nightmares. I already almost died down there when some ultraterrestrial psychic anomaly was doing a telepathic palm strike to turn my consciousness inside out, which was depicted a little too well. 

If you ever played Resident Evil, Ghost Recon, and/or Metal Gear Solid 3, you'll fit right in.

First game in the series, what can I say, there's a lot to go on.

After a while of playing the game, I did seem to enjoy it for the most part. I played the first half of the game with horrible resolution as the game does not automatically adapt to your monitor/computers resolution, but after messing with the settings a bit I was able to get it looking better. Game crashes a lot, and I mean a lot. It's pretty hard to play this game for an hour straight without the game just giving up on you with no error log at all, and me personally I wasn't able to find any solutions except messing around until the game finally didn't give in.

Couple of the problems I had in particular was crashing heavily in the Dark Valley for no reason at all, right next to lab X18. Another one was near end game, saving anywhere near the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant would result in an instant crash. Using any consumables from looting corpses would result in an immediate crash too, but that got easy to figure out and avoid. The story is rather short if you just dash through it, although you will have difficulty barriers if you rush the story but you can find your way around it if you're good enough with combat and tactics. You have options to take enemies silently or in head on combat, both of which have pretty nice mechanics but the A.I. can be a bit buggy. There are multiple factions in the game you can befriend, which befriending them will let you have your weapon out around them without having them get aggressive but it doesn't really seem to have any use other than that. You can't join factions, and you don't really get any benefits. The entire scientific area of the game kinda seemed useless to me, you do a couple missions there and then it's too inconvenient to travel all the way back to actually want to continue doing anything there. The map is large, but there are no fast travel mechanics. This sometimes feels like a problem when there are only three vendors on the map, which feels more like two since once again, one is in the scientific area. Military just meta-games the entire time and shows up everywhere the second you're escaping so they can come and kill you, and I won't elaborate any more on factions since I know I'll make a couple fans angry. (Lots of disputes between the community about which faction is the best.)

If you're looking for extra content such as helping the factions miscellaneously or just doing whatever yourself for roleplay purposes, you can, yet don't expect to get anywhere. The few missions you can get that aren't the main story are basically just go kill this pack of mutants here, or go find this random artifact here, or go kill this random dude in the middle of nowhere because he looked at me funny. The rewards for them are small and often make them not worth it but you can pass some time by knocking them out. I wish they expanded on the arena more since you can go 10 rounds through it before no longer being able to progress. I have never bought anything from a shop vendor throughout my entire time playing except the occasional food or ammo to survive, and in the end game it's pretty hard to find ammo for the guns who actually matter. Chances are if you find a unique weapon, you'll have to turn them in to someone for a quest, but luckily the game gives you the option of just ignoring them entirely which is something I like. Even when doing the main quests. Don't want to do something? Just say something along the lines of "Uhh, no, I don't feel like doing it right now." and you can pick it up again at any time you wish.

Beyond this there will be SLIGHT spoilers, so quick warning. Other than that I feel like the ending was pretty stupid, like you just took out all these dudes and mutants and almost died after seeing these horrific monsters in these horror labs and such, and you're getting quickly radiated in the power plant and are due to die in a bit, and you can wish for anything you want, and you chose to "get rich"? It seems pretty stupid to me, so the ending was a bit disappointing.

Anyways, in conclusion, for 24 dollars I did find myself enjoying the game for the while that I had it, but I probably won't be going through it again. I never did play it with mods and I heard there are a lot of them that fix most of the bugs, add more gameplay, and make the graphics better, as well as anything else you want, but since the game was made in 2007 it doesn't really make sense to judge it on the graphical parameters. Though, the game doesn't really seem like it was ever updated to fix some of the problems it has since it's still in super early versions, but that's all I have to say.

My first introduction  to the S.T.A.L.K.E.R games was Call Of Prypyat when i was a teenager. 
I remember spending long nights discovering the zone and its creepy anomalies, it felt as the most immersive post apocalyptic game I've ever experienced and the ambiance scared me to death and made it the most memorable pc game i never finished. 

Now i'm thirty I've decided to play the series fully and in order, and oh boy Shadow of Tchernobyl delivered more than expected. 

It's an immersive FPS Shooter/SIM where everything feels gritty and unfriendly. 
"The Zone" is unforgiving and always throwing something at you. 
The game never takes you by the hand and punish the unprepared, several times during the journey. 

Level design is still really good to this day, from huge landscape to hangar to old factories, nuclear plants and old sewers full of dangerous beings that want you dead. 

There's many factions that inhabit the world, stalkers, military, bandits and more as you dwell into the main missions.  
The scariest encounters would be the lethal anomalies and deformed monsters roaming free and trying to end you at every turn. 

Story is mysterious, engaging graphics are a bit dated but still feels quite good and immersive to this day. 
The fan base community of this game is dedicated and so are the mods that could enhance your experience with the game. 
I recommend everyone to try this franchise with all my heart because it deserves it. 

Good luck fellow stalker!

Stalker: Shadow of Chernobyl is a really interesting and unique game despite all it's flaws. The blend of survival horror, strategic shooter, and a little bit of an rpg element really shine in this game. The shootouts are tense and erratic for most of the game and the zone's atmosphere is dreadful but the best parts of this game are when you're underground. The horror belongs in these creepy, damp, and barren areas, and I think just about every "monster" moment was terrifying. They aren't used often but the first time an invisible creature just barely passes by you and you have to question if you had actually seen anything will forever be implanted in my brain. These moments are what make this game so good and despite the enemy AI being put together with sticks and stones and the game is slapped together with duct tape, the systems in this game keep it interesting and fresh. Which brings me to my biggest complaint about SOC; the story. Although the zone as a whole will fill the player with a sense of curiousness, the story will only add more questions then it actually answers, even with the "true" path. There's so much set up but you gain so little information about the factions and the world and even yourself. I was so confused if the twist was actually a twist that I had to look it up just to double check I was right. Luckily the story is simple enough and you're so preoccupied with what's happening you probably will forget half the mission objectives. The worst contender though is the ending, (spoiler stuff) it's really cool that there's so many different endings and they are fun to get but also they are based on really specific things so most players will end up with the "rich" ending which felt a bit out of place considering I had a fairly normal amount of money. The two true endings are a bit more satisfying but are still a bit anti-climatic and once again slightly incoherent. One of them sees you having to battle through the WORST area in the game. It's just an enemy dump till the game decides you're done and then it just ends?? It's not even particularly difficult it's just not fun to go through especially wearing the armor that stunts your run. Despite that I think that the ending cutscene is interesting it's just the pain to get there it really isn't worth it. I know I've complained a lot about this game but I really do love it and I think it's worth experiencing, even the bad stuff. There's a lot of charm and ambition here even if some of it is untapped. I'm excited to play the other games and see how this team expands on their story-telling and gameplay. 8/10 :3

Still a mostly good FPS survival horror game made by Ukrainians but does have dated gameplay, graphics, and mechanics. This is a game that needs to be played on the hardest difficulty or you'll be going up against bullet sponges and it'll make the game more enjoyable. A brutally difficult and punishing game but that's the point because this is a post nuclear war apocalypse world with bandits and mutated creatures trying to kill you. Still I would recommend Fallout New Vegas as that game is far better and superior. I would recommend this and Call of Pripyat over Clear Sky easily as these are the best games in the franchise. I would not recommend these games for everyone though because they can be frustrating with a lot of cheap deaths but still has the best atmosphere in the series. :( RIP to one of the devs that was killed in Ukraine by Russian invaders not too long ago.

This game is perfect, I did my first playthrough with mods but even vanilla, it's graphics just has something about it that makes it still look good, I don't know if it's my bias towards old graphics or something else, but it just looks good. 

The story in this one is alright, pretty simple but it's not S.T.A.L.K.E.R's strong point, that title goes to the enviroment and gameplay, the areas are well made and there are some details that make it better like hidden boxes that contain loot, some spots with weapons hidden in a huge anomaly field, or the fact that it is faithful to the actual exclusion zone in a few places. The combat aspect though, is my favorite part in the game, the A.I. is actually smart, they actually flank you, they push you when you open your inventory or start looting someone's corpse to take advantage of your vulnerability, they can be easily killed by hitting a headshot and the same applies to you.

Now, something else the franchise is known for is bugs and jank, it's an old game and it's engine can be quite glitch and crashy, I didn't find many bugs as much as others have experienced but they were definitely there, but there is a mod that fixes most of them and CTDs, so if you want to experience less bugs and crashes use the Zone Reclamation Project.

Lastly, the modding capabilities in all of the 3 games is really big, there are hundreds or maybe even more than a thousand mods for these games, be it russian or english, many to fit your tastes on how STALKER should be and quite fun to play after finishing the games. Just one very very big tip: never ever play anomaly, it's a waste of time and a pathetic attempt at a stalker mod, it is nothing like the actual stalker games and instead some tarkovified pile of trash.

Still a good game with rich gameplay. Hard game and Hard to master. One of the most immersive Story-driven FPS i have played. My advice for new players who don't want to lag to much by virtue of the realistic mechanics of the game:
-Play in rookie mode. It's still pretty hard for a first run, and when you grab the philosophy of the game it's very enjoyable and still challenging at times. Not a walk in the park. Foes leave plenty of weapons and ammo and usefull items. You won't have to search each corners and houses and corpses to find common items since you're very likely to find a lot of them. Rare items as well are imo easier to gather and are not indispensable to complete the game anyway.  That's something less to manage and feel anxious about. You won't get headshot and die too fast, especially in the last bit which is very hard in normal difficulty. You won't be too much annoyed with armor and weapon limited lifespan since they wear out slower. Armors are particularly hard to find in the map and you don't want to end up naked in a firefight.
-Don't do sidequest. They are boring, useless, time consuming and often buggy. The map is not that big but there is no fast travel and foes you killed automatically respawn. You'll get bored fast.

A master class example of gameplay and atmosphere with a unique setting and premise.

Shadow of Chernobyl's gameplay is ahead of its time and while some aspects seem a bit dated such as its gunplay, its presentation and visuals still showcase some amazing set pieces many years after its release. While not specifically "survival horror", it sure creeps into the player's skin and psyche. Everything wants you dead and the game makes it that although you're the player character, you're just another Stalker in his journey of the Zone.

Whether you want to play unmodded or modded, you're in for an unforgettable "innawoods" experience that will keep you hooked.

End note: while not vanilla/purtist friendly, I personally recommend looking into the OGSR:GA mod for updated visuals and enhanced gunplay. Radiophobia 3 is also an excellent mod but be prepared for an unforgiving experience.

Normally, I love games that take place in a post apocalyptic setting like this and while I still do love this game's world, I can't recommend it for multiple reasons. For one, this game's combat is CRUSHING. Like seriously it is balls hard and this kind of turns me off from opening up the game. Don't get me wrong, there's nothing bad about a game with intense, realistic shooting, but S.T.A.L.K.E.R. can just feel unfair at times. Also this game is super janky. The characters don't actually have any spoken dialogue excepts when you walk next to them and they a little phrase like "What are you looking at?" or "Go away". Also graphically the game looks fucking awful for the time. I mean this was the year of Bioshock and Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfare so this is just inexcusable. Overall, I give this game a 5.5/10.

I always felt like the much older games had a lot more personality to them, of course there are new games that come close to being very enjoyable and not money grabbers but not many that still have the same feeling as ones like this.

It has a lot of issues with bugs, translation errors, and difficulty spikes. However, it makes up for all that with a beautiful world with tons of sights to see, artifacts to collect, and loot to secure. People say you need to mod this game for a better experience, I disagree. I didn't feel the need to install any besides an FOV mod because the low FOV made me feel ill. One thing I do agree with is playing the game on Master difficulty. The AI is pretty dumb, so they're a cakewalk on the lower difficulties. Even on Master difficulty the game is pretty easy if you check every nook and cranny for loot as the game rewards exploration. 

With all that said, this game is not for everyone. If you're not a fan of slower, tactical shooters, you will not like this game. I'd still recommend giving it a try regardless because the game is pretty cheap when it goes on sale. I bought the whole series for only $5.

First played this game on the easiest difficulty when I was at high school in 2008 or so. It was crazy hard but the atmosphere made me emotionally attached to the game through all these years. I wasn't able to make it half-way even back then.

S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl was released in 2007. It is a gritty story-driven first person shooter made by a small team in Ukraine with less to no resources. The team behind it (GSC Game World) later had to disband due to financial issues in 2011. Though in 2014 they got together again and we're expecting for "S.T.A.L.K.E.R. 2" to hit the shelves in 2023.

It's roughly based on 1971 Soviet novel "Roadside Picnic" written by Boris & Arkady Strugatsky. And I have to say it's closer to the original material than Andrei Tarkovsky's 1979 movie "Stalker". Though Tarkovsky's movie is awesome too. The book is awesome as well, just finished reading it today. As for the game, the atmosphere is great, music is alright and the story is OK I guess.

Coming back to it today, S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is still pretty much playable and enjoyable as it was back in the day. Keep in mind that this is the game of an underpaid, mostly self-taught, tiny Ukrainian Game Development Studio and it does not compare to most AAA games as you would expect. It doesn't have face animations, doesn't have voice acting for the most part, some of the voice files doesn't even have English versions. But what's in it is good, and the combat is gritty, and the combat AI is unforgiving, and the economy is pretty well balanced. So most of what's in the game, works good, better than most of the AAA junk they put out every year.

I love the nitty gritty grimdark horror aesthetic aswell. Do yourself a favour, get this game. Also if you are looking to play it with decent graphics I recommend the aurora mod. Atmospheric, soulful and immersive FPS. Hardcore gameplay, interesting survival mechanics and soft RPG elements.

This game is definitely not akin to a standard open world title, and playing like you would approach a Far Cry game will get you killed. The world is organic and each NPC has their own routine and life while you are just another individual in this world.

You should approach firefights as you would in real life. You should also always be careful, since waves of migrating mutants, thieves and stray bullets from faction wars might end your life in mere seconds. Each second, even in friendly enviornments, can be your last.

Strangely enough, they also use all of this organicity and danger to bring forth one of the most humane games of all time. One of the most enticing moments you can have in gaming is chilling in Shadow of Chernobyl, sitting down by the campfire together with your fellow stalkers while one of them plays a guitar. The quiet, peaceful atmosphere is a fundamental part of the loop and it helps making this trip through this absolutely dangerous hellscape somewhat beautiful. Just wish the story had the same sense of humanity, but the lore is cool and I liked it regardless of some bonkers ideas here and there.

If you don't mind the fact that this is a game where you'll rely on quick saves, and also the fact that the path to the true ending kinda falls apart in the end, you will experience one of the most unique and interesting open world games out there.

Wish more open world games took the STALKER approach instead of the Ubisoft one...
I hate S.T.A.L.K.E.R and it hates me

I don't think this game is terrible, but it's not what I'd call a good game either.

When it comes to the story, I tried reading through the journal my character kept and read through some of the main quest text. I think if someone takes the time to read through the story, even if he isn't reading every tid bit, there should be enough to give him a good understanding of what's happening, but I feel like I only understood maybe 50%, the ending just felt like it came out of nowhere and answered nothing except one question. Not ideal in my opinion. The questing and storytelling is quite awful, even when it comes to tracking quests.

The gunplay is quite unpleasant. Early on the guns you are given miss the target unless you are very close, and it seems unless you hit the head you might as well be shooting at the sky. The enemy AI also just feels like they were programmed to slowly move towards you. There's also a lot more action than I would have liked. This game felt like 80% shooting enemies with it's horribly unpleasant gunplay.

The money system & inventory management weren't well thought out. It feels like unless you make it an active effort to avoid items your inventory will always be full, and so it became my second job to make sure I don't pick up too much. There's also enough money and items to never need to use the ingame store system. It could have been removed and it would not have worked to the detriment of the game. Right now it's there to make new players think the store serves purpose, when it doesn't.

The atmosphere & world didn't blow me away. The npc's felt irrelevant and boring, and the game has infinite enemy respawns all around. Sometimes scripted events kill the npc's you're supposed to talk to before you can even get there, even if you're running nonstop, and it's weird to walk past the same location just to see the same event you cleared unfolding again. It's also a lot more linear than I thought, it's so linear people shouldn't be calling it open world. The open area is very small and follows roads with some small areas to the sides, and late game I felt like I was holding W in a straight line for 3-5 hours.

I could talk about how I don't like various aspects of the game, but I'll leave it here. This game is probably my greatest disappointment in a while, as I don't think it does anything well. That said, I know a lot of people enjoy it so maybe give it a try if you see it on sale.

Also the game is a bit longer than my playtime, I apparently accidentally skipped a part of it.

This is one of the best open-world FPS/RPG games of all time.  I played it when it came out in 2007, and recently played it again with the Autumn Aurora mod (mainly for graphical improvements).  Somehow, I appreciate it today even more than I did when it was released.  How many games can anyone say that about, 16 years after release?  I honestly can't think of another game I enjoy more today than I did when it was fresh and new.

It does need to be said that this game doesn't have some of the quality of life features we expect from games today...but somehow, that doesn't really bother me with this game.  This game doesn't hold your hand; other than a few map markers and some dialogue, it's up to you to figure stuff out--but that learning process is also part of the appeal.  The map is big, and there is no fast travel--but it's so immersive and there's so much random stuff that happens along the way that I'm not really bothered by the extra travel time.  Autosave is sparse, at best, so you need to "save early and often" to keep your progress when you die--but the game's combat and environmental hazards are fair enough that if you're careful, and save now and then, it isn't a problem.  

The game's combat can be unforgiving, especially in the beginning, but it's unforgiving in a pretty fair way--meaning that if you avoid tough enemies until you're ready, keep track of your ammo, and use sensible strategy, you'll come out ahead more than you don't.  The player's character feels about as tough as the enemies who have comparable gear, so if you see someone who has better weapons and armor than you, that should inform you of your odds against that opponent unless you somehow secure an advantage. 
 Speaking of advantages, there are several factions that you can play off against each other, if you're clever about it.

The exploration and sense of wonder and discovery in this game are awesome.  Finding strange anomalies, rare artifacts, and hidden caches are all extremely rewarding.  If you help a wounded character, they might tell you to look in a certain tree stump in the woods for a hidden cache of supplies.  If you figure out a way around some dangerous anomalies, you might find a powerful artifact that somehow "makes sense" in the context of where you found it.  If you put in the extra effort to do side quests, you'll learn important things about the world you wouldn't otherwise be able to discover.  It really feels like every character, and every inch of ground is part of the world, and offering a mystery to solve.

Finally, one of the most interesting things about this series is the setting--a fictionalized version of the exclusion zone around the Chernobyl nuclear power plant that melted down in 1986.  This game (like the books it came from) asks the question, "What would the world be like if nuclear radiation had slightly magical properties?"  The world the creators built around that premise is truly remarkable.

If you're a fan of story-rich FPS or RPG games, chances are, you'll love this, despite its age.  Buy it, install a mod or two, and immerse yourself in an intriguing world.

First of all, I have to say that this game is NOT for everyone, it's a very strange mix of FPS, RPG and some light horror. The game is also notoriously unstable and buggy and the performance is very inconsistent, especially on modern hardware. I've played through the game 10 times and it didn't crash once, but I've seen people (with very similar hardware) experiencing all kinds of technical issues from low framerates to CTDs every 2 minutes.

It sounds weird, but the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. franchise almost "chooses" you and your PC, not the other way around.

The gameplay is also pretty different from most FPS games. The game almost teaches you to avoid unnecessary combat encounters. In most games, you want to gun down everything in sight to get the most loot and most XP, but in S.T.A.L.K.E.R. you simply cannot do that, because your supplies are very limited and you usually don't know if the loot gained from the enemies will outweigh the ammo and medical supplies you use up in the process of unaliving them. Enemies are also really spongy, especially better equiped ones, like army soldiers or stalkers in Exoskeletons. so good aim and headshots are pretty much a requirement, if you don't want to spend a whole AK mag on every single one.

Most of the starter guns are also not very accurate, which is done to make the player feel weaker in combat and teach him that above mentioned survival aspect, I guess? Contrary to popular belief, crouching or switching fire-modes doesn't do a damn thing, you'll just have to push through until you get some better gear. If you want a post-apocalyptic game, where all the guns are as accurate as laser beams, go play the Metro franchise, you won't find much of that here.

Graphics are actually somewhat good for a 16 year-old game, but animations for guns and NPCs look really dated. All of the guns are left handed, despite being held by a right handed player, it doesn't have any real meaning or impact on anything, it's just a trend from the late 2000s, because animators wanted to show off a bit.

The OST is really good and positively contributes to the overall feel and atmosphere of the game. Speaking of the atmosphere, it's honestly hard as nails. It really makes you feel like you're stranded in this unforgiving and irradiated hellhole, and some of the underground sections are honestly more frightening than half of the modern "horror" games. The creepy looking mutants heavily contribute to this horror aspect, this game is not nicknamed "Heart attack simulator" for no reason.

As for modding the game...

DO NOT MOD IT UNLESS YOU'VE PLAYED IT VANILLA AT LEAST ONCE. Seriously, mods interfere with the core gameplay and they either make the game super easy or super difficult. The only mod I'd recommend for a first-time player is the Zone Reclamation Project (ZRP), because it doesn't change any of the core features, and it's really just a community made bug fix/patch.

Overall, I'd say it's an 8/10, but this score is probably very biased, because it's one of my childhood favorites. You'll either love it, or hate it, there is no in between.

The Zone is a hellish wasteland only fit for the suicidal or foolish, and it's wonderful.  STALKER is a great experience when it comes to atmospheric story-telling and creating a living world around you that feels just as dangerous and frightening as it is beautiful and breath-taking.  

The last 3 hours or so of the main campaign though, not very fun.  Without getting into spoilers someone at GSC thought a string of missions where you take on well-equipped futuristic military personnel who can one-tap you hiding behind every piece of cover was a fun idea.  It comes as a surprise because up until the ending, as long as you're looting a lot and doing side quests, the game is actually kind of easy.  I wouldn't call the last few missions hard, as much as they are really frustrating and made me race to the end of the game.  I know the STALKER games only get better from here, but wow, that was a though one.
