I decided to play this series of games when it went on sale, not knowing what the hell I was in for. As I started completing missions, the game feels very much like Fallout. However, the shooting reminded me of the old Tom Clancy games: pretty slow, heavy amounts of cover shooting (thanks to the lean mechanic), and very reliant on burst or single fire. Combining the two makes it pretty enjoyable. However, since this game doesn't do much in the way of explaining the plot and its mechanics, I pretty much ran around and explored these tiny towns and doing whatever quests I had access too.

Unfortunately, the quests have their issues too. When it comes to fetch quests, you have a limited time to find X and bring it back to your questgiver. The items do not drop often or can be tricky to find, so expect to fail the quest at least once, or get lucky and find what item you need prior to accepting the quest. There was one mission where you can bring back this weapon a soldier of the Duty faction left around, but if you were like me and completed a certain part of the story before accepting the mission, the waypoint leading to this mysterious weapon breaks. This is because the person currently using the weapon is now wandering around this massive map, which was frustrating at first, but then I accepted that I'm probably not going to find it.

Speaking of the map, I ADORE it. Every place has NPCs that are neutral towards you, enemies rocking white stripes on black sweats yelling "CHEEKY BREEKY IV DAMKE", and mutated wildlife that really fits with the post-apocalyptic atmosphere of Ukraine. The environmental storytelling is plentiful, the faction bases feel lived in, and the weapons are punchy.

I ended up getting the "greedy" ending, which according to the wiki is very common to get for first time players. I honestly didn't even know that this was the final mission and was playing through it like a gauntlet, where you have enemies wielding very powerful weapons like the gauss rifle (they WILL one shot you), rocket launchers (YOU WILL DIE A LOT, QUICKSAVE), and silenced rifles (THEY WILL NOT APPEAR ON YOUR MINIMAP, STAY VIGILANT). After quicksaving and quickloading a lot, it was a great time. This game will punish you for not being patient, and then will further punish you if you are too patient. For a game with combat that is pretty slow paced, it sure knows how to put you into a frenzy.

All in all, I'm kind of unsatisfied with the ending I've gotten, but now I have acquired the knowledge I need to get better endings. I will be doing another playthrough in the near future, but in the 26 hours it has taken me to beat this game, there were no dull moments (except wandering back to turn in quests because no fast travel, but its a feature!). If you are looking for something set in a post-apocalyptic hellscape with factions to deal with and have already played more well known games like Fallout, I highly recommend you give this game a shot, definitely worth your cash.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

An absolute classic. One of my favorite game series of all time. This entry is my personal favorite in the series though Stalker: Call of Pripyat is probably the most polished without mods. Story and atmosphere wise, this game takes #1 in the series. I would often just sit beside the campfire with the random NPCs you come across and listen to them playing guitar. The mutant designs, especially the Snorks and blood suckers, are iconic and very memorable. The gameplay is a bit jarring at first if you aren't used to these games as the guns aren't fully accurate. It's something you get used to with time and I would recommend you play this game on master difficulty. It's the hardest difficulty so enemies can kill you extremely fast but, they die just as fast. On master difficulty, one well placed headshot will take almost every enemy out. If you plan on playing this game, I suggest the zone reclamation patch if you want a vanilla experience but with some bug fixes and QOL adjustments.

EDIT: This is also playable on Steam Deck/Linux with Proton! 

After 11 years of owning this game and it sitting in my library,  I finally decided to sit down and play all the games before S.T.A.L.K.E.R 2 releases (and before I actually try to play the Anomaly mod pack, as intended by the devs). And after all this time & attempts at getting into it... I finally get it. This is absolutely one of the best Survival FPS games ever created.
 
It does what the 3D fallout games do but better (gameplay, story, environments, music, characters/factions). I'd say the main difference is that the world feels so lively compared to Fallout. It feels like the world continues without you when you're done playing but thats where those comparisons end. Mostly because I wouldn't call it "Post-Apocalyptic" as the world as we know it outside of the Zone exists still (spoiler alert, Chernobyl exists IRL! Wow!). There are no real perk/RPG elements to the game besides stats for your character, either. If you want to get technical - the artifacts you collect can be considered perks in a sense, but they really only enhance stats but have a lot of tradeoffs. 

The atmosphere of this game is literally unmatched, the closest I have felt to this recently is Tarkov. Which unsurprisingly, after playing this game it made me realize that Tarkov takes a lot of mechanics from this game. That isn't meant to be a negative either, in fact playing Tarkov beforehand made this game much easier for me. 

I am going to assume if you're reading the reviews/interested you already know how this game plays. And instead of talking indepth about it and and sounding like a wiki - I'd like to share some tips:

The vanilla experience like many fans say is fine and should not need gameplay mods on your first playthrough, honestly, 
I don't think graphical mods are really needed either. However I would STRONGLY suggest you install ZRP. It includes some QoL features and bug fixes, I only really suggest this because the game can and after a certain point WILL crash on you, the ZRP mod fixes those issues for the most part. 

Find things feel weird and awkward (ex 'X' being the run key, whatever the hell the weapon fire mode button is, crouching) Rebind. Your. Keys. ESPECIALLY SAVE/LOAD! I would suggest binding load further away from the save key. 

Speaking of saving, I highly suggest saving before any possible encounter or level switch. Later in the game, saving before level switches will save you time if you get the occasional loading crash. If using ZRP you can press ESC and press S it will create a lvl named save. 
--
(The rest are up to personal preference but this is how I enjoyed the game)
Use whatever difficulty you want. I've read many arguments about this before playing the game and came to the conclusion it doesn't matter that much and chose master anyway because I enjoy dying over and over in video games.

Turn off the crosshair. At range you will ADS/Use a scope and CQC you will probably be point firing anyway. It gets in the way and kinda takes away from the immersion, the hud is fine.

Rebinds I did were: Sprint as Shift, Crouch as C, Low Crouch as Ctrl, and fire mode as B. Save game as F5 and Load on Num *

Equipment load matters. Carry like 300 bullets for your guns and 15x bandages and antidotes, 3-4x medkits of each and maybe 5x of 2 sets of grenades. Carry guns of different bullet types as well, you'll find that newer weapons will have a low amount of ammo starting out so keep a backup. 

I didn't do this but figured it'd be helpful: If you would like to not be shot at later in the game when backtracking to a certain area - stay neutral (loner) and try not to fight the factions. Bad shit happens in one or two areas if you turn on a certain side. 
---
I cant list everything here, and I've only completed 2 of the multiple endings. But the community has way more tips/fixes/workarounds if you encounter any other issues/questions on the forums/subreddit/internet/google.com.

I was in awe when this game was released back in 2007. Great open world for its time and amazing mutans that kept me awake a lot of nights because of how scary they were. Glad this game serie was part of my childhood. Just wish it didn't keep crashing from time to time.

The very first time you set foot in the underground bunkers has you enter a claustrophobic, badly wrecked secret lab. The outside which has bandits and army trying to kill you in a radioactive mutant hellscape, is bad enough, but the depths below are so much wierder and scarier.

There's invisible poltergheists throwing boxes at you from rooms away, invisible bloodsuckers who stalk you in the dark, but when you battle through all that, and are nearing a distant exit, suddenly you can't control your camera anymore; and seem to be sprinting in a direction you didn't want to go. A few seconds of that and you suddely see the controller, a hugely dangerous psychic mutant for the first time, right up close. Suddenly you're released and you return swiftly to your body as before, except with the cursed knowledge of what lies ahead.

You were a good stalker Vladimir Yezhov, one of the best in fact.

Rest In Peace.

S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl is a unique and atmospheric first-person shooter that is set in a post-apocalyptic world. While the game is not perfect, it is still a great experience that is definitely worth playing.

One of the standout features of the game is its setting. The game is set in an alternate reality where a second nuclear disaster has occurred at Chernobyl, resulting in a deadly and mysterious Zone that is full of danger and intrigue. The game's world is immersive and well-crafted, with a sense of mystery and danger that permeates every aspect of the game.

The gameplay in S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl is both challenging and rewarding. The game features a complex RPG system that allows players to customize their character and weapons in a variety of ways. The game also features a dynamic weather system that affects gameplay, as well as a day and night cycle that impacts enemy behavior and other aspects of the game.

While the game's setting and gameplay are great, there are some issues that hold the game back. The game's graphics, while impressive for its time, have not aged well and can be a bit jarring for modern gamers. Additionally, the game's AI can be frustrating at times, with enemies sometimes behaving in unrealistic ways.

Despite its flaws, S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl is still a fantastic game that offers a unique and engaging experience. The game's setting, gameplay, and atmosphere are all top-notch, and the game is well worth playing for fans of the post-apocalyptic and first-person shooter genres. So if you're looking for a challenging and immersive game, be sure to check out S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl.

The game is fun but I recommend you do some research before you boot it up as it's a buggy mess without mods. I wanted to do a modless first playthrough, but that came to a grinding halt when an NPC got stuck behind a door. After trying for several days to resolve the problem by multiple means. Killing every breathing thing in the sector, shooting the door, grenades, reloading and then returning, nothing worked. Then I attempted to use a mod to fix the problem. It still didn't work. Then my game crashed. Even with the mods uninstalled and after uninstalling and reinstalling the game, it crashes every time I try to load a save. It's going to be a while before I pick it back up and try again. The game has charm, and I do enjoy it, but you need to find a mod guide even to run it for your first playthrough to stop things like this from happening. If you have any mods for a first run-through feel free to suggest them. Especially if they improve the games stability, frequency of stuttering, or the at-times frustrating gunplay.

A great game that's rough around the edges. The setting, enemies, environment, and sense of "what the fuck" is what defines Stalker. While I find the gameplay to be "fine" in general, it doesn't stack up well compared to any other fps, with firing feeling just slightly "off", a difficulty system which is so badly communicated to the player that rumors about it working incorrectly still spread to this day, and unrepairable weapons and armor. 

Despite these flaws I would still recommend the entire series, and especially this great first entry, so long as you're willing to put up with its shortcomings, which can easily be offputting for many people. The lore, setting, factions, conflicts, and sense of difficulty was enough (for me at least) to put up with its issues and still walk away very satisfied with it.

While it might feel a little janky at times, I would recommend this game for the incredible atmosphere alone. The godforsaken environment of an irradiated Ukraine was able to completely immerse me at times. Spectacles range from electrifying, sprawled battles, such as ragtag paramilitary troops launching a full-out assault against religious fanatics that infest the remains of Pripyat, to fleeting moments of tranquility that can be found amongst the wasteland, like the wind gently sweeping over a great stretch of cracked road. Give Shadow of Chernobyl a go if you feel you have the patience to excuse some bugs and general wear and tear due to it's age. Plus, I hear that the modding community is surprisingly expansive and active to this day, so there's always that option if you wanted to fix any issues or even just enhance the visuals. Oh, and remember to play on Master difficulty. Apparently they structured each difficulty level in a way that leads to the highest one actually being the smoothest experience, oddly enough.

The gunplay is dognuts and the general gameplay is just loveable jank. Highly recommend you get any sort of mod that makes it vanilla+ just so that the rooty tooty shooty bits are slightly more fun than frustrating ( playing this on Master which is the recommended diffculty already makes it so that everyone drops like flies, except the players accuracy is shit. so the mods usually mitigate that)

What ties this finest of Jank together is the really fun and generally intruiging story and world mixed with seemingly helpless gameplay where you're almost always one wrong step from getting turned into just shoes, either by anomalies or enemy fire. 

The atmosphere of the game cannot be praised enough, they've nailed the dying and rotten look of the Chernobyl exclusion zone mixed in with abandoned soviet labs, experiments gone wrong and frankly the bizzare but somehow-it-works body horror aspect of some enemies and places. The game looks fairly beliveable and completely fiction at the same time.

Put on your finest rad-proof suit and get to discovering The Zone's secrets, There is a fuckton more than just the main storyline to uncover ;)

There is hidden beauty and excellence in Stalker Shadow of Chernobyl. The atmosphere is arguably its biggest strength, the way some NPCs gather around a fireplace and sing is a really nice touch in contrast to the depressing vibe of the game, the way the world interacts in its system beyond player's input is genius.

However it's so unsatisfying to play. I keep coming back to this year after year now, only wishing it would click with me this one time but it never did. The side missions are almost always repetitive with killing this monster/NPC, etc without any emotional payoff with the quest giver. The map is brimming with atmosphere but most of them are empty. The inventory management is utterly not user-friendly and confusing for first time player. The worst of all is the shooting mechanic.

The game wanted to immerse you in this somewhat realistic take on what happens on the zone; everything is dangerous but the way the game makes this experience is to cheat the shooting mechanic itself. The gun is inconsistent. I shot an enemy's head 3 times with a shotgun who stand only 2 meters from me and they still live even though he didn't wear any helmet. This is made worse that every couple shots in, the enemy staggers and I suspect that they can't take any damage at all except for headshot damage in that entire stagger animation. I wasted a whole clip of handgun without doing any damage. Not only that, the gun accuracy is abysmal. The iron sight only ever increases the accuracy ever so slightly. You can aim enemy's head 3 meters away from you, lock it in and it still will miss 70% of time. It's turned into a guessing game of RNG and what OP weapons you can equip. The fact that they tied the accuracy to game difficulty is really baffling and the game never said anything about the accuracy either, you have to go meta and google search to get that info.

The enemy respawning is also a questionable design choice. It would be better if enemy respawns when half a day or a full day has passed but I encounter enemy respawn in only 5 minutes. I was shooting 3 military men and after the last one died, suddenly 7 spawned in behind me running towards me. 

Stalker Shadow of Chernobyl is too ambitious for its own good and fall so off due to its poor executions of its mechanics. It feels really bad to play and the bugs don't help it either. The bugs are at the point that I don't really know if this is intentional or not, if I should be laughing at it or annoyed by it. 

Even after all this, I am curious on Stalker 2, I really hope they nail the shooting mechanic, the mission designs and characters. If you value atmosphere over anything else, this game is one of the best in that field but everything else is a miss.

I`m not very patient and sometimes I would skip some chat texts. Maybe that was the reason why I didn`t knew that I was going for my last mission on the game, so maybe a friendly tip without spoiling is getting the patience to read your PDA intel and what NPCs have to say.
When I ended the game I searched on the Internet, looks like there are at least 6 ending variations, which is a good thing if you want to replay the game.
For me this is a 10, full price is a bit expensive since it is a very old game, but was quite worth it.

I wasn’t too sure about this game at first, but after I started to get geared and really understood the mechanics, it rapidly grew on me. It does look and feel quite dated, even with mods, but the gameplay is strong enough to overshadow that fact. The plotline is deceptively linear, with side quests and factions introduced to create a somewhat open-world experience. There’s a much weaker emphasis on survival than I initially thought there would be and a prominent sci-fi element. I was expecting more of a suspenseful survival sandbox type game, kinda like Tarkov or DayZ but singleplayer. Y’know, something with a little less story. I know it’s treasonous to say, but I really did get strong Fallout vibes as I got later into the game.

Mods I’d recommend for your first playthrough:

- [url=https://www.moddb.com/mods/starter-pack]Starter Pack[/url] (Compilation of bug fixes, visual overhauls, and QoL improvements)
- [url=https://drive.google.com/file/d/1gVPHrj-dgkQMz8i5jRR5HWNwaZxTJAJx/view?usp=sharing]Weapon Addon Fix[/url] (Use this version as the default one hasn’t been updated to work with the ZRP bug fix)

- [url=https://sfx.thelazy.net/games/preset/11393/]Better SoC[/url] (Reshade preset. Turn off chromatic aberration and MXAO for the best experience)

A fantastic start to a timeless game series. The game surprisingly runs pretty smoothly on modern hardware and is worth picking up on sale, but you'd be better off buying "Call of Pripyat" (CoP) instead since a lot of it's features are newer and is the most commonly modded/modifiable game in the series. This game is worth getting if you're a fan of the series and want to try it for yourself.

I just finished playing Resident Evil 3 and was looking for something similar to play while I wait for the RE4 PC version to come out in March. Steam recommended Stalker and the reviews are pretty good with a Mostly Positive rating so I figured I'd give it a shot...especially now that you can return games - which is very cool. The game came out in 2007, which is the same year Crysis came out, so I figured the graphics would be similar...well I was wrong. Too be fair they might very well be on a par with Crysis, but they are still pretty dated - not terrible, just not something I want to spend hours looking at even if the story is a good one. Plus given you only have two hours of game time to decide and having plunked down $20 for the game I figured I'd just pull the string now. If I had paid like $5 I might have played longer too see if there was a worthwhile story there and some decent action.

So take my review for what it's worth. If you can deal with some outdated graphics and clunky game play and if you can get the game on sale, it might be worth a try.

It's overall an ok game but it's aging more and more. Lots of bugs to encounter, a totally outdated saving system, etc... The NPC are far from smart. The graphics aren't an issue. They were good for their time and now it's part of the atmosphere of the game.

So, is this game worth it? Well, yes it is. It's is a good game and just like I said, the atmosphere of the game is what makes it unique. But there are some very annoying problems, related to its age, that you may encounter.

Almost everything about the game is done well, so I'm just going to place the items that I thought made it less than a 10/10.

* Traveling was mind numbingly tedious.  On the map you could spot your objective only a couple KM away only to have a barb wire fence in your way which is inexplicably able to stop a man with a bazooka, grenades, and a Rambo knife that just finished taking down an army of undead.

* Why on God's green earth isn't there a function to right click and place a custom marker on the map?

* Even though you chose a different quest the arrow still points in the direction it wants you to go.

* "Return for the reward" and there's no one there.

* The different levels without showing the road maps of the levels you're not currently on is just silly and very annoying for no reason.

I sincerely hope they refined the above in the next 2 games along with the upcoming release because they're a thorn in the side of an otherwise great game.

The early game is a little tough to get into, the game is much harder than its sequels, but the story telling and world building is top tier. Its certainly a product of its time, its rough around the edges but certainly worth a pickup on sale. Took me just under 10 hours of casual play doing mostly the main quest line, but i enjoyed the side quests much more, especially "The Monolith's secret". Gun play is solid but there is a limited arsenal, voice acting is good and the way the factions interact is reflective of how the game continues to be set in a ever interacting world. 

TLDR: Its not the best in the series (in my opinion) but is still a good game, its rough around the edges but the story telling, world building and quest experience make up for the dated mechanics and visuals.

Fantastic game, i highly recommend sticking it out through the beginning and learning this game. it took me four times of coming back to this game to actually make any progress. The gun play does feel foreign and almost bad at the beginning which is what really makes it difficult to get used to. They do this to make the later guns feel more impactful and powerful. The best tip i can give is always aim for the head. Its usually a 1 shot kill. Because of the way you have to play this game it makes you play more tactical and gets you more engrossed into the world. That is what is amazing about this game, how deep and connected you feel with the world and the factions. Always on alert, paying attention to your surroundings. The ending kind of looses the feeling you get all the way up to the red forest. After that the guns you get are good enough to beat the game with and all you do is fight a crap ton of enemies. I did not even return back to the traders to sell items or restock. Even with this gripe it is still an amazing game and holds up to this day. Also i did not use any mods. if you do and it is your first playthrough i would only download ones that patch bugs and do not alter the game, at least for the first playthrough. my intention is the beat clear sky and call of pripyat, then play the gamma mod. id give it a 8.5/10. i cant wait to play the next games and this series will probably go down as one of my top

As a lifelong gamer, I was beyond excited when I stumbled upon this game on Steam. I eagerly downloaded it and started playing, but my initial excitement quickly faded. The graphics were lackluster, the controls were clunky, and the storyline was uninspired. I felt disappointed and like I had wasted my time and money. However, I soon discovered that the multiplayer mode was a hidden gem. I joined a group of players and had some of the most fun and intense gaming sessions of my life. The cooperative gameplay and friendly community made up for all of the game's shortcomings. In the end, I found myself logging on every day to play with my new friends. While the single-player aspect was a letdown, the multiplayer aspect of this game was a pleasant surprise and a real joy to play :)

One of the first games I got for my first PC build because I've heard good things, and with the sale at the time, thought it be fun to try. Boy was I blown away. This game holds up very well for its age, I can already see myself spending more time in it then some of the games I got that released in the last year or two.

 If you're a fan of the 3D Fallout games, and enjoy apocalyptic settings I could not recommend this to you enough. Even with the dated graphics and mechanics I found myself easily immersed in this world. I am excited to get myself through these games before S.T.A.L.K.E.R 2 comes out. I would also recommend this to any FPS enthusiast, especially since its age means most should be able to run it on whatever they have.

This game feels like the kind of game you wouldnt enjoy. You die constantly, the guns suck, the ai can see you from across the map and the graphics look a bit dated at some points, but for some reason it just works. You are vulnerable but so is the ai making gunfights quick if you are able to outsmart the enemys and flank them. The guns while bad at points can work and will if you use them properly and not as if its a call of duty game. The textures and models while dated can work really well because of the lighting in this game makes a game that was released in 2008 look like a game that came out in 2018. 

If you dont enjoy hard games and arent the kind of person who likes pressing quick save and quick load constantly, i wouldnt recommend this game. But to anyone who likes a challenge and wants to play a game in a world that feels real, i would highly recommend this game.

As a fan of the Half Life games (particularly Half Life 2 and episodes,) it's no surprise that this game grabbed my attention.
The game is, put simply, dull but that is completely by design. It creates this moody and incredibly eerie atmosphere which immerses you into this post-apocalyptic world where almost everything wants to kill you. 

Going into the game almost completely blind, the story didn't grip me straight away, but the atmospheric design, lore and game-play did. At first, I found it hard, frustratingly so. However, after I tweaked some of my settings and adjusted to the A.I, I started to understand how this game wanted to be played. 

Running around spraying at all the enemies will only get you killed and will deplete your resources fast; Meds and ammo are sparse so use them sparingly. Also, use your environment to your advantage and peak around every corner. At heart, this game is just an FPS Survival with RPG elements and the game-play loop is very simple. However, the way it is designed forces you to fight-smart, making you think strategically and take extra-safe precautions.  

Even after all that being said, staying alive can be hard for the average player which can be quite off-putting to new comers. Although, I can re-assure you that the there is a quick save feature and, from experience, I'd recommend you use it frequently.

Most side quests are straight up useless, inventory management is annoying and time consuming. Trade is scuffed because you quickly have infinite money, oh and of course legions of bugs. Having one of the main story NPCs turning hostile out of nowhere just did it for me :)

Saw the bundle for all three S.T.A.L.K.E.R. on sale and figured I'd check it out. I'm new to FPS games on PC so getting used to controls is a bit tough at first. The atmosphere and tension in gameplay is very cool, especially when I'm not as confident in movement and gunplay. Hoping the rest of the game is as enjoyable as the first few hours.

S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Shadow Of Chernobyl, or S.O.C. for short, is a masterpiece of a game I first completed not too long ago, in august of 2022. I played the game with the STALKER Complete 2009 mod, which I was hesitant to use at first as I usually used S.O.C. All In One Patch by "BalaclavaBandit" credit to him for making my first time playing the game so enjoyable. But after installing the mod, I was still hesitant to play the game with that mod installed for a reason you may find funny; I didn't say I liked the way it changed Strelok's gloves and how they didn't change with the suit. Still, mainly the fact that it looked like Strelok was wearing a black trenchcoat and black leather gloves, which just seemed too edgy for his character and his established lore, but I kept going. The next thing that made me hesitant about using the mod was the excessive amount of artifacts everywhere, especially in the garbage.

Another thing the mod did was overhaul the graphics, but I could barely notice it. Supposedly it also changed the weather, but I only really encountered that the sky was cloudy a lot more commonly. I carried all this hesitation throughout the game, but it was too late by the time of the barrier zone, which I reached a week after I started because I also had responsibilities and couldn't just finish the game in one sitting. I also got the true ending on my first playthrough, but I had to look it up after clearing the powerplant and getting to the coded door without the code breaker. Let's talk about the C.N.P.P. for a minute. It is one of the worst levels in gaming, rivaled by god knows what and is annoying to an extreme. If you have yet to learn what it is like to run through the outside train yard before you meet the monolith with two medkits! I repeat, two medkits!

Then you are a lucky soul, unlike me, who, instead of preparing for my first time at the C.N.P.P., just went straight through Pripyat after turning off the radar. This level could be better, unlike the rest of the game; although by default, the base game is buggy and glitchy, you can quickly fix that with mods. I have already spoiled a lot by mentioning the barrier, code breaker, coded door, C.N.P.P., and radar, but I will spoil it no further. But that ending is such a twist. This vital information gave me a better understanding of the game's lore. Too bad I can't talk about it. But other than the C.N.P.P., it's a great game and truly depicts what a game should be, giving the player a feeling that they have an impact while also making the enemies feel just as powerful and impactful. The atmosphere is top-notch, and the gameplay is fun but sometimes tiring. Overall, 9/10.

fun game
It's good for what it is and when it was made. All though it could do with a fix for the crashing issue when loading a game (quick and normal save).

For a game published in 2007, this blows nearly all contemporary AAA single-player experiences out of the water. The firefights are intense and there is a strong sense in the beginning that you are expendable flesh just like every moving creature in the Zone. I only have 4 hours and I'm already addicted. If you want to survive and get superior weaponry, you're gonna have to play smart, patient, and you're going to have to pay attention to your surroundings. This game doesn't really hand you anything besides quest instructions, a pistol, a knife, and a pager. 

Do yourself a favor and play it on Master difficulty. You can't run around and quickscope everyone, you're going to have to play cover and maneuver through the AI, which is fairly decent for a game that's over a decade old. They definitely don't just run at you to die in the meat grinder. Your enemies will move in groups. If they spot a dead body, their first response will be to back up and let their friends know there's a dead dude on the floor. 

(Mild gameplay loop spoilers ahead) 
Guns are wildly inaccurate. While at first I found this frustrating, I figured out that pistols aren't very effective beyond 10m. You'll want to find a rifle (which I found in like the first three hours). Even then, I'm still hurting for a long rifle. I thought this was stupid until I realized everyone else has the same inaccuracy I do. Sometimes it's better to haul ass than it is to spend ammo on a fight. 

In short: 10/10 really makes you feeeeeel like a STALKER.
You get into a gun fight and the game crashes. I think the atmosphere and presentation of the game is great and all but literally everything else is borderline shovelware quality.
Overcoat and a Krinkov saves the world

An almost perfect balance between a good FPS and a very immersive (semi) open-world RPG with meaningful choices to make, with a good story with multiple possible endings. The atmosphere is phenomenal, the gameplay is solid and almost addictive, enemy AI is decent (not great, not terrible), the Zone feels dangerous, alive and dynamic (unscripted events will happen without player input). Sure, the graphics are outdated, but the great art direction, level and sound design make up for that, making for a very immersive atmosphere in S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl. 

It has a few rough edges (I had a few crashes, nothing game-breaking), but overall it's a very solid, enjoyable game, definitely worth buying.

[h1]C.L.U.N.K.E.R.[/h1]

I remember watching a trailer in the early 2000s (before HL 2 & Doom 3) showcasing bullet ballistics among other cool stuff. Faithful material penetration and trajectory deformation depending on caliber fired, weapon reload animations, sounds... Was the most impressive thing I've seen as far as realism goes. Dream come true for everyone who fantasized about a proper shooter. When it released I was one of the lucky ones capable of running it in all its glory.

Today its cult status holds as if no time has passed, much like the place where story takes place - in Chernobyl exclusion zone, 20 years after the first incident. It was right the 2nd one that caused it all... Can't tell more without spoiling it as story in one of the better parts although the full reveal comes only near the very end.
For the most part you'll be competing quests for rewards to earn enough to afford better gear. Once set you'll venture outside the Rookie Village, closer to Zone's center and closer to mystery surrounding your recent past. Besides the main quest there are few unique side-quests for added flavor and many generic repeatable ones which rarely pay off.

A lot has been said about the atmosphere and rightfully so. One of the appeals is there are no heroes here, just ordinary men in extraordinary circumstances, seeking riches found only in the Zone. Primarily rare Artifacts, head sized otherworldly objects that provide passive stat bonuses when worn on belt and also selling for hefty prices. They're found around various anomalies, hazardous localized areas damaging anyone coming close and fatal to those pushing their luck.
To me most of the atmosphere comes from highly unique visual setting. What Far Cry/Crysis was for foliage that is Stalker for concrete. It is so well done it looks better than even the recent Stalker 2 triler. Texture parallax mapping is of just right detail density to look good from up close and afar. Concrete, brick, steel and wood are just so well weathered it just feels right. Devs spared no expense at adding extra details where others would simply duplicate assets to fill space. If there was an opportunity to make rebar stick out and bend a certain but different way than one next to it they done it. Same applies to literary everything: collapsing rooftops/beams, window frames, half destroyed walls, broken ceramic covers, placement of props and damage it suffered, all done with extreme attention to detail and contributes to immersion unlike anywhere else. And there's lots to explore - dozen or so maps about half square kilometers in size connected via loading gates and filled with buildings in various stages of decay.

AI is so good and disciplined in combat it'll make you rage like you're the bottom feeder in online matches. Thankfully they can't use grenades that would be too much. Their accuracy is just a flat chance based on distance so staying afar greatly increases your odds. What they lack in lethality they sure make up in survivability however.

Performance is impressive considering one major shortcoming it shares with another game released in the same year: Crysis. It runs on a single CPU core and despite source being available no one managed to bypass this bottleneck. That said slowdowns only come from script execution when AI comes 'online' in 150m circle around the player. When you see high quality shadows from a railing high up in the tower being cast everywhere by a guard's headlamp at night you won't believe how cool it looks and smooth it runs. I sure couldn't... must have played too many Unity games lately.

Last thing game does amazing is projectile ballistics (spread is a whole different ballgame). Speed, air resistance, penetration and ricochets feel realistic (except wind immunity), especially when you see a tracer bouncing of a helmet but its occupant dropping cold on the ground. A person would assume gunplay is out of this world, but...

* * *

Of many weapons there are every one is affected by bizarre design decision of having a random arbitrary bullet spread. To illustrate, ideal scenario of being still, low stance, iron sights, pristine weapon, first shoot: 1m cone shaped spread over just 30 meters. Yep Slavs in their infinite wisdom never fail to disappoint. I should know I'm one of them... Gunplay as a result is total rubbish until mid/late game when you find a rifle devs decided it should have a lower spread. You'll only miss 50% from then on.
But it gets worse, much worse, the so called [url=https://www.reddit.com/r/stalker/comments/8b6u4q]Magic Bullet[/url] mechanic. After the initial shot an invisible 1 second timer starts before the next fired shoot will do same amount of damage, any sooner and it'll do only 20%. Effectively turning automatic weapons you worked so hard to get into children toys. Add to that bullets fired from sidearms disappear after 50m, and even less for Shooties.

Stealth is broken even though 2 out of first 3 missions encourage it. Once spotted (or reload within ~20m of nearest enemy) everyone on the map knows exactly where you are and is aiming at you. If bullets can penetrate whatever cover you deemed safe when you saved, time to say goodbye.
Sound is broken. Direction is fine I suppose but distance doesn't matter. Had a pack of wild dogs bark in my ear only to realize they're far away when I turned. Eventually you get used to that an start ignoring stuff not directly in front. Custom OpenAL driver couldn't fix it either. Listening to "Hello, Hello" coming from inside a hermetically sealed reinforced concrete bunker over and over again from 200m away became a global MEME long ago.

Until relatively recent beta patch game was melting hardware because ordinary V-Sync still wasn't functional. Some time ago devs released a statement how they indeed weren't set out to brick your PCs because of that. No bug komrad, merely an anomaly.

Gunplay alone is enough to bury the game for me but I ain't done yet. Game was in development hell for a long time and amount of bugs on release day would shame even Bethesda. Today is not much better in terms of official patches. Full list is quite long and serious, including show stoppers, but thankfully there is a cure for most of them. The answer is [b]Zone Reclamation Project[/b], community bug-fixing project set out to preserve full vanilla gameplay, with addition of a Modifier program allowing for tweaking over 100 different things (including non-vanilla QoL) using a friendly GUI. Just know it's not trivial to set up, took me 2 weeks of research (ZRP and everything else) before even setting foot in the Zone.

* * *

Even with the amazing ZRP it's a hard pass from me. Way too clunky even after fully set up to one tastes. Exploration looses appeal as soon as you realize there's not that many pre-placed goodies and those that are just aren't worth it. Every single hidden stash is empty until you read a dead man's PDA pointing to it, when it magically gets few items placed inside, almost always useless.
Annoying things still present: enemies can still spawn on top of you, running is interrupted if there's even a slight change in ground elevation (wait till you encounter stairs lol), interaction between stash and inventory becomes a nightmare with many objects, distant battles cluttering the world with unrecoverable items, PDA map always centering on some distant unrelated place, shallow global AI (A-Life) - living world outside your 150m circle for all intents and purposes does not exist.

No idea how I managed to finish it relatively unscathed 16 years ago the first time but it got me into MODs finally, just to get rid of many dumb design decisions (forced quest with low time limits, low carry capacity, no gear repairs, etc). Wish to play CS and CoP for the first time and had to dive in SoC once again for the full experience. From what I read that ride should be a lot smoother but at the expense of storytelling. Wish me luck Stalkers.

S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernoby combines a huge dark landscape, a fantasic story that leaves you  always wanting a little more, supernatural monsters, insane cult leaders, stalkers, and more scatter the landscape giving an never ending feeling of danger. The freedom to wander and roam searching for things and not knowing what awaits creates one of the most immersive experiences in gaming.

Stole some documents, had to escape from a military compound. Every exit was a death trap, so I went on the roof drank some vodka and jumped down 4 stories, 80% damage. Run through a crack in the wall of the compound head on into an anomaly almost die again until I heal myself. Think I'm in the clear until a mutant sees me and I have to engage him, unfortunately shooting at him alerts the military and they start shooting at both of us. By all odds me and the mutant then have a common foe, we both engage the enemy in a fierce firefight and mouthfight until all our enemies are dead. Then I shoot the mutant in the head killing it instantly.  

There is no mercy in the zone.

Is this worth playing/buying? 

Certainly yes during sales :) 

As a game it will suck you in and make you enjoy playing it without even thinking about finishing it.
It will fill your brain with alternative priorities than pushing it to its end ... but there is the catch ... the end will catch you with your guard down, not expecting it to end that sharply! 

It makes you as a game, believe that it will last for twice as much but it won't be far before you realize you are watching the final cinematic ( i won't spoil here )

I am not going to say anything about graphics etc as this is a 2007 title and instead of focusing on that you should better focus on some revolutionary ideas it brought to the gaming industry and the fact that a nowadays copycat is one of the most played game atm (It won't be long before you realize which is that) ;) 

Overall a worthy experience.

[h1]*DON'T STAND THERE, COME IN STALKER!*[/h1]

[h1]To put it bluntly, this is probably one of the best PC-ONLY game I have ever played.[/h1]

[h1]STALKER[/h1]
[b]Scavengers, Trespassers, Adventurers, Loners, Killers, Explorers, and Robbers.[/b]

One of the most atmospheric open-world game I have ever played, this game is close to perfection. Even on modern times, this game still holds out pretty good while back in 2007, it required top tech to run it properly.


[h1]POSITIVES:[/h1]
[b]+Unique, atmospheric, immersive, open-ended first-person survival gameplay (more atmospheric than Metro 2033 franchise espcially for the open-ended/non-linear gameplay). 
+Amazing virtual world is like being at Chernobyl, especially on the DYNAMIC day/night rotation.
+Fantastic and creepy ambient music! Gotta love the guitar rest areas too!
+Excellent blend of action, horror, and exploration.
+Large variety of options, armours, gadgets and weapons.[/b]


[h1]NEGATIVES:[/h1]
[b]-Game was filled with bugs and for a long time until it got thouroughly patched by now.
-Story is a bit incoherent (a bit hard to follow up... read STALKER WIKIA once you beat the game)
-Even at novice level, Combat and AI can often be too challenging.
-Glitched A.I. at times.[/b]


[h1]OVERALL & RECOMMENDATION:[/h1]
[b]F.U.K.C.I.N.G. GOOD GAME! Especially now that the bugs got ironed out, you HAVE to play this game! While at it, go ahead and play the rest of the STALKER series, CLEAR SKIES and CALL OF PRIPYAT. [/b]

I’m not typically an FPS player, so the style of SoC is something pretty new to me.  But with Stalker 2 on the horizon, I took the Christmas deal to pick up all three original games for less than a tenner to see whether the upcoming release might be something that would appeal to me.  The jury is definitely still out on that.

SoC has a fantastic brooding atmosphere which fits perfectly with the environment and story.  It keeps reminding you that you’re in a very unique place, where nothing should be taken for granted.  For a game of its age, personally I think the graphics have aged pretty well:  It’s certainly more attractive graphically that something like Fallout 3.

For me though, the gameplay itself is a complete let down, with too many features being poorly implemented.

Let’s start with the zone itself.  It might look like a huge open-world space, but it isn’t. It’s a series of connected ‘regions’, and transitioning between them can only happen at specific entry/exit points.  Sometimes passing through these points will actually teleport you huge distances within the overall zone map.  Immersion goes out the window.

Dotted all over the map are personal stashes from which to steal, anomalies to collect for financial gain, dead NPC to pickpocket.  You can horde endless amounts of goodies because the game is literally putting them there for you.  Except there’s a problem – there is nothing you can do to increase your carry capacity.  In no time you’re overweight and can barely move.  Of course, there’s a simple answer to that.  Just stop looting. Before long the shimmering glow of an anomaly is something you just start ignoring.  You simply don’t have the capacity to collect them and cart them back to a trader.  Kill a gang of bandits and it’s not worth looting their bodies because you’re already over capacity.  SoC is not a looter shooter, but can’t stop itself from giving you things to loot.

As I said I’m to really an FPS player, so I can’t speak for how well gunplay is implemented (by other people’s accounts, not very well).  All I can say on the point is that when you have a gang of five NPCs closing in on you and you empty an entire magazine into one of them and they still don’t drop, you have to wonder whether the balance is a bit off.  I believe this has something to do with the difficulty level of the game – the lower the difficulty level the harder you are to kill; but by the same straw the more difficult it is to kill the enemy.  To my mind that would mean that the odds of you winning a battle are the same regardless of the difficulty level – the only variable here is how much ammo you have to use up in the process.

It has been noted by others that NPC have an unfair ability to detect you.  The game strongly hints towards the use of stealth, but this is somewhat redundant if the enemy is always able to detect you.  One situation I personally encountered was a gang of bandits who were able to detect me through a train wagon while I was crouching and had been completely immobile for at least 30 seconds.

Questing is another area in SoC that has been poorly implemented in my opinion.  Conversing with many NPCs may lead to them giving you a fairly mundane quest – “go get thing from location and bring it back”.  But too frequently those quests might be impossible to achieve, especially given that they have a one-day expiration date.   The map tells me the weapon should be here, the quest’s wiki page tells me, “yeah, there’s a good chance the weapon will have been moved. Don’t take the quest unless you’ve already found weapon”.  More significant quest lines can be gotten from traders.  These are usually more detailed and have far more steps, but still the map-markers and descriptions can be vague, and the level design means that there’s only one way in and one way out.  In the first of the Agroprom missions I had collected what I was there for but rather than moving on to the get-out-of-there step, the map was telling me to go to a different location on the same site.  When I finally got to that point, after wasting more ammo and med kits, there was literally no reason for me to go there, and the quest marker moved on to telling me to leave the site.

A third type of quest appears quite repetitively when you pass through some of those region transition points.  Through the PDA one of the traders will ask you to kill all the bandits in this region. Because stealth doesn’t work you’re going to have to kill them anyway before you can move on, so making a quest of it seems somewhat pointless.  Once they are all dead you’ll get a reward from the trader - but only if you travel all the way to the trader to hand the quest in.  Why can the trader give me a quest remotely, but still need me to go back to him for my reward?  This just leads to so much back and forth that eventually you just kill the bandits for free in order to pursue your objective rather than the trader’s.

One irritation I want to touch on is the strange drone fly-over scenes that happen occasionally when moving through a region.  They are supposed to give you a birds-eye view of the area you are entering so that you can get an idea of the layout and what’s already going on when you arrive.  But they happen at only one entry point even if there are multiple ways to get into that area, so if you take the wrong route, you won’t see it but will still end up in the middle of the battle.  What’s more they happen every time you pass that entry point, no matter how many times you’ve passed through before, and while the fly-over is happening your character is stuck and vulnerable to attack.  My character genuinely died of a mutant attack while one of these fly-overs was happening (for the fifth time).

My final major gripe with SoC is the non-existence of any character progression.  My PDA tells me how many points I’ve earned from kills, and they in turn transport me up the zone ranking.  But what does my character actually gain from that?  From what I can tell – nothing.  My character will only ever get better in the game if I as the player get better at playing it.  As the main story progresses, and he ventures deeper and deeper, my character is no better equipped for what lies ahead than he was at the start of the game.  He may have a more powerful gun, but his ammo capacity hasn’t increased; he may have accrued a vast wealth from trading, but that won’t help him against the all-seeing AI.  As a bad or mediocre player, I can never hope to reach the end of this game, because there is nothing that I can do to give my character fighting chance.  I just need to become better.  And I don’t like that.

I have only started this game once and after about 30 hours am nowhere near its conclusion, but I just don’t feel like I want to go any further.  I can’t tell whether it’s because I’m just a useless player, or that the game just doesn’t want me to play it.  The zone is not supposed to be an inviting place, but I wonder whether the development team pushed their unwelcome a bit too hard.   I am interested in finding an end to the story, but would rather watch a playthrough on YouTube than persevere on my own.

So I gave this game a try because I had heard so many people talk very positively about it and after about an hour I didn't get it. The AI was janky at best and the shooting felt off. I couldn't tell if it was an accuracy issue or if the guns just didn't feel strong enough. Started looking through reviews and finally got to a few that basically said guns don't do much damage outside of headshots and there's very little indication that you actually hit the target. So my shots were likely landing, I just couldnt tell that they were. I could only tell when they would actually flinch from a shot, which they wouldn't always do. There are mods to fix these issues I just didn't feel the game did enough for me to invest the time to implement them. Atmosphere felt cool and the story may be interesting but if the core gameplay doesn't work properly then there's no real point in trying to play it 

You shouldn't have to mod a game to make it playable, this might be an amazing game with those mods but you still shouldn't have to implement them in the first place. I do wish that Steam had a middle of the road review option because I'm mostly writing this so people know what they may be getting into when buying this. I didn't see enough in what I played that warrants taking the time to mod. Just wanted to give a bit of a heads up


EDIT: Felt some of the terminology was harsher than the game deserved and edited portions to indicate that my issues with the shooting mechanics weren't with the accuracy but more with the indication of shots landing which made me question accuracy.

I picked up this game because many people told me it was fantastic, and after playing through and getting the "greedy" ending I was a little frustrated. Though I do really like this game, its mechanics, and especially the setting, I don't think the game does enough to 1. emphasise morality and its importance through important choices (as games such as Disco Elysium or Fallout New Vegas) 2. lead the player to an appropriate ending
SPOILER WARNING
I finished the game by approaching the wish-maker with ~120,000 rubles, which is not enough to buy a suit of armour that i was saving up for before I realised I was about to finish the game, which got me the 'Greed' ending, where my generous, helpful, and well prepared stalker suddenly decides all they want is to be rich, which promptly gets them killed. I realise the game also wants you to find and kill someone from your past who you can't remember, but I thought that helping the people of the zone was more important, so I pursued that instead. I would have been fine with a choice given to me about the failed wish, but to have my character decide without me they want nothing but to be rich left a sour taste in my mouth.

TLDR; great game, but maybe before playing, watch a "before you play stalker" video, or use a rough guide to get the best out of it

S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl is a great open world FPS game that incorporates survival and horror elements in its apocalyptic atmosphere. Set in 2006 in Ukraine, near the area where the Chernobyl nuclear plant exploded in the 1980s, you find yourself in a deadly and ruthless exclusion zone after a mysterious new accident. Battle mutants, other scavengers (stalkers), and the radiation to hunt valuables and strange artifacts. 

Heavy FPS. There is no character creation, but there is inventory management.

If you liked Fallout 3 or Fallout New Vegas, but wanted something a little more difficult, this game is for you.  You might even rage quit, like I did after about 6 hours (it says 4 hours on record, not sure why). But still, good game I plan to pick up again.

It is amazing what the developers are doing for Ukraine, raising money for the displaced and spreading awareness. Thank you.

- blood/gore
- animal killings/death
- killing humans, obviously

Easily one of the most immersive and atmospheric games Ive ever played. Genuinely feels like SoC set the stage for games like Fallout New Vegas with it’s non linear story telling and character interactions. Sure the story is nothing ground breaking but provides a perfect enough pretext to set out and explore the zone setting in motion an addicting gameplay loop: finding new loot, meeting new characters, discovering rare artifacts, etc… A solid game through-and-through, but I’d be lying if I said it was perfect. I had two MAJOR issues with this one that caused an otherwise amazing game to feel incredibly unpleasant to play at times:

- The amount of backtracking is atrocious. I swear half my play time was spent running between point A and point B to complete missions (endurance artifacts are ESSENTIAL, for sake of your sanity). Having the option to fast travel to and from missions upon starting and completing them in Call of Pripyat was a welcome inclusion.

- The final act is pretty bad, especially when compared to the rest of the game. It suddenly becomes a generic FPS game and throws everything else that made the game so great out the window. Ubering your way through waves of Monolith soldiers goes against every core philosophy this game had been perfectly setting up up until this point. Out with a simmer, not a bang.

Regardless of it’s faults, Stalker SoC has quickly become an all time personal favorite of mine. A one of a kind game!

Coming into this game I had absolutely zero knowledge about the franchise and what it's about, buying it purely because it looked fun and sounded interesting. What followed was probably one of the best experiences I've had in gaming. Ever.

While start is slow and can be a bit confusing as to what the hell is going on, it remains enjoyable, and the further you get into the story, the more this game shines. Roughly about 10 hours in is where the story and gameplay truly starts to shine. The ending, while feeling quite abrupt, is fitting, and quite a different end than most games in the genre.

The gun play can, at times, feel weak (with certain guns not feeling weighted properly and gunfights in tight areas often making enemies feel much spongier than they probably are) and this can (and does) become quite frustrating right at the beginning and right near the end of the game. But where it does shine is in more open areas medium distance between you and the enemies, and most of the late game guns I encountered were incredibly fun to use in these settings and felt good to shoot with.

I definitely recommend this game to anyone who's interested (and if you're looking through the reviews for this game, you probably are). I would however recommend you download the ZRP mod with it, as the base game is quite buggy.

The atmosphere in this game is unreal. It's just so fun to just wander around and discover the zone. However, the first couple of hours are extremely rough. The pistol just straight up sucks, and the Viper 5 isn't too much better. Once you get a rifle like an AKM though, the gunplay becomes a lot more fun. Several tips:
1. Install ZRP mod for a more stable experience (never got any crashes)
2. Headshots are always a one-hit kill. Be patient and don't spray-and-pray. Wait between shots if you can, and use cover.

Also, if you get motion sickness from this game like I did, I recommend 3 things, though it still took a couple of sessions for me to get used to it.
1. Disable head bobbing via ZRP mod's Modifier.exe
2. Install another mod to increase FOV to something like 90
3. Try to avoid sprinting and moving the camera at the same time

[h1]Overview[/h1]
S.T.A.L.K.E.R. SoC. The game that popularized again bcs of recent "War". This game is very famous around my Junior High School years. Now when this game on Summersale 2022, i decided to buy 3 of them lol. Ofc tried the first game of the list according to release dates.

Update: I've Finished the game with 2 Ending, The Infinite Dark ending and Rich Ending (Which is the stupidest ending??).


[h1] PROS : [/h1]
- This game is fun, Finally I realised why I get bored quickly in nowadays game, This game aged like fine wine, good story, good gameplay, good 
- [strike]The survival mechanics doesn't involve eat or drink[/strike]You can get hungry somehow but food is scarce to found if you dont diligently kill everyone and trading. But food can help you regenerate healths while not wasting the instant heal like Med-kit/Bandages
- The game is simple, not too overcrowded mechanics that ruin the survival and shoot-out flows.
- The Graphics of character models maybe dated, but the environment really felt real especially compared from the last game I played. Fallout 4
- The animations maybe dated, but the AI of enemies react really good. Even surprising most times they can figure out how to flank me in many different ways. They hiding, they flanking, they confuse you to trick where to shoot them. It's challenging and fun.
- The story itself is pretty straightforward and involves a-lot of reading. And no choices so far impacting anything. So if you find side jobs if you need cash you should do it.[strike] There's no moral penalty[/strike]. There is a moral penalty, you can avoid kill anyone aside bandits and keep finishing quest that don't involve killing innocent people and keep NPC from death. But once death, you need to reload. Don't wander too far since they often died out of sights. [strike]You can just accept or refuse, that's it.[/strike] There is a choice but only about the ending. You can find it on internet lol. It only matters of what you do at the end.

[h1] CONS : [/h1]
- Map UI and how to pinpoint locations and find which one is main quest, side quest, etc. really annoying they don't look different at all. Maybe I've spoiled by modern games mini-maps features as this game is 2007.
- [strike]It's hard to shoot accurate from long range if we don't have any feature to mods weapons with scopes or iron sights.[/strike] There is a mod like silencer, scopes but it only apply to certain weapons, and so far it for mid-low tier weapons only. But also, this game is really simple and we can concern to other aspects.
- The enemies eat bullets like sponge, especially in later game. Idk, its really hard to get headshot and approaching them is hard enoguh with radiations everywhere.
- The enemies outfit models looks to similar to each other, confusing me is that the same guy I've been shooting still alive or is there dozens more?
- If the game approach [strike]nigh time[/strike] Dawn/Evening. Its really hard to see any enemies but they can see us clearly somehow without flashlights.
- [strike]I'm still early in game, so I've yet to find out any base that give us any other abilities to sell or trade. Even buying better gears.[/strike] So far I only found 3 sellers, The First guy on Bunker, The Bar with cool music, and The Lab professor in middle of zombie infested nowhere. Running back with heavy loads sometimes infuriating, except you want to drag corpses each time, somehow you can drag them no matter how heavy their gears are lol.
- And the most annoying is if you forgot to save somewhere, when you die you get aaaaaaalll way back. I kept forget this game doesn't have any auto-save features. And when you save at bad spot or timing, wish you have 2 separate saves or this is it. You need to start from beginning again.
- OFTEN SAVE, you can get stuck in certain buildings and only way out is reloading last save.

Well theres other 2 games and [strike]I've still far from finishing SoC[/strike], I heard they improved half of what i've complained here. But if this game deserve the classics title as people said? Idk, so far it's a good game [strike]but I still yet see. Maybe updating the game after finishing it later[/strike]. Recommended

This game is a pretty mixed bag, on one hand it has an excellent atmosphere, the inventory and equipment mechanics are actually really fun, and game play definitely has its moments where it truly shines and you can see what the devs intended, but its really janky. Its recommended you use an overhaul mod to fix the broken npcs and weapons. on the upside, its pretty easy to install the fixes, there are several good guides right here on steam for it. However, even with these, there are still moments that are really frustrating. there are instakill traps in some areas, even in tight spaces like underground tunnels, and while you are fighting enemies. The human characters are honestly all pretty broken. For starters, they don't make sounds when they walk or move, so you will never have any idea how many or where anyone is unless you see them. this with the fact they like to hide in the dark corners in pretty frustrating. this wouldn't be so bad, but the game doesn't have autosaves, so dying unexpectedly without a quicksave can happen pretty often and is very annoying. even the friendly npcs are frustrating sometimes, they will block your path, especially on stairways, and once I was even softlocked because I was in the corner that an npc was trying to move into, so he just ran into me in the corner forever and blocked me from moving at all, forcing me to reload a save.

The open world is actually really cool, its made up of several levels that are separated by loading zones, and because they're not that big, it feels like a full open world, while still being small enough that travel even across the whole map doesn't take that long. each level is also pretty dense with things to do, and since looting dead enemies will often reveal locations of stashes, you have good reasons to revisit areas and find new little spots in the levels you already looked through. the game also has a system where npcs will move around the zone on their own, so it really feels alive, and like each level is always changing every time you go back. Even camps and areas will change npcs, maybe it will have bandits, or mutants, or mutants AND bandits, or maybe friendly stalkers took it over, and you can sell some stuff to lighten your pack.

All in all, i do recommend it. I'm writing this around half way through, so I don't know how it ends out, but i've had a great time despite it all.

S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Shadow Of Chernobyl, is a FPS RPG with a unique atmosphere in a horrific post-apocalyptic universe.

The game immerses you in a complete world, with many side quests and a very interesting main plot. If you take the time to read the notes and talk to the NPCs you will learn a lot about the world and your character.

There is a lot of armor and weapons in the game, which can be modified with accessories such as sights or grenade launchers, the loot system is very pleasant thanks to the many caches scattered on the map.

The game features different factions of NPCs, each with their own story and a large bestiary. The AI is quite good and makes every fight enjoyable.

The game is quite old and has a lot of bugs, so it is recommended to save regularly in order not to break the progress of the game.

In conclusion, if you like post-apo, this game is a must, you can find the trilogy for a very cheap price and it will bring you in a unique universe that no other game can offer.

I've been trying to go through some classic games recently and STALKER appeared on my radar since it was on sale. 
I've heard many good things about it so it seemed like a good game to try out.

I have to admit, the game whilst nothing groundbreaking these days, did provide quite a few hours of entertainment.
Despite it being 15 years old, Stalker:SoC has held up very well and the mod community helps it even more.
Speaking of mods: INSTALL ZRP BEFORE YOU START PLAYING. It will not effect the story at all and will fix some annoying bugs.

With that out of the way, the good:
*Decent gameplay mechanics that overall don't really get in the way of the game (though they aren't particularly "different" either, but let's remember this is a 15 year old game)
*The graphics, whilst scuffed occasionally still hold up really well even in the modern day and fir the aesthetic of the world created by the story.
*Compatibility - despite the game being 15 years old, the compatibility seems to be perfectly fine even with moderns systems. The more time goes by, the more I understand that this is not a given.
*The atmosphere is great and fits really well the theme of the game. Despite this being an old game, the devs clearly utilised what they had at the time well, whether its sounds scape, the look of the world and fleshed out the game world nicely.
*Good community and mods. If you want to expand on the experience in the Stalker: SoC experience, there are a few large mods that were made by the community that you could try out (like Autumn Aurora)

The bad:
*The voice acting is a bit all over the place. This game probabnly was primarily meant to be played in Russian, but then ported to English. This shows everywhere with signs being in Russian, some NPC chatter being in Russian, even some of the main mission dialogue you can hear is also in Russian. This wouldn't be as big of an issue if the game actually had subtitles, however it does not. There apparently is a mod that would add them but there is a possible incompatibility with the ZRP modpack so be warned.
The dialogue of some characters also has no variability and they just repeat the same thing over and over every time you walk close to them. This initially is just something you notice but the more you hear it, the more irritating it gets.
*Bugs - there are quite a few that seem to have been ignored by the developers at the time, some of which I cant imagine they werent aware of. This can be mitigated by using ZRP though.

Overall, I perfectly understand why this game has received the praise it has. By todays standards maybe this game is nothing amazing, but for its time I imagine it was quite the feat that the developers managed.
Its not a game you can't miss, but seeing how cheap it is by default (and you can get it for even less on sale) I think this is an easy game to pick up and try out!

I have just finished my first play through of STALKER and let me tell you it was an experience. I walked into this game knowing only that i should install a mod, for the game to run better (this did not give me high hopes). And now that I am done and recommending this game let me say "you should play the game". The graphics may be outdated as hell but let me tell you I had fun the hole way through this game. I wish i did more in my first play through, that my main advice with the game do as many side quest and exploring as you like cause before you no it you'll be lost to the zone.

What I Don't like 
- Graphics: This game is old and you can tell sometimes it's hard to tell the difference from an enemy to terrain 30 feet in front of you.
- Gun play: I'm very mixed about the dun play I like it's style but I hate that every gun is not accurate at rages exceeding 50 feet. some guns do no damage even to enemies that had the gun you just picked up.

Recommendations 
- go into the game blind 
- install a mod that helps the game not crash I like Reclamation project myself but any that are recommended should be good (mods are not needed but highly advised)
- Don't try to beat the game quickly: you can finish this game in 12 hours if you really try so I advise you grind gear, find good guns, and do any side quest that seem interesting cause many of the main side quest will send you down a rabbit hole of locations and NPC's 
- and finally stalker Don't get lost to the zone

You need a lot of patience to play this game. It's a labor of love and you can feel it everywhere. Engrossing is the word to describe it.

Now I said that you need a lot of patience. Why?
Weapon accuracy, inventory management, weapon accuracy, stamina, weapon accuracy, your weapon has jammed, weapon accuracy, game crashed, weapon accuracy, this fricking map hud is annoying and finally weapon accuracy.

Now, granted, it doesn't take too long for you to figure all of that out, but oh, boy, good luck until you get there. And If you read up online, trying to understand how weapon accuracy works as an example, you'll see that you're obviously not the only one bothered by this, but not only that, people who have GENUINELY tried to argue that this weapon innacuracy bs is a bit much, get bombarded by elitist douchebags saying that it's a skill issue. No, it isn't a fricking skill issue you moron, it's just bad, annoying and frustrating. ESPECIALLY near the end of the game. Enemies don't get these same issues, so it's just all very frustrating and stupid.

Having said that, the highs of this game are worth it. You'll hardly ever come across such an atmospheric game... Again, engrossing is the key word.

This game is incredibly fun and atmospheric, with an interesting premise that makes you constantly want more. The Zone is such an unique and incredible thing that just leaves you hooked, and the game play is surprisingly fun. A few things to note, I definitely recommend harder difficulties as they make the game easier, also the game is old, with tons of weird bugs and glitches, some of them harmless, others crash the game (don't eat food straight out of someone else's inventory for the love of god). 

All in all, if you can get through the jank, it is a really fun game with an interesting world that makes you crave more.

Watched a video by snipper on YT playing this game and it's exactly the style of games I like to play. Unfortunately, this game doesn't work at all, at least for me. 
The shooting is very bad, I can't tell if the weapons are just bad or the shots aren't actually hitting the AI or what exactly the problem is, but some enemies I shot over 16 rounds into with the starting pistol and nothing was happening. Other weapons also would take excessive rounds of ammunition to take down.
The radiation is really confusing to me. In fact, a lot of the HUD is generally confusing and there's no tutorial on what exactly all these readings and buttons and sounds are for. Numbers pop up and go away, beeping goes off and disappears, radiation comes seemingly from no wear and suddenly you're dying. There's also these translucent stationary floating orbs that pulse around the map and if you run into them, they pulse and deal damage. This is an interesting feature that I actually like but sometimes they don't appear at all and you can just hit one after another of these invisible explosions until you're bleeding out and you die.
The missions are REAL janky. The map has a mind of its own sometimes and it's difficult to navigate with the mouse controls. My objective also kept jumping around and even had the first objective and second objective active at the same time and wouldn't allow me to progress. When I finally did progress, I was dealt a lot of damage in game trying to figure out a way around the progression block and used up all my med-kits. Coincidentally, when I got to the next progression point, the objective was to give a guy a med-kit. Which I didn't have!! So I had to advance past my objective killing enemies and searching bodies in future mission points until I found a med-kit. At that point, I magically got radiation poisoning and died because I couldn't use the med-kit, I had to give it away! Which brings me to the last issue...
Lastly, and most importantly, I don't know if this is a feature or it's just broken but every time I died, I had to go all the way back to mission one. Full restart. Which makes no sense with an autosave feature. It prompts me to restart from last save, and full restarts me. I figured maybe it doesn't actually load from the autosave if you die so I tried going back to where I was and manually saved the game. When I died, I still started all the way back at the beginning of the game. So I tried manually loading the game from my last manual save but it loaded the game at the start of the first mission in the beginning of the game! So like I said, some games are like that, but if it has a save feature it shouldn't force restart you at the beginning.
Really wish I didn't spend $12 buying all three of these games just to find out I'm never going to play any of them. Unless some big changes take place, I will not be playing this. I really wish this wasn't the case because it has a lot of potential and what I did play had it's moments and watching other people play looked really exciting. But this is currently garbage as a download and play game. If it was free, I probably wouldn't have even written this but I spent money and it doesn't work so there you go. Let me know if they fix it, I'd love for it to work.

Playing this in 2022 for the first time, no mods, only vanilla. At first I didn't get it and was a bit confused as to why people love it. Then as I progressed further into the zone, met some monsters, factions and visited locations that send chills down my spine I got it. If an old game is playable AND enjoyable in 2022 it's a great game in my opinion. 15 years later it's still popular, I even checked online servers that were 90/100 full! 

The single player feels more alive than some MMORPGs with NPCs constantly talking, fighting, singing, complaining, laughing. Yes, they say the same thing over and over most of the time, but it still feels live. Rival factions fighting each other, NPCs vs monsters, monsters and unfortunate stalkers vs anomalies, all that adds to the overall disturbing ambiance. My only regret is not playing it earlier and [spoiler] that you can't repair weapons and armor *legally*. [/spoiler]
