[h1] S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Shadow of Chernobyl - 7.7/10 [/h1]
[b] Playtime - 9.8 hours [/b]

[b] Plot and Dialogue: [/b] 6/10, 6/10
[b] Setting and Art Design: [/b] 9.5/10
[b] Soundtrack: [/b] 7/10
[b] Graphics: [/b] 6/10 
[b] Gameplay and Sound Design: [/b] 8/10, 7/10

[b] Plot and Dialogue: [/b]
The plot of this game has enough to keep you enticed at the beginning by providing your character reasonable motivation as to why they do what they do. However, the plot doesn't really effect the character throughout the game and remains flat. It was serviceable but nothing great in reality. Dialogue isn't anything to write home about. Better than average, but not great.

[b] Setting and Art Design: [/b]
The setting of this game is where it earns its worth. The game feels so depressing and hopeless, which is what we should be expecting from it. You feel as if you are in this world and you are experiencing it yourself. While it has mostly a dull color scheme, it's appropriate for where the game is set. They really hit it out of the park here.

[b] Soundtrack:  [/b]
The lack of a soundtrack is to Stalker's benefit. This is not meant to be some sort of action film, it is a depressing tale that is meant to immerse you in the world. The only music present in this game is the main menu music (which is amazing at setting the tone), as well the music that appears throughout the game by people playing the guitar or over the radio.

[b] Graphics: [/b]
It was made 15 years ago. The graphics aren't great but they are serviceable. 

[b] Gameplay and Sound Design: [/b]
The gameplay is very brutal in this game. Guns are inaccurate, enemies later in the game are tanky, you can lose your health fast. You have to play this very methodically and have great resource management. It is tough and unforgiving, but it is enjoyable in the end. Some times there were bullshit deaths I will admit, but that's part of the game. PLEASE REMEMBER TO SAVE FREQUENTLY. AUTO SAVE IS BAD IN THIS GAME.

Sound design is wacky at some points, but good for most of the game. 

[b] Final Notes: [/b]
If you are interested in a more depressing and moody version of Fallout, this is right up your alley. It's usually on sale for $5 bucks and for that price, it's worth it for everyone. Play it and enjoy the world of Stalker. SAVE FREQUENTLY.

I love this game even with all its faults. However this game needs a WARNING sign to all who want to try it. I will briefly mention what i love about the game then i will explain all the issues this game has in order to provide said warning label.

This game has a cult following and somewhat of a pedigree. The buggy nature of the game mixed with some interesting story and setting along with great atmosphere and weird slavic shenanigans make this a one of a kind experience, especially since nothing has come out since the last game quite like it. Yes i adore the Metro series but that series has a better story, its more focused and linear and provides better atmosphere imho, while on the other hand this series is more focused on the setting and is more like an RPG with a focus not on levels of the character but guns, armor and artifacts. So it's a more technical RPG. That is unique. Add to that an abundance of mods that provide such an experience that will give you hours and hours of replayability and challenge (think Escape from Tarkov but singleplayer).

Now for the negative aspects of the game but only Vanilla (no Mods):
As mentioned the game has A LOT of bugs. Game breaks easilly, enemies shoot at you without looking at you, reloading a save sometimes doesn't reset enemy knowledge of your location, getting spotted a mile away, they shoot you trought walls, objective markers dont dissapear, voices repeating same lines over and over again, enemies don't flinch, instadeath, clones spawn in a single spot, enemies spawn and aim at walls or at the sky until you shoot at them, they shoot at you even if there is no way they can see you..... the list goes on.

Whatever everyone is saying, NO the weapons don't deal more damage on higher difficulties towards enemies. The first weapons are inaccurate so that makes you think you are shooting blanks while you are actually missing shots. Headshots usually kill in one shot, but for some reason not always (armored enemies or just glitches). 

Most quests are fetch and kill quests and don't bother doing them unless you really want to. Most of the resources (and money) are easy to come by during the later half of the game. The progression is natural from bad weapons to not knowing which one to carry since there are a lot of good ones suddenly.

The bad part of the game is the way you traverse around the map while collecting stuff and completing missions only to have to walk back the entire way just to complete it for the reward. Along the way most enemies respawn or raids occur so because of the way the semi-open world is structured you will have linear corridors you have to pass and they are almost always garded at some point by either mutants, dogs, bandits or zombified enemies.

The game shines during the middle segment but falls flat when nearing the end (last 3 missions). It becomes very linear and you have a point of no return that the game doesn't mention but some characters do in some sort of way if you pay attention. The problem is that you have to be well prepaired to even have the possibility of succeding. These last missions are VERY poorly designed and ruin what the first half of the game established. The game doesn't have a combat focus at all, that is the reason everything is so innacurate and wonky. Then the game decides to throw 30+ enemies in a single building at you just at the end of a mission... and then there is almost a constant wave of enemies until the end of the game. You will HAVE TO kill most of them to be able to pass alive. They will instakill you around corners, nade you while in cover, snipe you with a gauss rifle from a building far out of normal range (for a normal chance to hit them because of the bad accuracy) or RPG you from across the map. The enemy placement is really really bad during the last bit of the game. SAVE OFTEN and plan ahead. F6 is your best friend!

The last bad thing is the story kind of. Yes the atmosphere is good but ruined during the last bit of the game cause of the abominable combat. Same goes for the story. But it also suffers from bad explanation. You have 0 developed characters other than the main character somewhat - the guy you are playing as. So any plot twist is not really surprising. There are 7 endings 5 of which are "fake" endings and 2 are "true" (1 of which is cannon ofc, like in Metro). The 5 fake ones are not that big of a deal and make no sense until you see the requirements to get all 5. The other 2 endings are a lot better but their explanation is really bad. I understand the concept cause I read about it more but for most people it will be confusing and won't give you much fulfillment (No catharsis).


With all that said I do really like the game. Just make sure to remember this is a unique game with a lot of problems and a lot of good things. The mod support is astonishing and after trying the base game mods should be on your list to install if you found the game to be interesting but could use a bit of tweaking.

Played it when it was first released and now replayed it. The atmosphere and setting is as amazing now as it was back then, but I sort of wish I had actually modded the game this time around since there is a huge amount of flaws in the game so I recommend actually starting with a modded playthrough (especially if you have played it before as I had)

My main gripe is with the weapons and how accurate (or non accurate rather they are). It makes the weapons feel horrendous to handle and almost makes the game look like a parody at times. You can aim straight at someones head from a few meters away and still your bullets will fly all over the place. It does get better as you get better weapons but it still makes for a horrendous gameplay experience at many times that almost kills the game for me. It honestly feels like an RPG dice roll when you shoot someone and hope your bullet will go straight instead of just fly at an angle. I guess the "RPG" feeling of things being random and more stat based with bigger sense of progression of the weapons is the intention but for me it really hurt the experience a lot. You put your crosshair bullseye on someones head and then you have to pray for a good dice roll and a straight bullet every time you pull the trigger. 

For a good part of the game I actually thought the enemies where bullet sponges since straight headshoots did not seem to kill them (and I played on highest master diff), but it was only later that I really saw that the reason my headshots did not kill the enemies where that the actual bullets fly all over the place and are not straight. You often have to fire about 3-10 bullet straight at someones head if you are not in complete close quarters to be sure one lands a hit and kills the enemy. It makes for a horrible gameplay experience. 

I would rather have realistic accurate guns and then make things more difficult in other ways (not being able to just spam bandages and medkits and not being able to save whenever etc). I would assume these are things that mods fix. 

Another problem with the combat is that you often don't feel like there is any visual feedback as when you hit someone, sometimes the enemy react but more often you just feel like you are shooting a paperdoll until it falls over.

Also the sound effects are completely horrendous in many places (something I must think mods fix also)

Lastly enemies keep respawning in areas way too fast. Again making the grounded realistic feeling of game fall apart at times.

I really recommend the game for the setting and atmosphere, but do consider modding for the really bad/broken parts.

Unlike previous ordinary FPS, this cult classic game gets you into a zone living by itself thanks to a smart ecosystem process (entitled A-life system). Don't try to kill everyone in a room then get into the next room : Stalker has not been designed that way.

If you start the game for the first time, from now on, the zone becomes everything to you. You will meet there anomalies, mutants, and men. You can make friends or enemies. If you look closely, you may find valuable artefacts. And between them, the space : various apocalyptic atmospheres await for you, either conveyed through immersive landscapes or compelling musics.

This whole survival experience, loosely based on the eponymous novel by the Strugatsky brothers and its movie adaptation by Andrey Tarkovsky, follows a story surrounding the infamous nuclear plant of Chornobyl.

In one sentence this is "An equipment based RPG shooter, with a creepy atmosphere in a post Soviet apocalyptic environment".

The game has a bad opening but if you can get past the first 30 ish minutes it becomes a tense shooter with great moments, some that were scary but not in a cheap way.

If anyone reads this here are some tips to get started.
1. Play on veteran or master difficulty- on easy mode all the enemies are bullet sponges but on hard they deal more/take more. Much better way to play plus you'll learn quickly why cover and ammo conservation matter.
2. the pistols in the beginning suck. take it slow until you get better weapons.
3. You dont need to take every gun or thing and sell it as money is not that hard to grind. 
4. Be smart about what you are carrying. You can store spare equipment in blue chests near traders ( of which there are few in the game) but try to be aware of how much you are carrying.
5.Flashlight is bound to "L", night vision ( once you get armor that has it) is set to "N". Change ammo type is set to "Y". There is also a keybind to change fire mode from semi auto to single shot, and also for some rifles from bullets to the attached grenade launcher.
6. There is no thirst mechanic but there is hunger- eat some food every day to be healthy. You can drink energy drinks to restore stamina though.
7. There is no way (even with console commands) to bring people back to life when dead. If they die, thats how life is in the zone.
8. Use F6 to quick save and F7 to quick load. Use this often. Also make occasional saves as the game can crash, seemingly randomly.
9. There are no 1 of a kind artifacts, but some are incredibly rare.
10. Explore the environment, there is a lot hiding for you to find.

Many moons ago in 2003 I stumbled upon a trailer for a game called S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Oblivion Lost. After watching said trailer, I quickly became obsessed with the game. I wanted to learn everything I could about it. I searched high and low across the internet for every bit of information I could uncover. Eventually I found the developers forums (GSC) and that became my second home while I awaited its release. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oqQt-C6KB_8&list=PLAl2CYaVBm6BBV1PbLqoVTbqchC9tHiaz&index=15&t=67s 

I remember at the time I was playing Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind, With it I fell in love with non-linear open world 1st/3rd person games with RPG elements and how much I could get immersed in virtual worlds. I am all for fantasy settings don't get me wrong, but there is nothing more terrifying than reality. (With a spin of fiction of course, alternate reality if you will) The abandoned urban/industrial locations in S.T.A.L.K.E.R. were more my cup of tea. That in itself made me very excited to play it. I couldn't wait to get lost in its world. 

While I waited though I researched about the nuclear disaster at Chernobyl in April 1986, it was mixed emotions for me. I was sad/amazed/intrigued. Sad for all of those people who lost their lives because of this. Nothing but respect for the liquidators and anyone involved in the initial cleanup. Those people are heroes and deserve nothing less. Amazed that this game had some real history in its background story. Even if it is incredibly embellished (mutants, anomalies, artifacts etc etc.), you have to admit it makes for an interesting premise to a story. Finally, Intrigued on what these game developers had in store for the players to experience, without making a mockery of those who had lost their lives in this tragedy. The game also borrows elements from "Roadside Picnic" by Boris and Arkady Strugatsky and the 1979  Andrei Tarkovsky film "Stalker". If you haven't heard or checked them out yet, they are most definitely worth it. Masterpieces in their own right.

Well turns out it was a long wait lol, game finally arrived in March 2007. It was no longer Oblivion Lost, it was now called Shadow of Chernobyl. Which was a welcomed change imo, what was not a welcomed change was the amount of content/features that were removed from the game. Vehicles, locations/maps made smaller and simpler, monsters/mutants, superior lighting from old alpha builds among many other things had been removed it was rather disappointing to say the least. The survival aspect of the game took a huge hit, leaving many in the community confused as to what happened during development. GSC Game World regardless of all the missing features still delivered a good game and it was well received by critics as well. 

The game at release had performance issues and bugs that required some official patches + plus community fixes. Once that happened it was clear that S.T.A.L.K.E.R. - Shadow of Chernobyl was a game ahead of its time. In a league all its own and a true gem in the PC gaming world. The atmosphere takes front row seat in this game it is almost like another character in the game. Such believable atmosphere it is downright amazing, it keeps you on the edge of your chair as you play. 

[u]Pros[/u]:
- Incredible atmosphere!
- Impressive use of lighting and shadows, 
- Cloud shadows that shift as day/night cycles progress. 
- None stylized (photo based) textures (realism), Replicating the rust and decay feel.
- Great cut-scenes that hold up even by today's standards. 
- Plenty of side quests 
- Exploring is encouraged to find secret stashes scattered throughout the world to find loot, weapons, ammo, suits and artifacts. Artifacts can be placed on your belt to grant the player abilities like resistance to radiation, increase weight limit etc. Some interesting combinations that can be made with the multitude of artifacts available in the game. 
- The games AI can be quite challenging because they adapt/react/flank/take cover depending on your approach. This adds to the games replayability immensely, if its one thing I have learned playing this game is that when it comes to killing the AI is that no playthrough is ever the same. Never. They are very unpredictable lets put it that way.
- Trading system with merchants and other friendly AI characters
- "The Zone" is alive even when you are not in the same vicinity, AI will be fighting mutants and/or other factions (Bandits, Duty, Freedom, Loners, Military, Mercs, Ecologists & Monolith) All fight among themselves.

Besides all the bells and whistles the story is incredibly engaging and keeps you interested throughout. Without too many spoilers (I am sure most people reading this have already played this but still) You play as "Marked One" an amnesiac trying to retrace his steps, he is then set on a mission to the heart of "The Zone" (term used to refer to the 30 kilometer Chernobyl Exclusion Zone, established after the accident.) to find a target and their whereabouts. Game also has multiple endings depending on the choices made by the player, 7 in total.

[U]Cons[/U]:
- Lots of "fetch" side quests (Surprise? lol)
- AI that can sometimes see you from "miles" away (vanilla)
- Some quest giving characters can die. (vanilla)

Just a heads up. Nothing game breaking but worth noting. Just like all games, it's not perfect. 

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
[B]Mods: (Updated 9/18/2022)[/B]

The modding scene for S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games is very much alive.

- ZRP (Zone Reclamation Project) (community fixes keeps vanilla intact)[url=http://www.metacognix.com/files/stlkrsoc] ZRP[/url]

[u]ZRP[/u] goes perfect in a first playthrough to have the best bug-free experience with the game. Once your done with your first playthrough consider modding the game. Shadow of Chernobyl has some incredible mods worth installing. Especially, if you are looking for cut content like mutants & vehicles, a new storyline, better visuals (Texture packs, Reshade, ENBs etc), more weapons & attachments, new side quests, improved enemy AI, realistic weapon damage & accuracy, free roam & ironman modes, new areas to explore & all 3 games (Shadow of Chernobyl, Clear Sky & Call of Pripyat) maps together in one & survival elements in the form of crafting, animated consumables, item repairing, cooking & base building. 

[u]Some of the mods I can recommend are:[/u]

[u][SoC Mods] [Classics][/u]
- Oblivion Lost
- Priboi Story
- L.U.R.K.
- OGSE (Old Good Stalker Evolution)
- AMK v1.4 
- ABC Inferno
- STALKER Soup
- Narodnaya Soljanka DMX 1.3.2 dkz02
- [b]Autumn Aurora 2 (Overall favorite SoC mod)[/b]

[u][Standalone] [Modern][/u]
- S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Lost Alpha DCE 
- Radiophobia 3
- Dead Air: Revolution 
- S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Anomaly (Monolith 64-bit engine + hundreds of addons)
- [b]S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: G.A.M.M.A. (Curated Anomaly Modpack 329 addons)[/b]

The list goes on really, just my humble recommendations on the ones I have tried. 

Clear Sky and Call of Pripyat are awesome games as well, worth checking out at least once. They also have great mods which I will not mention in this review. Worth noting is that many of the improvements seen in modern day STALKER mods couldn't have been possible without these two games. But I will say that there is something about Shadow of Chernobyl's allure and atmosphere that didn't carry over as well to the other two games. Out of all three games, Shadow of Chernobyl is by far still my favorite.

I don't claim to know everything about these games, because honestly I don't. I still discover new things about them every time I play them and new mods coming out all the time. They are gifts that just keep on giving. Thank goodness for Eastern European game developers & the passionate modding community for keeping this game alive!

STALKER is a game loosely inspired by a book called Roadside Picnic and a movie named Stalker. It is an open world survival / shooter game with a somewhat linear story. Although there are choices here and there and factions you can join, you don't have much consequences like modern games only ending is different. Which reminds me to say Stalker is a 2007 game.
You kill mutants, loot mercs, military, whoever is dead, old buildings, abondoned places, gather artifacts, use or sell them to get strong. Get quests and jobs to uncover the mystery you are in and also to survive. There is no level up or stat/skill system, you get stronger by items. And there are tons of items. You have to eat and sleep regularly and avoid hazards, find safe places to sleep or cover from strange zone events. World is alive, mutants, factions, hold bases, fight against each other, patrol etc. Reminds me of Fallout 3/New Vegas. 

First of All , ***I've played Stalker OGSE 0.693 Patch 2.10 Revised Fix2***. So the whole experience is different and I believe much better. That's why my playtime shows different because Ogse uses completely different installation/folder. It's not hard to install and you don't need to install anything else. It improves gameplay, graphics, everything at once. With ogse you can use your 2-3 year old desktop GPU to full extent. It does not make the game modern but definitely makes it better. (Compare screenshots) Adds many weapons, items, full maps, lots of quests that left out etc. ***Highly suggested.*** 

+++ Setting : Chernobyl after incident becomes a mysterious zone, anomalies, mutants, military and factions trapped in or just want to benefit from it. You are a neutral stalker trying to figure out your memory loss and certain near death experience. You can make friends and enemies alongside factions but the Zone is the real enemy to everyone. (or is it?) 
Artifacts and anomalies are tied together, both a danger and also rewards you. You can get resistance to damage, faster healing etc from them. Finding and picking good artifact combinations is important. 
Zone  is almost always dangerous, scary, keeps you on your toes. There are some parts of the game that is right out of a horror movie. Music and ambient sounds are perfect. 

++Gameplay: With Ogse, there are tons of weapons, weapon modifications, ammunition types, repair , vehicle driving etc. Every weapon beside pistols are satisfying, bombs, rockets are deadly to anyone. There are some issues that respawns occur at map transitions sometimes and is annoying but nothing you won't handle. 

+Technical : With ogse I encountered very few crashes with win10 latest, rtx 3080 and i6900k. It is somewhat cpu bound and not so multi-core friendly which i think why i have lower than expected frames but since this is an old game and a very big mod that re-writes the game its OK. 

++Music: Some music choices of Pripyat, Freedom base is so good, I had to mention it. Even though I don't understand the language, they are quite good. As far as I know most of them OGSE additions. 

With all that said, if you like this kind of post apocalyptic settings this is a good game. I spent lots of hours without getting bored. Controllers are annoying though. And dogs.

The Godfather of the Sandbox Survival. 

S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl is a Soviet Post-Apocalyptic Immersive Sim where you really only have one goal in mind: To adapt and survive the hostile and irradiated wasteland of the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone where everything from mutants, bandits, anomalies, military factions and the environment itself is trying to kill you.

Combat is particularly lethal; emphasizing on tactics and accuracy more than anything as firefights can go both ways. Resource management plays an integral part of the game so pick and choose wisely what you need and what you like to haul around. STALKER can be brutal and even unfair at times but that's almost kind of the point. You're handicapped by default. You're not a one-man-army, the fact you even made it this far is nothing short of a miracle.

S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Shadow of Chernobyl is a very enjoyable FPS game, with stellar atmosphere, an ominous soundtrack and variety of sounds that never quite become familiar whether you're a rookie in Cordon or an expert in the CNPP. I played the game with the Starter Pack 2019 modpack, and I gotta say, the game is incredible and ran about as good as a game this old is capable of given the engine GSC used. The modders on that pack squashed tons of bugs, basically anything game breaking you can consider gone, the only thing I noticed that was still an issue is a certain sniper wanting to dome a certain NPC you might wanna talk to about 60% through the story, but unlike vanilla, he at least can't shoot him until you've accepted the quest to kill said sniper. The graphics were updated but not taking away from the vanilla experience, as well, using Aurora mod I believe. The gunplay and difficulty on Master feels good, guys in armor are absolute tanks and given the modern plate carriers (and in this case an Exosuit) even one guy properly beefed up feels extremely lethal. The game really forces you into a cautious, methodical style of playing where you get used to the weight of your backpack, how far you can run in case of danger, sticking to darkness whenever possible, and always going for the head of anything man or mutant. Awareness and focus is required as the game doesn't hold your hand for anything and both the storyline and anything you want to do will involve agency on your part to a degree a lot of gamers might not like, but once I realized that I was actually king of my own decisions for once in a game it felt like a breath of fresh air. Wanna power through the storyline? Go right ahead, but I don't recommend it, although it has been done before. I really only did maybe 5 missions I didn't "have to do" for some rare artifacts and gear, most of my time was spent exploring the Zone and looting the many, many, many stashes in the world. That is where the real gear is, and as many times as you come up with arms full of junk you find something worth 50 junk stashes. I encourage anyone interested to give Shadow of Chernobyl a shot, as I always wanted to play this series and with the Starter Pack 2019 modpack it really is a wonderful experience, the gauntlet at the end is a real doozy, but just remember stalker, anything is possible in the Zone.

This game does a lot right but there are some key things that really suck about it. The Trader door glitch is so obnoxious. He's your main point person for missions in the beginning and his door glitches closed all the time. Very stupid and annoying. "Just install mods." Just shut up and give me a good game that isn't broken. The Trader also gives me missions that I then cannot complete because...I don't know why. "Bring over the tail of the psuedodog." Ok, so I go out and kill a dog and get the tail and bring to to the Trader and he doesn't acknowledge that I have it in my inventory. Why? I watched a lot of videos about this game and it always looked like something I would like, but no.

Update after 7 hours: Like most people, I returned to the game and I'm slowly making my way throught it. It's frustrating at times (often) but it's also rewarding and has great atmosphere.

Also, this is the jankiest game I've ever played. Some missions have the most random criteria for completion.

Every time I play this game I fluctuate between recommending and not recommending it. If you, like me, have wondered about this game for a long time, then give it a try. If you're just passing through, keep on strolling.

Final edit: I'm on the final level and I really cannot recommend this game to anyone. It is so bad. It's just bad. Every time I load a game now, all the enemies that I've already killed respawn, so they are behind me and kill me instantly. It's just a broken mess of a game. There's also just too many different kinds of ammo and too many different kinds of guns. Enemies that kill me from 100 feet away only have shotgun ammo on them and a shotgun when I loot them. For the player, shotguns are only viable when you're close enough to kiss an enemy. The atmosphere and some, only some, of the gunfights are great, but everything else is hopelessly bad. I'm done before I complete it.

This game, in my opinion is possibly the best FPSRPGs made to date. Its aged very well, the ragdoll physics and dynamic lighting were ahead of there time. The atomsphere and soundtrack immerse the player in a creepy dsytopian hellscape, leaving the player unable to relax except for a view brief rests in safe zones.

This loose adaption of Arkady and Boris Strugatsky's Novel Roadside Picnic and Andrei Tarkovs Film  STALKER does justice to the source material whilst still feeling exciting and unpredictable. STALKER takes the themes from Roadside Picnic, the tone of STALKER and sets it all in an  creepy, lonely exclusion Zone not created by an alien visitation, as in the Strugatsky brothers novel but created by a 'Manmade Disaster'.

This game is like black coffee, bitter and disgusting at first but then you start to get a taste for it. 


Definitely a cult classic. Not for everyone. Vanilla is graphically dated, and you WILL run into bugs. 
Though, I like to play this when I want to experience Escape From Tarkov atmosphere w/o playing Escape from Tarkov because sometimes I like to be nice to myself and not feel sad.

Great atmospheric Slavic FPS. It is a little dated though in certain gameplay aspects, and some annoyances like sluggish weapon draw speeds and enemies spawning behind you or right in front of you. Ambient sounds become repetitive after a while. There is lots of walking and backtracking through places. Still, the game has held up well. I presume this is the same for the other two installments in the series.

Steam shows played time as 6 hours at the time of this review but I have owned a physical copy since release and have spent at least a couple hundred hours playing. I consider this game to be among the elite in all of PC gaming. Its a must play along with other seminal titles like; Doom, Quake, Starcraft etc., etc. The gun play is tight, the atmosphere is unique and expertly crafted, the world is fantastic while being completely believable, and the story is above average. If you have never played, don't play it with mods first and don't hesitate, just play it!

At first, I saw this game as an ugly, buggy mess. The world itself too sparse and guns have little to no accuracy. 

However, after four hours in and learning the gameplay mechanics, I found this is one of the most immersive shooters I've ever played. 

For people who are new to the series, the best way to describe S.T.A.L.K.E.R, it is a shooter x survival horror x rpg. Managing ammo, guns and medkits. (Ammo weighs you down in this game), creates a unique immersive experience you will not feel in today's modern shooters.

While the graphics and some of the bugs will put you off at first (mods help FYI), give it a good try and you'll find the game an absolute gem to play.

(I originally wrote this as a Sgt Pepper's Lonely Heart's Club Band review but I ended up saying a bunch of stuff about the game) 

I feel like a lot of the praise around the Beatles lies more on their influence than on the music on its own. It would obviously be foolish to ignore the historical significance that they have but at a certain point, it feels a bit misleading, especially when a lot of the reviews that praise albums emphasize how some of the songs are forgettable or even bad, before giving them a 10/10 score because it "flows well". I don't wish to look down on anyone's perspective and blindly call the band overrated but the urge is still there. Because it's easy to look at these reviews and say that some people are deluding themselves into liking something that has maybe aged badly, but that's really stupid. I think that it's more interesting to try to find out why people react like this. 

S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Shadow of Chernobyl is a Ukrainian horror fps from the 2000s. It's a game with a great atmosphere and an interesting story. It's also an extremely infuriating experience because of the great presence of bugs, crashes, and mistakes, and because of the honest to god awful combat. It's a piece of media that has evident, glaring, game-breaking flaws, but that people still hold in extremely high regard. People still consider it one of the best. Yet it feels wrong to call a game a masterpiece when there is so much wrong with it, it's contradictory. A funny example of this logic is that, when it was released, critics argued that the intense flaws of the game were purposeful. They apparently reflected in a deep metaphorical way the reality of Ukraine's history. I'm pretty sure that this was later disproven but it shows how people try to justify their immense appreciation for a certain thing. And when you run out of ways to describe your genuine love, you end up saying shit like: "I like the vibes ig". 

I think that it's a bit sad that people have the need to justify their subjective feelings for a subjective thing. Obviously, being able to defend your point of view in a reasonable way is important but some things are beyond that. Like why are apples better than pears, why is the last of us 2 better than the first one, why is S.T.A.L.K.E.R not worth playing, why is Sgt. Pepper's mid? There are points where these explanations, these feelings, transcend words. You like/hate a certain thing because you like/hate it, because it resonates with you in a unique way, because you experienced it at the right time at the right place, because it reminds you of something personal to you, or just because. I love S.T.A.L.K.E.R and I have no idea why, and even if I can't get behind the Sgt. Pepper's hype, I still respect it.

Overrated schet, letterbile incoming:

All this game has going for it is atmosphere and soundtrack, and, admittedly, those are fantastic. But everything else is indefensibly shit.

Let's start with the basics; yeah, this game is broken. I don't understand why these other reviews mention easy fixes online, when I've had to scour the internet for such basic issues as lowering the unbearable head bobbing and weapon balance. Of course, there are many large mods that fix all those problems, but they're effectively different games, and only a few actually let you play the original game's story, and those few force terrible graphic and music changes. 

But I digress. Even after fixing these options as much as I could, the game is still a boring, confused mess of fetch quests and terrible combat. Terrible, terrible combat in which you spend most of your time peaking behind walls and cinder blocks, shooting people 5 miles away from you who are just standing completely still at the side of a tree or in the middle of the field. After finally winning a battle by waiting by various corners for an enemy to show themselves, I didn't only not feel any satisfaction, I instead lost all my immersion because my amnesiac newbie stalker just slaughterer an entire fucking military compound and got away, too. So much for the dark, grim, alien world of the zone where even the best barely get by. 

And this stratagem of just peaking around a corner for half an hour isn't unwarrented, as it is the only strategy possible. Running straight at the enemy and trying to dodge around is a death sentence. Stealth is literally non-existent, so you can only hide in a building or a corner and shoot at foes when they get close. Where is the deep, stressful combat I've heard so much about? I enjoyed fallout 3's combat more than this. At least that game has a decent amount of different weapons, this game has 6 at the most when nearly every one is a thinly-veiled reskin of another. 

The AI is not terrible, not good, and certainly not fun. Sometimes it likes to sit behind cover for the majority of the fight, occasionaly silently moving to a different position across the battlefield and instantly blowing my head off with an ak47 from miles away because I decided to peak up and try to kill one of the other 10 bandits playing a DS behind a helicopter for the last 5 minutes. Occasionally enemies will stand in a field or move towards the player, either deleting you the second you step out of cover, or completely ignoring you. Needless to say, combat is not enjoyable in the slightest. I can't even be bothered to mention the incredible lack of enemy variety. Fighting mutants is actually fun, but they're so rare it's certainly not enough to counteract the vast, vast majority of enemies being shit. 

Story is cool. But the actual missions being such repetitive borefest fetch quests completelt destroys any hope of it carrying the game. You'll spend pretty most all your time walking around similar enviroments doing nothing, and the rest in the shit combat. There's more to write but I can't be asked, maybe I'll add more later

It's okay, not terrible, just not my thing, I heard so much about this game and thought it was going to be insane but it's actually kind of a slog at times. First third of the game had my attention and interest, second third I nearly dropped it just out of boredom of walking around everywhere, final third of the game I was in full sunk cost fallacy mode (So much combat oh my god the last three hours of the game is just shooting and shooting), "I already put 15 hours in I guess I have to finish it". It was an alright experience and it certainly had its moments but the game as a whole is a lot of just walking around an interesting landscape and world. Exploration is rarely* rewarded as stashes and hidden caches don't have loot in them unless you've found the coordinates to them on a body so that was a bit of a frustrating realization. Other than that the game's pretty buggy, had to play with a bunch of stability mods and even then it crashed fairly often, but it has aged quite well graphically, music and sfx are decent too, I can see why it's beloved by so many people but I guess I just ain't one of them. I'd say only grab it if you are going in pretty blind, if you knew anything about it going in or had high expectations like me you'll probably be disappointed. Here's a review from someone that knows a little more what they're talking about: https://youtu.be/xTq4ibgVof8

This game is so "ahead of it's time", objectively by today's "standards". I played through each of the games for the first time years after they were released. 'Shadow of Chernobyl' is still my favorite, it even warranted a 2nd playthrough from me, which I hardly do for any game. Usually once I "beat" a game, I feel like I got closure and I don't feel the need to revisit it any time soon. This game is so good, that my 2nd playthrough felt independently original to the 1st one. At certain moments, I may have remembered certain parts of the map or enemy spawn areas, outside of that it felt like a completely different experience. 

Truly a masterpiece, I know people love Call of Pripyat and Anamoly mods but personally I still feel like this is the best. This is my favorite S.T.A.L.K.E.R. experience I've had. I did wish on my 2nd playthrough that there was gun modding or repairing, as in Call of Pripyat or mods. However, part of me still enjoys that I had to meticulously plan out and physically move guns and ammo. In preparation for when guns ran out of durability in certain fights or areas. The guns become decreasingly inaccurate as the durability wears down. 

For example, saving a full durability sniper and rounds for an important fight feels extra rewarding to me. As compared to just being able to repair any gun at will. If you enjoy 'story' driven shooters, this game is cream of the crop in my opinion. Especially if you're into post-apocalyptic settings and exclusion zones. If you end up enjoying it then there is at least 1 worthwhile playthrough of 'Clear Sky' and 'Call of Pripyat' as well. They are all three distinctly different in their own ways, this one still being my favorite.

S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl is a 2007 FPS with survival & horror mechanics, but the game also features many RPG elements. the player does not gain additional abilities or statistics like most RPGs but is instead allowed to attach artifacts which can increase or decrease player attributes. there are a large number of items in the game, so the player has customization choices which are constrained primarily by how much exploring they do. the game world is not a true open world, but rather 18 different maps separated by loading screens as you pass through small passageways. it's a pretty neat way to make it seem like a giant open map, especially for it's time. other than a couple technical issues like a few too many bugs, the overall game design is great and they do a really good job capturing the bleakness of a post-apocalyptic setting.

Damn good atmosphere and solid gameplay for it's time. The scavenging aspect is a lot different to other open fps games most people are familiar with so you can't go into every situation guns blazing or you'll end up dead or with minimal resources. I would recommend playing on master as this only heightens the damage you give and take but doesn't change the AI in any noticeable way.

However, there are bugs and it can sometimes crash on modern machines unfortunately so I would recommend using something like the zone reclamation project or complete mod for a smoother experience as either of them can iron out the common issues and crashes.

[spoiler]It does drop off a tad with the larger gunfights particularly in and around the brain scorcher as well as within the chernobyl power plant. Just make sure to be fully prepped and save often. Though the true ending when going through the portals is more manageable.[spoiler]

I am a 50 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started stalker and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So i decided to make a Steam account and download this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, looked at the menu, but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

A chef's kiss on the cosmic horror/apocalyptic video game genre.

DISCLAIMER: I did play through the game with the Zone Reclamation Project, which mostly just makes the game more stable and less buggy, with a few QoL upgrades. As such, you may want to take everything I say with a grain of salt, though 95% of my experience should've still been the same as a vanilla player. This review will also mainly be comparing it against it's fellow games in the series instead of overall.

Many people claim that Shadow of Chernobyl, despite being the first in the series, is still the best of the main trilogy. While it is certainly worth playing if only for the story alone, I must say that I don't see it. This entry has some very notable strengths over the others, but overall? It definitely has aged the worst in my opinion.

Strengths -
Freedom (not the faction): This game definitely treats you as if you were a total newcomer to the zone, learning about it more and more as you progress, and starting with absolutely horrendous equipment that you will need to replace ASAP if you wish to not struggle against even dogs and bandits. To enhance this effect, (and make it even more challenging) it gives you very little guidance, but also very little restrictions. From the start of the game, you can effectively go anywhere you want, and for better or worse, you can even ignore the entire story, with the game reacting appropriately if you do. This is very different from the other two games, where you both start with somewhat decent equipment, an obvious main goal, and a clear cut path of progression.

Better storytelling: Kinda going with the above point, this story definitely has a stronger mystery bent than the other 2 games, and I really like the breadcrumb trail you are given as you go through the game and get closer to your objective. You really have a lot of side objectives you can do to understand more about who you are and what you're doing, or barrel on ahead regardless of consequences.

Honestly... That's basically all I can think of that it has other it's brothers.

Weaknesses -
Worst gameplay in general: In the base game, there is a lot of stuff lacking that the other games in the series innovated with. Without mods, there is no way to repair your guns or armor (aside from a glitch that only affects armor) making EVERYTHING in the game on borrowed time. That unique gun or armor you just found? There will come a time that you simply cannot use it anymore. Weapon and armor mods are also not present, so it's not like you can even really get attached to your equipment that much anyway, so I guess that helps with the aforementioned problem I guess? Artifacts are just kinda laying there on the ground for you to pick up, or rolling on the ground. No detectors or anything needed, and they don't respawn, so their is a finite number to be found at any time. On the other hand, I guess I like the way artifacts affect you when worn in this game, with it not just being a binary "wear this good artifact with this rad-reducer one for a flat buff."

AI is dumber: AI is not that impressive in this game compared to it's sequels. Both NPC and mutant patrols rarely actually wander anywhere, and they remain static far more in this game, and it got to the point where I could literally predict the spawns in certain areas after visiting them enough times. (Fun fact, every time you enter Agroprom, a blind dog pack will ALWAYS spawn in the railway tunnel and usually attack the nearby stalker camp, no matter how long it's been since you last went there)

Factions are basically non-existent: There is no way to meaningfully join or side with any of the factions in this game, and for that matter, bandits, military, and mercs are always hostile to you, with no other characterization. The only real "choice" to be made in regards to factions I can remember was helping or destroying Skull's squad, and this basically either kills Freedom entirely or just removes a single squad from the game respectively. Obviously for your own enjoyment you can help Dutyers and kill Freedomers or vice versa if you wish, but there is no real reason to do this, as there is no progression or ranks to work towards, and no one will acknowledge your actions, even should you completely wipe out their hated enemies. And because squads will almost never move from their positions, these two giant factions more or less become static monoliths in their given locations. Apparently via a borderline glitch via sequence breaking you can "join" freedom specifically, but it's obvious the game was not planned around it.

Fairly Weak Mid-Late Game: The game get's a little droll after the early game, mainly because there is only like 3 meaningful traders and quest givers in the ENTIRE game:
Sidorovich, who you basically ignore after the early game because he is so far away from the main maps. (and there is no fast travel in this game without mods)
Barkeep, who will likely be your main trader and questgiver for the majority of the game due to his centralized location, large quest selection, and good stock as you progress through the game.
Professor Sakharov, who basically only deals in science stuff and therefore is the most situational of the bunch.
Unfortunately there is little else to works towards outside of this and the story, because artifact hunting is not really something you have to build and plan for due to the way they are found in this game, hunting mutants is really only useful when it comes to doing missions for Sakharov, and the game in general becomes a brutal gauntlet against Mercs and Monolith after a certain point, specifically after you reach the Red Forest and go into Pripyat. Seriously, the end game of this game is probably one of the most unforgiving slogs in any game I have played. The game has absolutely no chill as it throws literally 100+ guys at you with the best equipment they have to offer, with it basically becoming one giant point of no return.
As for the traders/quest givers, there ARE technically more for the factions, but there is almost no reason to actually talk to any of the faction leaders or their specific traders because their stock tends to be crap and their (infinitely respawning) missions are even more basic and bland, almost always being "go here, kill these guys, come back." Riveting. Speaking of...

Crap side missions: Almost all side missions in this game are infinite basic and repeatable tasks that involve just going somewhere and killing everything there 90% of the time. The only exceptions are the main guys I listed above, but even then their missions are little better, usually just being fetch quests when they aren't generic destroy missions.

Kind of short: Despite me dragging my feet and spending far more time than I should have just doing side missions and stockpiling money I didn't need,  I was still able to finish the whole game in slightly under 30 hours despite it's freeform nature. If you care little for the side missions and know what to do, you could probably finish the whole thing while still doing almost everything the game has to offer in around 15 hours. While the other games in the series are arguably even shorter, they make up for it in replayability. The lack of any meaningful choices to make (specifically in reference to factions) makes it so that there is honestly little replayability in this game, as every playthrough will more or less play out the same way, and despite how many endings their are, almost every ending can be achieved in a single playthrough if you really go out of your way to do so and know what to do.

Despite all this, I still recommend this title solely because it's still STALKER, and also the fact that's it's story is arguably the most important to understanding the setting as a whole. The unique direction of the story and presentation alone is probably worth at least giving it a shot, but I will not sugarcoat that I believe that from a gameplay perspective, this game is indisputably the weakest of the bunch.

STALKER: SoC has a cool setting, strange design choices and is full of jank. I do not advice to play the vanilla version of the game since the gunplay is in such a broken state. I'd recommend STALKER:SoC to players who are patient and ready to mod the game.

pros
++ great atmosphere and setting
++ some memorable moments
+ Stalker has a different feel compared to Metro despite many similarities. especially when it comes to open world vs solid, but linear campaign
+ good story
+ old, but weirdly charming graphics
+ many mods

cons
-- gunplay has many problems:
1. body hits hardly do any damage at all. only headshots are worth it and it still takes too many of them. especially when enemies are wearing full armour
2. weapons, especially the early ones, are hilariously lacking in both strength and accuracy. this is likely why many players rage quit during the first mission and never touch this game again
3. most weapons give you a headshot damage boost, but there is a 'time_to_aim' delay that you have to wait in order for it to kick in again. this means that spraying the enemy in full auto is basically useless, forcing you to wait for some time for the next headshot. you can mod this out or find a mod that does it for you. this feature is terrible on every level
4. enemies hardly stagger when hit. one of the biggest signs of a good gunplay is that enemies stagger when hit. it hardly happens in this game. particularily non-human enemies seem to lack any damage in-take animations. humans do stagger somewhat when the head is hit, but not for long and you have to wait for your damage boost anyway.
5. for a game that requires you to aim for the head, the crosshair is surprisingly ****. too big and hardly visible during fire fights
- personally I don't like too many survival elements in shooters. however, this might be a pro for other players
- last mission throws balancing completely out of the window. devs must have been trolling us

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
STALKER: SoC has many things going for it. There is a reason why STALKER: SoC still is beloved by many fans around the world and why modders have created hundreds of mods. Still, the gunplay has so many issues that I only recommend the game to players who plan to mod the game in some ways. I would have enjoyed my playthrough much more if I did.

Information:
the difficulty level is confusing. most players will tell you to play on the highest difficulty level since both the player and the enemies will die faster compared to lower difficulty levels. Others have called this a myth. I don't know what is correct, but I do encourage you to do some research on that before starting a new campaign.

Tweaks:
I had to limit my FPS in the nvidia inspector since the game ran on 2000+ FPS and no in-game settings allowed me to lower it.

1. you're not playing doom, you're not a badass guy killing demons with your fist. you are a nobody with nothing and you don't know where tf you are and what to do. so don't expect much when you just started playing.

S.T.A.L.K.E.R. 1 is an EXTREMELY slow burn. I think most players who try this game might outright hate it at the start or just don't understand it (like I did). 

In the opening hours of Stalker, you die almost instantly to everything. Bandits, mutants, anomaly's, zones of radiation will all kill you over and over again as you start to learn the world and how it ticks. Your weapons are especially bad, using just a measly pistol or a sawn-off shotgun if you can find one. They're inaccurate and don't do much damage unless you go for head shots. You have very few resources to heal or protect yourself from the elements early on so you might stumble into a hazardous area and then die because you didn't have the resources to stop the damage.

What I'm getting at here is that Stalker does not care what happens to you. It doesn't care if you die or if you live, it doesn't care if you have no bandages on you to save yourself from bleeding to death in that small firefight you just barely survived, and it doesn't care what you think of it's harsh world. It's world is gonna exist, with or without you.

This is all by design, because Stalker at it's core is trying to immerse you in it's unforgiving world. It's trying to make you feel like you're really just barely scraping by (especially in the opening hours). Living by the skin of your teeth, exploring and discovering strange oddities and soaking in the atmosphere is the name of the game.

If any of this sounds interesting to you, I recommend trying the game out. It's a game that doesn't hold your hand, for better or for worse. It's definitely not a game that's for everyone, however there is something really special about the world of Stalker I find appealing and despite it's flaws, I enjoyed it.

Don’t get me wrong, this game is amazing. The atmosphere is incredible with the occasional distant screaming and gun fire along with the low rumbling and beeping to inform you of nearby anomalies, and the dynamic weather and day/night cycle can up the tension and suspense. But holy shit the amount of backtracking you do in this game is insane. There were so many times I got a quest from the a guy with the objective located halfway across the map, spend up to fifteen minutes to get to the quest, just to have to spend fifteen minutes again running back to the guy to collect my reward, just to get 1000 rubles and a grenade. The game is an atmospheric masterpiece, but the backtracking could turn even the most sane person into an Arkham asylum inmate.

Would recommend installing the ZRP mod alongside the game to fix some bugs that were never fixed, and any cheats if you so desire (ZRP comes with a modifier tool so elements of the game can be changed to your liking), if this is the first time playing stalker watch some beginners guides as going into the game blind is a really bad idea because of the amount of content that is easy to miss and the many mistakes that could be made during the game that can degrade the experience. The start is quite slow but it gets better as you play through just make sure that you're going well equipped for each main mission as the game gets difficult quickly.

Easily one of the best post-apocalyptic open-world experiences of all time. Even though I prefer Fallout NV in terms of writing and story telling, no game comes close to the atmosphere of SoC. This game scares me. It makes me stressed and anxious. In STALKER I'm always looking over my shoulder, trying to avoid the inevitable jump scare of a pack of dogs I didn't notice surrounding me. Inside the different buildings and facilities that feeling of being watched, or being **stalked** on might say, is intensified by 1000x. Horror games don't even compare to the shear terror of being almost out of amo and stuck in a dark, haunted lab in SoC.

The graphics might be ugly to some, but I find that they hold up pretty well. SoC is graphically consistent, and its environments are very well designed. Open spaces invoke a dreadful sense of isolation and vulnerability, while interiors are claustrophobic and uncomfortable.

While the human enemies are quite boring, this game's enemy design really shines in the mutants. All of them freak me out, and even the zombies manage to be uniquely unnerving.

STALKER's factions are based (loosely) on the real world factions of the Russian civil war. Freedom represent the Greens and Blacks, the former being non-aligned guerrillas and the latter being Makhnovian anarchists in Ukraine. Duty, on the other hand, is representative of the old Soviet mentality. They're strongly hierarchical, militaristic, and legalistic, but they fight to tame the chaos of the zone and protect the people living in it. The ecologists, military, and monolith exist as well, but they don't really have philosophies as each are beholden to larger organizations or ideas. The military exists to control the people in the zone arbitrarily at the request of an outside government, the ecologists simply want to research the zone regardless of politics, and monolith are a cult of brain fried soldiers and stalkers. Personally I find the factions interesting and an interesting tie in to Ukrainian history, but there are very few ways you can interact with them in game and most of their related quests are boring and pointless.

I've heard a lot of people online say that mods are basically a prerequisite to enjoy this game. They aren't. As of this review, all my hours are max difficulty vanilla. 

While there are quite a lot of crazy glitches you'll encounter, I strongly recommend giving the vanilla experience a try. The SOC experience hasn't been replicated to this day and won't be in the future. It might be dated, strange, and poorly balanced, but that's what makes it so worthwhile. 

It's sad that STALKER 2 is a massive cash grab with absurdly priced preorder bundles, preorder exclusive story content, devs that wanted to add NFTs to the game, and a scrapped Russian voice over the devs removed even after selling preorders for over a year under the pretense that there would be a Russian dub. Save your money and just buy the original.

Despite the handful of bugs I encountered during my first vanilla playthrough, I really enjoyed STALKER. Traversing the wasteland and picking through the loot of my fallen enemies never got old. To me, it really felt like I was playing a single-player Escape from Tarkov, and honestly I think I wish Tarkov played more like this game! The firefights with the AI were surprisingly challenging even though I played on the normal difficulty, which meant that the gunplay never got boring, I can't count how many times I was engaged with multiple enemies, only to get blitzed and overwhelmed or flanked from another angle. The faction AI was really exciting to observe too, STALKERS roaming the land on their own journeys, mutants terrorizing hostile mercenaries, and skirmishes over territory between different factions. The main story was enjoyable and I never felt like I had to grind to progress, although the option to do so was always present. There is no leveling system, just loot to equip, and no barriers to equipping any loot at anytime other than limited loadout slots, which made adapting and experimenting on the fly very rewarding. Finally the atmosphere was splendid. The visuals and sound and narrative context had me completely immersed on many occasions. Working my way through labyrinthine underground facilities not knowing what and when something or someone would attack had my heart beating a little faster than usual. 

Overall, despite some rough patches and bugs, I highly recommend this game to newcomers. This game has timeless value.

S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl is a product of a neverending development cycle that was basically forced to be released by a publisher. The game was reworked, rebuild and restarted numerous times, with a bunch of cut content still being left inside the game's code and restored by the community. So it's basically a miracle that this game got released and it's actually pretty good. It is an Eastern European FPS, so it's barely functional on a basic level, but it's very atmospheric and endearing even in it's broken state.

The story of STALKER takes place in the Exclusion Zone near Chernobyl Atomic Electric Station where the catastrophic meltdown of 1986 occured. The zone spreads for hundreds of kilometeres outside of Pripyat and holds a lot of secrets and unexplainable phenomena. There are anomalies that change gravity or create energy blasts out of nowhere, strange and aggressive creatures that defy the laws of nature, and artifacts of unknown origins that give magical abilities to the ones that hold them. The setup for the plot is classic RPG stuff, you play as unknown and unnamed protagonist that suffers from amnesia. The only thing he has: a PDA with a single instruction to kill someone named Strelok. The only defining feature, the tatoo on his forearm that reads S.T.A.L.K.E.R. So the name that our character gets is the Marked One. As our protagonist we need to figure out who we are, who is Strelok, and solve the mystery of the Zone.
The story is decent, it holds you enough with it's mysteries and the setting to be interesting. The last few plot twists however were always too much for me. For a world as adark and unsettling as the Zone having M.Night Shyamalan twists at the end kind of cheapens the experience.

The graphics and technical performance of the game are an issue. The game is build from sticks and stones and prayers of it's developers to hold it all together on a budget of two sandwiches and a bottle of cheap vodka. The game looks fine, but definitely dated. But the graphics themselves are not the issue, it's everything around it. The game crashes a lot, sometimes there are bugs with post-processing that are fixed by rebooting the game, physics that were definitely impressive for the time, constantly freakout, causing stuff to fly around. Some missions can get bugged and become unasccessible, sometimes there are objectives markers that are still hang around on the map after completion. The AI acts like a complete idiot, sometimes blocking path or not reacting to neccesary triggers, or worse, repeating them everytime you are close. The game is better right now, compared to it's initial release, but that because of patches that were applied after release, which basically another layer of duct tape on top of cracks. Thankfully the game has passionate community that always has new mods and all sorts of stuff to make experience better (or worse).

The gameplay of STALKER is an FPS/RPG hybrid. You have to explore the open world of the Zone, complete quests, find new loot and supplies to survive, and fight mutants and enemy Stalkers. The Zone is split in several different locations with it's own factions controlling them, their own anomalies that spawn new artifacts, and their own secret stashes. By completing quests you earn money and sometimes supplies like food, medkits and bandages. You need to upgrade your gear before heading into a new location, since regular leather jacket won't cut it against high-caliber weapons and anomalies that literally split reality apart. And there is a lot of cool gear. Getting that new shiny gun or a new costume with higher defence stats are always motivation to get better for a new location. And also you can quip artifacts for their unique abilities. Some artifacts increase your resistances, increase your health or stamina, but most of them come with certain downsides, like contatly spewing radiation, so exposing yourslef to them is basically death, or lowering your resistance to certain effects. But with a right set of artifacts the game can be broken in your favor. The shooting is okay, but at the beginning with basic weapons it can be tough, since they don't o much damage and have horrible accuracy, but getting first decent weapon is a huge step up, and it's somewhat smooth sailing from there. Unfortunately, like I mentioned, the AI can be a bit of an idiot. Enemies have some semblance of self-preservation with getting into cover and avoinding grenades, sometimes they can even flank you. But most of the time they have horrible aim and can even just stand in one place waiting to get shot in the head. One time a whole squad of monolith idiots just went one by one throgh the door where I just shot them one by one. The only reason enemies are a threat is by their sheer numbers. They don't have a good aim, but sometimes they can hit and if there is a lot of them, they can shred you pretty quick. The combat with mutants is just trying to stay away from them. Most of them are melee, with exception of psychic mutatnts like poltergeist and controller. But those guys are a rarity and only appear in underground laboratories. 

But the game is really good, for a project that was restarted and rebuild multiple times. it's janky, it's even broken sometimes, but such is the life in the Zone. if you want to have an alternative post-apocalyptic experinece in irradiated wasteland with a more of a harcore flair to it, STALKER is really good. It's setting is memorable and melancholic, it's horrifying, and sometimes comforting. It can be infuriating, but when you get into it, youcan't stop. Good hunting, Stalker, and good luck out there.

Story:

Somewhat confusing at first as your character has amnesia and the story takes a while to speed up, only until the last areas of the game does it become more involved, with some ambitious ideas. The ending(s) are interesting but can come off as disappointing/anti-climactic, although a secret ending (The True Ending) explains the much needed backstory to the world you are in. In all, a slow start that begins to unravel itself as the game progresses which then really takes hold only until the last hours of gameplay. 

Gameplay: 

The game is very atmospheric and immersive, along with being difficult as you have to scavenge for supplies along with fighting enemies that heavily outnumber you. The latter being especially fun later in the game when you are kitted out in valuable weapons and armour, its the earlier hours however where the gameplay could turn many people off, for example, one of my biggest gripes was how inaccurate some of my weapons felt when aiming. This is due to weapons being found in the earlier stages being inherently inaccurate, making killing enemies frustrating as you essentially click on their head until a bullet finally hits them. When you can find a scoped weapon, combat becomes immediately better as now you can (somewhat) reliably kill enemies. The game also introduces items called 'artifacts', which are due to the supernatural game world, they are permanent stat boosts that come with both pros and cons, giving the game light RPG elements as you can mix and match what boosts you want to alter your gameplay. The gameworld is suprisingly large with it being segmented into different areas, with some hub areas for you to trade and pick up and return quests. Side quests are very basic, with most being simple fetch quests that can become frustrating as you have to go across different areas of the gameworld and return, for a reward which is often not worth the time put in, because of this there was little incentive for me to do side quests as I spent more time going from A to B than actually doing the quest. The main quest however is relatively straighfoward and could be beaten fairly quickly if you just want to experience the story. 

Overall, Stalker: Shadow of Chernobyl is a game worth experiencing for its atmostphere alone, and is a unique type of game that is not really seen on the market. Whilst it is frustrating at first, it becomes a great game once you stick to it and is quite memorable for its gloomy setting along with a punishing, almost tactical style of gameplay. 

8.5/10

P.S the game is rather buggy and prone to crashing, to fix this install the Zone Reclamation Project to make the game playable https://www.metacognix.com/files/stlkrsoc/

This was a huge hit among 16 year olds in 2007. Playing it in 2022, there are a few things to note.

This is one of the earliest survival FPS games, set in an alternate universe's Chernobyl Exclusion Zone. Not only is the place irradiated, but reality is falling apart and there's also a ton of mutants. Plus, literally everybody in the zone is a combatant, and most of them are zealots, soldiers of fortune, or vicious opportunists. All of this leads to a ton of interesting ways to die, and the map design, enemy accuracy, and environmental hazards are all exceptionally challenging (punishing). TL:DR the game is hard. I've been electrocuted, irradiated, thrown into the sky by an angry vortex, blasted in the face with shotguns, chased down by horribly mutated dogs, set on fire, exploded, and I've just plain bled out. Such is life in the Zone.

If you can survive long enough to understand it, the story isn't bad. Everybody you meet is an Eastern European survivalist, quick to remind you that war is hell but camaraderie is appreciated. The game's threats extend beyond mere guns n' ammo, though - dark experiments into the human psyche (and 'noosphere'; the realm of ideas), piles of radioactive garbage, blood-chilling mutants, and malevolent military forces all conspire to make the Zone a particularly entertaining suburb of Hell. There's something new and awful around every corner. 

Of course, the game is hideous by modern standards. Keen modders have worked around that if you need decent graphics. The UI holds up remarkably well, though, and inventory management is refreshingly quick and clean.

If you like a challenge, enjoy old game engines, or appreciate gaming history, I'd give this a whirl. Despite the war with Russia impacting the studio, a S.T.A.L.K.E.R 2 is in the works, so now's a pretty good time to experience the original.

Oh My God this is the best Atmospheric game i've ever play

I heard this game was good especially on hard mode like veteran, but i didnt expect it to be as good as i thought it would be.
It all started at Garbage where the difficulty would ramp up a bit with more enemies to fight, and a common face that would feel more unique after my encounters with him. 

Dying was a common occurrence to me (L bozo), ive probably seen the main menu more times than i have healing myself, so i felt defeated playing this game and i was close to quitting. But it was only until i went to Duty checkpoint in a thunderstorm at night that i was shown the reason to keep moving. 

There were a couple of Duty soldiers around but there was only 1 man next to a fire. He was sipping some red bull so i decided to chill opposite to him, at that point i was deciding to quit the game, but thats when he whipped out his guitar. 

During the piss-pouring rain, raging thunder and the clash of lightning, he played ‘He was a good stalker.’ As i listened while this thunderstorm was going on, i realized how ironic this is. How such a bad storm is beating down while this guy is playing this melancholic tune for me to hear, almost like hes making light out of a bad situation. So it dawned on me that this is an unforgiving game and i shouldnt quit just because of a few hard enemies, just try to have fun with a game that wants to fuck you over then pats you on the back and repeat. So i did what any person would do after seeing a concert performance like that, i gave him half of my food, ammo, bandages and the like for free (he was broke anyways so nothing to trade).

Hours go by at The Bar, Yanov, the scientists, Wild Territory, then back past the duty checkpoint. At that point I started to get tired of STALKER, not because im dying alot, I’m getting better and actually hiding behind cover alot now, but im just getting bored of it. I get to duty checkpoint and whaddya know, its nighttime and a thunderstorm is going off, while i see that guy in the distance next to the fire. I immediately run and sit next to the guy and wait until he pulls out his guitar, he does and i just listen to him while the storm rages on. Theres just something about the atmosphere of STALKER that just allures me to this game, just sitting next to a fire in a thunderstorm while a person strums his guitar, inspiring in a way. When he stopped to take out a bite of his big diet weenie, I felt invigorated and ready to go again for more of this beautiful game and what lies at the end.

To me that man and Duty checkpoint will be like home to me, if i ever feel like im ready to quit and be done with this game, i just go there and sit down hoping he sits as well so i could chill and talk with him.

And i know in my heart everytime a thunderstorm goes off at night he goes and sits down next to that fire, waiting for me to sit and listen to his songs of hope, so It is mandatory to listen to the calls of thunder when dusk comes. 

Play this game, seriously.

Nearly 40 hours on Steam doesn't scratch the surface of how much love and un-clocked time I've put into 'STALKER - SoC' and its sequels.

You awaken as an amnesiac 'S.T.A.L.K.E.R.' -- societal misanthropes who've moved into the mysterious cordon Zone surrounding Chernobyl, in search of their fortune in artifacts -- or worse.
Your near-dead body is pilfered from a wrecked corpse cart -- and you're left in the care of an enigmatic Trader, with nothing but your wits and your PDA...
Your PDA that contains a single message:
"KILL THE STRELOK"

This open-world adventure-horror-shooter drips with atmosphere.  With satisfying social interactions and gunplay, the player also spends time applying survival mechanics that are as frustrating as they are rewarding.  
Exploration and collection are necessary for you to thrive.  This is a breeze, because the game's perfected ambience can keep you enthralled for hours...days...years...

While it lacks the dynamic lighting, post-processing effects, and narrative trappings of its progeny, this original still forms the bedrock of one of gaming's most underrated franchises.

Game is still amazing 15+ years later and worth a revisit before its return. Mods highly recommended, but do yourself a favor and take the easy route.

I'm not completely oblivious when it comes to managing files in Windows.. even when following the most popular/upvoted guides on and outside of Steam (and each individual readme), learning how to install mods for Stalker SoC one by one takes some research and patience... i.e., more time than you want to spend. There were a couple attempts I had that crashed the game, and there was no way of knowing where I went wrong without having to uninstall and re-download the game. Save yourself some time and utilize the link provided below. It's a 1.5 GB download and takes a couple minutes to read, extract, and have this game from 2007 running the best it can (or at least good enough) so you can fly through this series before Stalker 2 comes out.

https://www.moddb.com/mods/xpresstunings-remaster-edition

This maintains a vanilla state of the gameplay, but increases visuals and performance. You can definitely have fun without these, but the game is noticeably dated without it (that headbobbing will drive you nuts). It's pretty satisfying seeing how dedicated the fanbase of this series was for getting the most out of this game. The package makes all the difference.

A few problems, major problems, very frustrating problems:

1. At the beginning of the game (and later too) you can take up to 4 or 5 quests (you take them in the 1st zone), but you need to go to the 5th or 6th zone and go back. The whole go-there-then-return make almost 50% of the whole game (as maps-covering), in the run you'll find the better armors and weapons. When you return to the 1st zone for the reward, they are so looow-level (they are made as rewards for 1st zone leveling and, I don't know why, they aren't balanced for your actual level), and you don't need them. There's more - you need 2-3 game-days to go, complete and return (the quest is completed not when you make the demanded things, but when you return to the quest giver at the beginning of the game on the 1st zone!??), but you have only 1 game-day to complete all the quests?! This makes the game so annoying!

HINT: You can intall an add-on to disable the time limitation and complete the quests when you want. The game with the add-on is more fun!

2. I can't find where to go. There is a sewer, very hard on higher difficulty, because of the distance and almost 100%-accuracy of the enemies. Then I went to a town, and found a sniper rifle with longer range than the enemies. Like this, the game is a piece of cake and I don't have fun with the levels before. And now I don't know where to go, because all the maps are so easy with the rifle. I lost the fun of covering and tactics from the early-game-levels of the game.
