STALKER is a very unique game. Intended to be released in 2003 it was highly experimental in design and rather unique. Even on release it came out a whole year before Fallout 3, and its intentional release was set before Half Life 2. It's easy to see the influence of Half Life and most notably Counter Strike on the game.

Shadow of Chernobyl starts out slowly with nothing but a sleeping bag. You get really weak weapons in the beginning, but these are relatively early replaced with rifles that can be used all until the end of the 20 hours it takes to finish the game.

The gunplay is like a match of CS. You come to a compound and it's all on you most of the time. The enemies have marksmanship accuracy while you need to carefully aim your shots. The steep learning curve, constant dying and reloading and bad weapons initially will deter many people from this game.

STALKER SoC is only played on hardcore mode of today, and is famously actually the "easiest" on Master difficulty. You need radiation pills and food as you go along and ammo has weight. Your carry limit is low enought to only being to carry 2 weapons plus ammo. You can fail one part of the main quest relatively early and be locked out of the good ending (I had to backtrack my save files when I understood this), and the final good ending has no quest markers. Near the end there is a point of no return which you might not be prepared for.

The story is... mysterious. I think that the mystery drives the game along with the ambience and world. No characters are particularly interesting, dialogue is poor, voice acting bad, the files to read passable at best. But the atmosphere. My God the atmosphere!

Very unique game, there truly is nothing like it. At times, like said, it feels like playing a tech demo of the future of gaming from 2003. Open world 3D FPS, what?

I probably won't play it again, but it was definitely an interesting ride!

It took me 17 hours to beat the game and then i realized that there are like 13 or a little less endings which shows that replayability is high
Pros:
-High number of possible replays
-Mood in stalker makes it a game one of a kind and the monsters can scare you 
-Amount of stuff and options is high: you can destroy some factions or become friendly with them
-Engine of the game itself is pretty decent 
-Game has lots of mods so boredom shouldnt happen
Cons:
-You have to manually save most of the times and forgetting might take you 30-60 minutes away like me 
-Some npcs will have the perfect aim making it near impossible to defeat without grenades or lots of meds
-Quests in some moments dont explain what you have to do: you have an large terrain with enemies with absolutely no info on how to get to the location nor how to find the last enemy hiding somewhere


Conclusion:
The game is worth playing and with a discount the stalker bundle is great for hours of gameplay or even after completing every of the games you will try stalker anomaly which is free?

[h1] S.T.AL.K.E.R.: Bugs of Chernobyl [/h1]
S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl has a lot of positives, but it also has one huge problem. 
Let's start with the good sides. The story is quite mysterious, which makes S.T.A.L.K.E.R. a really interesting game to play. You want to reveal all the secrets of the zone and immerse yourself in the lore of the S.T.AL.K.E.R universe as deep as possible. 
Gameplay is also quite good as long as you play the main story. Side quests are literally "go - kill" or "go - find" and the reward for these quests is useless every time. 
When everything seems so good, sadly, there is one big problem - the technical part of the game. The graphics for 2007 is quite good, but besides that... AI shooting and killing you trough the walls; AI stacking on top of each other; AI getting stuck in textures; Enemies reappearing in the same spawn zones again and again; Sometimes you fall into textures; Sometimes the game crashes without any reason, and this list can go on and on. Sometimes it's so bad you're not even sure whether the game has glitched again or everything is going as planned...
[b] Overall, is S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl worth playing today ? I would say it's worth speedrunning it in 7-10 hours just for the story. It's good, but it lacks optimization. 6/10 [/b]

So I've heard nothing but great things about this game. It's based off of the Tarkovsky movie which is a great movie. The setting of the game is great. I finally broke down and bought this game and tired to enjoy it but I just didn't find it to be a great game, or even a good game.

First of all, it pulls off the atmosphere pretty well. STALKER in theory is a great concept. The game fails to deliver on it's game play. It's slow paced and atmospheric, which is fun, but the gun play doesn't suit that sort of game play. It's a first person shooter but it has the slow paced movement that you would expect from a 3rd person cover based shooter.  This leaves you basically trading health for health packs to kill enemies most of the time. Enemies come out into the open to shoot at you, you spray back and they or their team mates shoot you. There is no real skill to this. It's simply: "Do you have enough health packs to get through the gun fights?" If the game were cover based timing would play a better role and it would suit the rest of the slow paced aspect of the game. If your character could move with speed and agility the game would be more action packed and you could benefit from your reaction time. Instead, the gun play fails on both levels and it's not a good slow paced shooter, or a good fast paced shooter. 

There is no cool down between using health packs which would again, accentuate skill. You can spam them into infinity if you have enough of them. That isn't very fun at all. Then there is the constant looting of every body just to make sure that you can get enough ammo to fight the enemies. All enemies drop handgun ammo. But pretty early on in the game the handgun becomes useless. Not all enemies drop ammo for the automatic rifles that they are shooting you with. You see an enemy with an AK, you kill the enemy, pick up his gun and it's empty, and he has no AK ammo on him. I only got 6 hours into the game and I was carrying 1200 rounds of pea shooter handgun ammo and was constantly having to switch back and forth between the AK and the SMG because the ammo for any meaningful weapon was so scarce.

The constant looting of bodies unnecessarily slows the game down even more. IDK if I've ever played a first person shooter before where I didn't automatically pick up a persons ammo by walking over it. But the game tries to pull off some sort of RPG element with how much you can carry and ammo can weigh you down.  

The heart of the problem for this game is that it tries to be an RPG and a first person shooter and it doesn't really pull of either of those goals very well. If this game were a cover based shooter like Mass Effect without the annoying loot and weight management that slows the game down too much it would be a great RPG. If your character were faster and more agile with limited use of health packs and more ammo (and again losing the weight management) it could be a fun FPS with a good story.

Play on Master Difficulty!! On Novice there is a 60% that each of your shots will literally disappear due to an odd development choice that makes you miss even if you are perfectly on target. Playing on Master will make bullets do more damage on both ends as well as reduce the bullets that are fated to miss. The AI is smarter on Master and the game is very tough, but on lower difficulties it's just frustrating.

Edit: Everything I said about the difficulty is wrong, this was a common myth that the majority of the community believed but it has been debunked. 
Difficulty does change the global bullet damage though, meaning on easy mode the enemies will be bullet sponges but so will you. I still recommend playing on Master, or even Advanced just to strike a balance between difficulty and bullet sponges.

This is absolutely a hidden gem of a game, but you will require some mods to get it working properly, namely the ZRP, AKA Zone Reclamation Project. I feel like it's the sort of game that gets much better the more you play it due to it's semi steep learning curve and a few outdated game mechanics such as the map and stamina system that need to be learned over time. However, if you are willing to stick with it, this is one of the best games you will ever play.

The games main strengths include:
> A chilling and creepy atmosphere (especially in underground).
> One of the coolest game worlds I have personally ever seen.
> The best tactical FPS gameplay and AI I have ever seen.
> Plenty of things to do such as finding caches and completing sidequests.

The games main drawbacks include:
> Hard to get into (my first playthrough was nowhere near as good as my second due to me not understanding game mechanics fully).
> Unplayable without Zone Reclamation Project mod (easy to fix though).
> It's pretty old (2007), so some parts are quite outdated like parts of the graphics.

Overall, I would very much recommend Shadow of Chernobyl to anyone with a decent amount of patience for some jank as it really is a one of a kind game.
It's amazing...... but I'm not telling you how to beat  it.

Even when it gets tough, its still really enjoyable and rewarding. Granted, the game may feel a little old for today's time, but you could always try out the bajillion mods available for this game. 
Although, I would recommend a vanilla playthrough first with some bug fixes (see Zone Reclamation Project).
No real cons, other than.... what in the hell is the accuracy of the guns. I know for a fact that playing at Master difficulty does nothing to make enemies feel less bullet- spongey. When the bullets don't hit where you want to, it gets really annoying.
The real trick is to crouch and go prone (or lie down?), then shoot. Even at lower difficulties, you can easily headshot some poor mercenary 100m away with a goddamn pistol.
The sound design and ambience is really immersive, although it is a bit saddening to not understand what the soldiers are saying near campfires. Gun sounds are okay, with the player having to compensate for recoil. Mutants still look terrifying for such an old game, and some straight up make you piss in your pants.

Coming to this game as a Fallout Fan (Fallout 4), I was startled to find both similarities and differences between this Russian game and my favorite game (Fallout 4). I found it interesting that this game uses radiation from Fallout. It also uses a made up currency, Rubles. This is very similar to Fallout's "Caps" (Bottlecaps for all the non-gamers!). I'm not sure if they stole these ideas from older Fallout games like Fallout 3 but I hope they didn't. This game is much harder than Fallout, this is one of the differences I noticed, this game is like the Dark Souls (Hard game) of S.T.A.L.K.E.R games. Another difference is that there is not many funny characters in this game unlike Fallout 4 which has Codsworth and Hancock! This game is very glitchy unlike Fallout games. I don't remember the story that much I just remember having to kill a guy which is similar to having to kill the guy who kidnapped your son in Fallout 4 (Bad-*ss)! Overall, 2/10, the graphics are bad. If you want a good game you should play Halo 4! -Boonkwang

This is a classic game that has inspired so many games since and really will make you nostalgic for the late 00's of computer gaming. I would definitely recommend this to anyone who this has been recommended this game. 

That being said, at 5 hours in, I think I'm going to stop playing. The game has many old features and is a little too "realistic" for my liking. There's no fast travel, some quests will have you back tracking to unreasonable distances, and the story needs to be read via text (which is fine, but the story hasn't engaged me enough to pay attention). The gun fights often don't feel satisfying enough and healing during combat can be challenging, due to trying to crouch while doing it. 

I can absolutely tell this game is a classic. A certified banger, if you will. If I get the urge to try it again, I will gladly jump back in. This game is an acquired taste, but one that I would recommend any one try if interested. It's just not for me.

Jogue na dificuldade Master! 
S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Shadow of Chernobyl é bem único e bastante imersivo, a atmosfera criada no jogo é excelente. O combate é muito bom, você sente que as armas possuem um certo peso e que não são "brinquedos". A progressão é boa e na dificuldade Master foi bem balanceado.

I have been playing this game since 2011 and even by then it was "old" as far as game tech goes.
If you are on the fence about this game, let me give you a few key reasons I keep coming back.
The gunplay is brutal. You can die quickly if you're an idiot (or unlucky).
The Voice Acting is actually really good.
The atmosphere; It set the mark for games like this.
But the biggest point is that something different seems to happen every time I come back. Enemies do not always do the same things, people are not always in the same places, and monsters are not always roaming the same corners.

Now, I will warn you. This game is from 2007. It's ugly. It's old. It's brutal. And it's crude. It's the definition in its raw form of "A face only a mother could love," but it is worth it if you like horror RPGs (I guess that's what this would be?)

Now, if you got this far and you are about to buy it, also consider strolling over to ModDB (or google) Stalker Complete 2009. It's simple to do, but it improves a LOT of outdated elements. Purists may give you crap, that's fine. Once you play the game through, explore the Stalker subreddit, and look into mods like Dead Air. This game has been tweaked to brutal detail to offer dangerous and unique experiences.

Its a great game to just get immersed in. Highly reccomend you get the Zone Reclamation Project mod since it squashes a lot of bugs and allows you to change some things. I personally made it so i could trade weaponry with other Stalkers to better arm them + allowed Stalkers to avoid Anomalies instead of just walking into them.

Even without ZRP Stalker SOC is a great game. I've had a blast just travelling from different parts of the map hauling gear and other bits and bobs to sell.

Its A.I is also the best I've ever seen, with totally unscripted events happening that really make you feel like its a living breathing world. For instance, a campsite with a group of friendly stalkers or I quite often trade with and chill with was being threatened by an incoming Spetsnaz patrol which lead to a very intense firefight which had me scrambling for any kind of foothold as I desperately tried to save my friends. By the end of it I had an excess of AK's and the surviving Stalkers now considered me friends which really did lead to a bond between me and the NPC's

SOC is great at getting you to care for NPCs. You at first value friendly NPC's as they serve as an extra gun out in the Zone thats killing mutants and Bandits and also as someone to trade with (usually selling things to them) so you don't have tot travel all the way to Traders. However with time you really begin to value the NPC's as in the very hostile Zone where almost everything wants to kill and bandits seem to be everywhere seeing a friendly face is quite refreshing and allows you to take a breather. When one dies I genuinely feel sad, not just because theres one less Stalker out in the Zone potentially killing mutants and bandits but because the Zone got just that more inhospitable.


Also it runs really well, with vanilla being perfectly fine.

TLDR: I really like this game, you should play it, runs great vanilla, download ZRP mod.

I heard a lot about this series and always wanted to give it a try. When I first played it, I was met with a lot of frustration since I played on the hardest difficulty. A lot of my time was spent quick saving after killing an enemy and dying to the next. The gun play was something to get used to since I felt like I couldn't hit anything while everything could hit me with ease. However, after getting better gear and becoming well-acquainted with how the game works, I began to see the beauty of it. The combat can be cut-throat and keeps you on alert. The horror aspect of the game is what really makes it shine when you're slowly making your way through dark tunnels and decrepit buildings out of fear. The enemy variety and design is awesome when it comes to the monsters. The different factions are also interesting. The story keeps you engaged with wanting to reach Pripyat and the Wish Granter. The setting and the different zones also keep things fresh. In my opinion, while I do enjoy Call of Pripyat, this game is the definitive S.T.A.L.K.E.R. experience.

This is the first Stalker game and the only one I have played, and I definitely enjoyed it. It goes as a shooter, where you play as an amnesiac man and have to hunt down someone named Strelok, in a place called the zone. You have standard weapons, but the atmosphere is just great. My only complaint is the difficulty, I must have died a thousand times.

S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl is the first STALKER game, but it takes place a year after its prequel, Clear Sky. You play as an amnesiac man named Marked One, who continues the last mission he remembered: hunt down a stalker named Strelok who managed to enter the center of the Zone, the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant. It's an open-world FPS-RPG where you collect items and do quests. Imagine Fallout mixed with Metro, set in a post-apocalyptic, post-Soviet country with bandits, mutants, and good ol' radiation. It has levels based on real locations, too, like the ghost town Pripyat.

Compared to its prequel which I played first, SoC is better in so many ways despite the prequel being the newer one. The early missions are simple and easy, welcoming to any new player. Money, armor, weapons, and artifacts are also very easy to find, you don't need to buy them from shop or go inside an anomaly as they are given as rewards or just laying around. Some unique, more powerful weapons and armor are available and easy to find. All of these combined makes the combat easier to handle, but still a bit dangerous. The final levels are sadly linear and has plenty of combat, but I didn't really find it difficult thanks to my gear.

However, those easy-to-find gear came with a consequence: money becomes almost useless. I always play scavenger in open-world games, and I don't ever need to use money as there are no overpowered gear that is only available at traders. There's also no fast travel, not even those paid guides, and you have to run back and forth to do some sidequests. Biggest flaw of the game. I only recommend doing the more unique ones, such as find armor/weapon or the "kill named person" assassination quests which yield good rewards and unique dialogue. Otherwise, the backtracking gets tedious and you only get generic lines and useless money.

This game has 7 endings, but you can only get 3 per playthrough. 1 is a "false" ending, which is short and unsatisfying, but depends on your actions during the game. The other 2 are the "true" endings. To get the true endings, you must do a series of short sidequests involving meeting people from your past, but other than that what you did doesn't really matter, unlike in the false ones. The bad ending is only a bit longer than the false ones, but happens in a different room. The good ending, and also the canon one, is quite longer and involves a lot of combat. But it's worth it, and it gives you a chance to try out your powerful end-game gear.

S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl is a pretty great post-apocalyptic game, and worth a try if you like the aforementioned Fallout and Metro games. I kinda recommend playing Clear Sky first though, since the confusing mechanics there are different from here so you will still be confused if you play it later. Get the bad one out of the way first, and enjoy feeling powerful and rewarded in this game.

S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is one of my absolute favorite series of all time. Nearly every year I finish the trilogy again and again.
Let me explain why it is simply a fantastic game:

1- Atmosphere & Story :

S.T.A.L.K.E.R. takes place in the "Zone" , an unforgiving and deadly place formed after a fictional second Chernobyl Disaster, the area is completely devastated by radiation, mutants, anomalies and valuable artifacts formed from these anomalies. Soon people who call themselves Stalkers flood the Zone to make a fortune from said artifacts. Military and Scientists ( or Ecologists ) also came to study and understand The Zone. Our protagonist "Marked One" is an amnesiac Stalker with only one mission "Kill Strelok". An unknown stalker.

Atmosphere is the strongest part of the game, developers actually went to the Chernobyl NPP and city of Pripyat to create the game's world, and it looks great. You travel from army outposts to stalker camps, secret labs to underground tunnels and it all feels like a part of a real and living world.

2- Weapons & Shooting Mechanics :

You have your standart assault rifles, pistols, shotguns, grenades and sniper rifles (and a little surprise near the end). Due to game's setting, most of the assault rifles consist of Warsaw Pact ones but NATO weapons are also present, further into the game. Shooting mechanics are solid and when the bullets hit the enemy, they react appropriately. Silencers, scopes and grenade launchers can be installed to weapons. Weapons also have realistic recoil, individual ammo, varying accuracies and firing rates.

3- Factions :

In S.T.A.L.K.E.R. there are 8 factions, you can work for some of them but others are strictly enemies (Monolith , Military etc).
You start the game as a rookie stalker and choose who you want to help. I don't want to spoil the factions so much as they are introduced as the story progresses so I will cut this here.

4- Artifacts & Anomalies :

Anomalies are hazards created by the disaster and almost all of them are deadly to the player, some will burn you, others will shock you, but they have one good characteristic : they spawn artifacts.
All artifacts have special properties and when attached to stalker's belt they grant useful abilities such as giving higher stamina or lowering radiation sickness. They also worth a lot of money.

5- Mutants :

Besides the human enemies you have mutants, animals or humans warped by radiation or experimentation. You start tangling with measly blind dogs to enormous pseudogiants. All of them are unique and some drop mutant body parts which you can sell to the Ecologists. Also some of the more dangerous mutants have kind of introductions:
Imagine walking through an abondoned lab and you hear a roar, like an animal roar but something is not right , then the ground starts to shake, you ready your trusty rifle and ...
In short, mutants really add great horror and help improve the already fantastic atmosphere of the game.

6- Fanbase & Mods :

S.T.A.L.K.E.R. just like Half-Life, has the most active fanbase I have ever seen.
Still to this date there are mods coming out for it. I strongly advise any fan of the game to give at least one good story mod a shot after completing the game. To me, there is nothing better than diving into the world of S.T.A.L.K.E.R. once more with new missions, enemies, items, mutants, and sometimes even cars.

As I finish this review I want to thank GSC for this amazing series, there is still nothing like S.T.A.L.K.E.R. . It is oozing with originality, has a great fanbase, mods and overall an amazing atmosphere

Gunplay felt really good at times and really bad at others. In the beginning it is quite bad, shots don't hit enemies even close range, but with better weapons it gets much better and is quite good at least in close distance encounters. But long range gunfights are terrible, even the sniper isn't very accurate and never having enough sniper bullets makes it worse. With rifles long range battles feel like waiting until you get good RNG to finally get a HS. A cool mechanics like noise wasn't important at all and stealth felt unrewarding. Radioactive Anomalies were just annoying, especially Vortex but mostly avoidable. Main story and locations are okay. Overall still recommend it if you like intense survival shooters.

The first and the hardest of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Trilogy.
The story is an absolute banger and the atmosphere is top notch.
If you are a someone who has played game like Fallout series, this i absolutely recommend this game for you
Tho Fallout is excel in interaction with world and NPCs S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is excel in atmosphere and story.

this game run on X-Ray Engine 1.0 the first engine model that powered the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series, because of that there will be tons of bugs even after patches, but like Bethesda's games the community come to the rescue.

here's some of mods that i recommend :
- The Starter Pack https://www.moddb.com/mods/starter-pack
Like the name suggest it a starter pack for those whose new to the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series, it's basically a vanilla game with improved gameplay and some visual improvement, it includes : 
- "Original Weapons Renewal" 3 a HD rendition of SoC Vanilla weapon
- "Photo Realistic Zone" a texture pack for ground, trees, structures etc
- "Stalker Weather Overhaul" a better looking weather and skyboxes
- "STALKER Shaders MAX 1.06" for better looking shaders, adds depth of field, slight motion blur
- ZRP "Zone Reclamation Project" a community-supported modpack for overall bugfixes
- "FOV Switcher v17" as the name suggest changing your FOV to your preference
- there will be mechanics you can ask to repair your gears just like in CS and CoP they're located in Freedom's base
and Duty's Rostok

- Repair Kits Revamped https://www.moddb.com/mods/repair-kits-revamped
adding a repair kits in case your weapon breaks in the firefight

- SoC HD Models Addon https://www.moddb.com/mods/shadow-of-chernobyl-hd-models-addon
like the name suggest it add an HD models to SoC, tho the community is divided about this mod

[h1]STALKER is hard to talk about[/h1] 
It's a product of a long and troubled development process by an eastern European developer to create a very ambitious project. And eastern European games have fairly odd design elements by default, even when they are not trying to be ground breaking. 

Play the game for the first time without mods, without watching videos about it, without reading walk-throughs, be completely on your own and the information the game gives you. For some this is not going to be possible due to certain technical issues on an unmodded game, but if you can, do it. 

STALKER is a first person shooter in a semi-open world with roleplaying and minor survival-horror elements. And STALKER is also none of those. STALKER is very hard to talk about. The open world nature combined with its shooter elements seems almost prophetic when looking a few years later at games like Ubisoft's FarCry series almost doing the same thing that STALKER did, except on a more polished and mass-marketable level.
[list]
 [*]The first person shooter part of the game feel unresponsive, you'll be questioning whether your shots even do damage or merely pass through your opponents. 
 [*]The open world is segmented in several smaller levels that break up the pacing of the game. Some levels are small or linear enough not to provide any sense of being open at all.
 [*] The roleplaying aspects are limited to weapons and armours having arbitrary statistics, a very RPG-like progression system (even though there is no levelling up or directly improving your character) and some open dialouge choices which might affect parts of the game.
 [*]The survival-horror elements are limited to a hunger requirement (that is so generous most players don't even realize it exists on their first playthrough, it becomes obvious only after you start selling all of your food items, thinking they are just a glorified way to regen health), inventory management and traversing an environment where everything constantly wants you dead.
[/list]


On the other hand, all aspects of the game have fine attention to detail, that bring it well out of the crowd.
[list]
 [*]All weapons experience bullet drop, realistic bullet travel time, bullets can ricochet and pierce materials. Although the combat distances don't get long enough to notice until very late in the game, it creates a nice differentiation between different types of weapons.
 [*]Most weapons have at least 2 types of ammunition available. Some are straight upgrades, others are more effective against one type of opponent while less effective against others, but help vary things up a little.
 [*]Headshots are incredibly deadly. Oponents feel like bullet sponges only if you don't score headshots. If most games have 2 or 3 times damage multipliers for headshots, STALKER has a damage multiplier of 5 on humans and 10 on other enemies. This might seem like a completely meaningless mechanic, but it completely changes the way you perceive difficulty in the game. If you can score the headshots, most firefights will always feel too easy.
 [*]Even though your character remains completely the same throughout the game, you feel constant progression of power due to how the weapons and armour are distributed. Exploration and some sidequesting can be used to get ahead of the curve, giving a very RPG-like feeling of leveling up. The starting weapons are completely awful, which helps with this power-leveling perception, when you can look back at how much better everything you have towards middle/end of the game compared to lowly bandits.
 [*]The atmosphere! The world inhabitants are obviously emulated rather than simulated, but the mood it creates when you see random loners just passing by from one location to another, getting attacked by wild boars on the way, while the gunfire attracts a group a bandits you were supposed to eliminate for a quest, that later get ripped apart by said boars, which then drag the human corpses in bushes and feed on them. All this in a daytime cycle which transitions extremely smoothly, with nice weather effects and an ambiance ranging from desolate to creepy gives a feeling of a world that actually is somewhat alive, even despite how incredibly morbid everyday life of its inhabitants are.
 [*]Weapons and armour detereorate. Weapons become less accurate, they can start jamming, armour loses effectiveness. Even though you might have the best gear, you are always looking for a replacement, in case you can find something in better condition. Such minor aspects make the survival part of the game truly shine.
 [*]The world is full of dilemmas. There are no good guys or bad guys in the entire game world. One faction argues that the Zone must be destroyed, because it endangers the rest of the world, another faction believes the logical solution is to study it at the expense of people's lives. Even the "neutral" loners in all of STALKER games often come from criminal backgrounds, some are selfish, some came to the Zone for the thrill and the adventure. In all of this, nobody is in the right. [/list]


And so much more little things...


And despite all the praise I could give, this is by no means a game for everyone...
The game is too difficult or too easy for some players. Small groups of human enemies can be dispatched with a single magazine while not taking any damage yourself, if you know how to. Money is also constantly coming in even when you don't try and there's not a lot to use it on. In other scenarios turning a corner to see a pack of 15 dogs charging at you spells a lot of pain at the very least. This is also the charm of the game - no matter what, you always feel vulnerable, even inferior weapons at point blank range can nearly instantly wipe you out. Some will find this immersive, as it's not just another power fantasy, and the best choice might actually be evading an encounter at all if possible. Some will find this just a source of frustration, helplesness and annoyance. 
Something very specific to eastern European and Russian games is the prevelance of how easy it is to nearly instantly die. Wrong dialouge option? Those 4 guys armed to the teeth around you turn hostile when you don't even have your weapon drawn. Wasn't sure what that weird thing on the ground was? It's a gravitational anomaly that drains stamina, making you unable to escape and you die. With time you get used to the game's shenanigans, and again is part of the charm, making the very first playthrough so memorable, other times this will cause cheap deaths and wasted time because the last save was made 30 minutes ago.
The localization and translation (at least to English) work on the game ranges from well done, to mildly amusing all the way to downright stupid. Although this creates some very good meme material, one cannot deny how jarring it is to see some of the voice acting play out right there in front of you.

[h1]Mods, patches[/h1]
The game might require some tweaking to get running well. For my personal taste, default visual bloom settings were just atrocious, but become very pleasant after adjusting some values in the console. A lot of people will recommend all kinds of mods. My only suggestion is that if you really must play with mods that fix some of the issues the game has, download ZRP (Zone Reclamation Project) - this is mostly a compilation of bug fixes while not changing the base gameplay. Most other mods vastly alter core gameplay, most notably increasing difficulty, accounting for the playerbase probably having previous experience with the game.
Early game in all STALKER games is just painful - the guns are inaccurate, nothing does enough damage, you die a lot. I can see how this might be a turnoff for some.

 STALKER is really hard to talk about, and that's why I love it.

After about 10 hours of this game and finishing it I'll say this is a unique survival game gem. This game is based on upon the chernobyl nuclear powerplant disaster and I thought I was cool to see it based upon that. When I first played it I got bored of it. 4 months laters I played it again and was already addicted to the universe of the game. It can be a little hard to get used to it at first. Some enemies can survive more shots than you think. Some can take about 10 body shots to 2 headshots to be taken down, depending on your gun. You have to watch your inventory a lot because you can be carrying a lot of stuff which can slow you down when running. There are times where you will die a lot (Died about 10 times in one area), so it's best to save before hand after every gun fight to not get suprised by the next one. My favorite part of this game is going through the city near the end of the game where you can see the hotel houses and the ferris wheel. It gives me a bit of a cod 4 vibe. If anyone likes survival games you will like this one.

I bought this game some years ago on the premise it was the equivilant of a Urkranian/Russian Fallout. At first I didn't enjoy it due to it being vastly different. But this year I came back and I delve into the world and did everything I could. And truly this is one of the best games I have ever played in my life. Although this game is a bit on the older side, everything people praised it for were true. The atmosphere the world gives off and the lore is simply unbeleievable, you truly feel how sad and depressing the world is in STALKER, especially if you watch videos on youtube that do translation for all npcs. You realize how sad everyone is because they are just trying to make enough money so they can make it by. Or when you find the zombies you realize their mublings are their broken memories. Many of them saying they will come home to their daughter or crying out to their mother as they die. Or with the military, their government has simply abandoned them there, they were given no real objective besides no one enters or leaves, until finally after some of the players actions, they try to take control (I wont spoil it).

Each faction aswell is well written and I can see myself siding with almost any of them since they, depending on the players views, are morally gray. Duty wants to contain and destroy the zone, Freedom want to allow all to enjoy the zone and something that shouldnt be contained, Loners are simply random people trying to make it rich, mercenaries getting paid to do things for outer powers, Monolith trying to protect their "god" of sorts, Military just doing their job, Zombies poor stlkers that got their brains scorched and are now husks of their former selves (if you ever encounter one please put them down stalker), Ecologists simply want to study the zone and its anomalies.

Truly one of the best games out there. I recommend this game to anyone who wants a gritty atmosphere and want to have an adventure in the zone.

If you've never played S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl please give it a shot and use some simple mods to update the graphics. Also set your brightness settings so that the dark feels dark. SS.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl is a first-person survial horror shooter.
In this game the "Zone", a ruthless and uncontrolled terrain full of anomalies and mutants,
has engulfed the area around the Chernobyl Powerplant.
The military and other factions fight for supremacy while small fry tries to gain pricey artefacts.
Suffering from amnesia you will try to fight your way to the center of the Zone, 
hoping to find power, yourself and an explanation...
Stalker is certainly a game to recommend. The atmosphere, story and world are reason enough.
But it does have a few flaws. It feels unfinished and clunky in some parts 
and a few gameplay aspects can be tedious. (The "Complete Mod 2009" helps!)
Yet if you manage to stand over these problems then you will be in for a memerable ride.

Proud to say I've been a S.T.A.L.K.E.R. fan since 2009.  

This is a game that does survival right.  Atmosphere that really draws you in and immerses you.  Visually, it hasn't aged well given it was made on a budget of Stolichnaya and sausage in the mid 2000's.  However, it has one of the most diehard and committed communities out there that have consistently delivered some of the most impressive mods to make up for that.  If you're new to the series check out Anomaly, the standalone mod, you won't be disappointed.

This game is a fun and challenging experience. The best parts are having to take the game slow because the enemies are tough to the point that you have to become really well acquainted with F6. Having to keep track of weight limit, armor condition, food and other stuff also made one of the most immersive experience i have had. This game always felt tough but fair.. that is until the NPP level that was just pure chaos and just not fun. Who thinks that having to run from helicopters  and hordes of the strongest enemies that kill you in seconds all while you have to rush to make it under a certain amount of time a fun concept? That was just pure hell and not enjoyable. I know what you guys are going to say get good and turn the difficulty up to master to kill enemies faster; which is a complete lie by the way. That is how us manly man and master stalkers play the game. I personally came here to enjoy a challenging but fair game whose atmosphere will engulf me and through out most of the game it did just that.My favorite parts of the game was going under ground in the dark and having to check every corner  to make sure no enemies where hiding to jump on me. Enemies being able to kill you quickly always kept you on edge and it was truly immersive experience. The level with the floating items that will fly/tossed at you was my favorite, truly fun. The sounds in this game are also great and really add to the overall experience. Things i did not like are how guns work in this game, if i put my iron sites on your dome and you are not wearing a helmet i expect to kill you, but here it was guessing game on whether your bullets will even connect, this made you waste ammo just to artificially raise the difficulty. Also why can i not have a shotgun as my side arm and a assault rifle as my main? the handgun is basically useless and just took unnecessary space. The final thing i did not like was that NPP level, and it was the thing that made me quit out the game. Why do games designers think that hordes of enemies and rockets going of everywhere is the solution to a final level? Overall i definitely recommend this game even with it flaws it is one of the best shooters i have ever played. The creatures/enemies are tough, the atmosphere is incredible, and going underground or into a bunker is just an incredible experience. If you have not played this game just do it and enjoy one of the best gaming experiences i have had in a long time. P.S bloodsuckers can kiss my ass.

The game is amazing, i completely recommend it but since I am not good at talking about the strong points of something  i will just talk about the flaws it possess. 
You cannot repair weapons, that nice unique weapon you like to use, better keep it for special occasions or prepare yourself to throw it away halfway though the game, cause they have a finite number of uses. This is specially annoying when said unique weapon is chambered to a different ammo caliber, fire-rate and accuracy are good but they are not that special, having a nice gun that use cheap ammo is. The viper 9x18 is only automatic weapon that uses the trash 9x18 ammo you are going to be drowning in. 
Pistols are kinda of useless, you take as much time to reload as to change the weapon so having a backup weapon for when you can't reload is not that effective, plus they kinda suck. Where the automatic pistols at? Who stole all the automatic pistols in the Zone?
There are no normal rifles either, only sniper rifles. Doesn't really affect the experience. Sure it would be nice to have a medium range lever-action rifle but you can live without them.
Grenades are kinda difficult to use since you can't cook them. You can hold right click to charge a meter that would make think it's how long you charged the grenade timer but it only affects throw distance, so you can't use really effectively, plus the physics are kinda of fricked(fucked) up and makes the grenades difficult to aim, sometimes the grenades bounce right back at you.
Hunger, it's kinda there, never knew it existed until 30hrs in, cause the game gives you so much food.
Factions are also kinda there too. They don't really matter a lot and it's actually better to not involve in, since joining one side will make the other one hostile and that's just more enemies to  fight.
This one is just personal, rocket launchers suck and i don't mean they are underpowered, they function exactly like they should, an insta-kill basically, the problem is enemies with rocket-launchers they have unlimited ammunition and will just spam them over and over, and when you are using the exoskeleton armor you can't run so good luck dodging the rocket. Get a sniper and kill them as fast as you can.
*Like i said before, a definitely recommended, buy it you won't regret it. Runs on trash hardware too and it has a lot of mods that give additional hours of gameplay.

Well there is a reason this series of games are still talked about today...
I had a blast with stalker but I'm not gonna lie, there are problems.

Positives:
Atmosphere is really well done, it really immerses you in the world mainly because of the sound design and lighting which are really good despite graphics having aged.
The shooting is great, this is a bit controversial because the game uses a chance system for bullets missed in order to roughly simulate recoil, I didn't mind this mechanic too much because it made finding better weapons very rewarding since they did more damage and were more accurate.
The enemy AI is nothing to laugh at either, they try to defend themselves and hide behind cover, or in bushes so they are harder to see, and they imploy strategies like flanking you, which adds to the sense of realism and keeps combat encounters fresh and always fun.
I also like that the game is straight to the point, no skill trees, or many branching dialogues or exposition, generally you will get a job, do it and get a reward, simple.

Negatives:
Well I played the game as vanilla as can be, meaning 0 mods and 0 fan made patches.
The game is buggy, from quests not completing when you clear the objective, to quest markers marking places where there is nothing or quests instantly completing because your target spawned on top of a campfire when you entered the area he was at.
The story, despite interesting isnt very well told... for the most part of the game I was completing objectives I didnt really know how they would help me? For example, going into the several undeground labs, some of them I dont know why I had to go there ( and I just finished the game at the time of this review), or the fact that the route to the true ending is locked behind a chain of side quests that you don't realise the importance of, because they just pop on your pda without much alarm after completing some main objective. 

Conclusion:
Overall I think Stalker Shadow of Chernobyl is a pretty great game and damn well worth a buy, I can see why it is still talked about today, and it was one hell of a good time playing through it, the gameplay loop is on point despite the way the story is delivered having its flaws, buy it.

I really want to like this, as the world and the atmosphere seem really appealing to me and I appreciate that they've tried to make a very dark and oppressive world. The thing is, it just plays like crap and it's buggy as hell...and there is no getting past that. 

Gun play is atrocious and the AI gets away with so much, that it just doesn't feel enjoyable at all. Though direct engagements are not really the intention, hit detection and damage taken by enemies is abysmally implemented. I tested out a few interactions and found some enemies surviving more than 5 point blank shots to the head, some point blank shots somehow missing enemies, all while i'm bleeding out from a couple shots taken halfway across a location. If there are groups of enemies, they seem to clump up a lot too, usually where i was last heard or seen. Then that's it, they just stand there indefinitely. 

This was all witnessed within a couple of hours, so I sadly have no intention of playing any longer or recommending it to anyone.

Cons:
- Completely stop moving if holding 10kg too much.
- Maps need loading across zones and no way to carry stuffs back to traders.
- And there are indeed only a limited number of traders out there.
- Game is totally looter unfriendly.

Workaround: 
- Just drag corpse like an XXL suitcase. Problem solved.
- At cross map section, drag one corpse at each entrance. Take a few minutes to repeat picks and dumps. For no-brainer clicking and a final easy TAKE ALL, remember to unload necessities on a third corpse, but always quicksave at the same side of it in case next loading screen brings random mutants or military.

I actually earned some 250K+ before adventuring into the red forest. There were still quite some loots left in two chests in the military base section, but I accidentally kill the Freedom guy the first time i storm into the camp, so no trades in the zone unless I haul them back to the Barkeep. Didn't check any walkthroughs or spoilers so I was totally in the wrong impression that, in such a place named "Hotel", in the city of Pripyat, there is probably some kind of a trader out there yes? All the way through the forest and the scorcher quest and finally into Pripyat I was dragging this same captain corpse and dumping everything I looted, RPGs, snipers, all guns and pistols, ammo unloaded, all foods and med-kits and cute artifacts and body parts, everything. Dragging my precious luggage slowly walking in the street of Pripyat is a weird experience. What a loner. But the moment I realize the hotel is but a ruin, and as I double check and learn the fact that from red forest there is NO MORE TRADER in the remaining part of the game, such a heart-sinking news! What am I doing all these for? And till that sad yet funny moment, I suddenly realize that, my suitcase can no longer hold any extra items. There is after all some kind of limit on a corpse's capacity! I made a save, and then tried to take all. The weight reading confirmed that a corpse can hold up to 1000kg. Well, 10kg I cannot move an inch away, but dragging a corpse stuffed with ONE TON of trash no problem comrade. Even funnier thing is that, I can no longer load this quicksave and another closely followed previous one, game simply crashed at loading section. No similar questions asked or solutions to be found online, so I had to load another earlier save to continue to the final game. During the nuclear plant underground I was still playing with suitcase as I was fearingf out of ammo, as earlier in the X16 lab quest I was completely ripped clean to some final 10 bullets upon returning to the safe bunker. But then the final stage with all those teleportation anomalies completely ruined my days as a frenzy looter. Can't complain that my "Wish Granter" gave me an "I want to be rich" ending. Heard the threshold is a merely 50k for that ending. If only there was a trader in the nuclear plant, I could have been an authentic millionaire no doubt.

"Open world survival" is a scary tag nowadays because of the tons of bad games that were released in the last years, which is strange since STALKER was released in 2007 and did such a good job that makes you wonder why are today's games so bad

Basically, the game is about a nobody who receives a mission to kill a famous stalker. You roam around this unhospitable place, full of bandits and monsters, and receive a couple of missions from people that are not bad enough to kill you. Not only that, anomalies created by radiation are also around and they will destroy you if you are not careful

You have to play smart - enemies won't hesitate to attack you, they hide behind cover, resources are scarce. Guns and armor have their durability reduced as you use them, which makes them worse, so don't be too attached to them. You can and should loot bodies to get ammo, food, and equipment in better condition

But it has its flaws, the most important one is that the game tries to be a FPS and RPG-like, but guns are incredibly inaccurate and the weapon stats doesn't mean a lot (some early weapons with high accuracy are worse than endgame, lower accuracy ones). So in the beginning, it's hard to fight because your guns are bad, but later on it's still hard because enemies have insane armor. The game basically has you rely on headshotting the bad guys, but weapon inaccuracy makes it a thousand times worse than it should be

Overall, I think this is a game worth playing, but keep in mind that it is as hostile as its world towards the player. There are mods and guides that can help you tweak some of the annoyances and I strongly recommend doing so

Nothing better than playing apocalyptic game before the Apocalypse.

1986 was surely a special year. In the middle of crazy 1980s, an unexpected accident happened, resulting in a crysis on a scale unseen before. I mean of course Chernobyl disaster, a nuclear accident considered as the worst in history (and let's hope that the last one that big ever to take place).

Knowing the background of the event from several decades ago is necessary to fully appreciate the effort put into S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl. Not only GSC Game World succeeded in recreating faithfully Chernobyl Exclusion Zone, but also - or I should say especially - managed to create a game with atmosphere that is really rare to find in the industry. Atmosphere of dread land filled with deadly anomalies, mutants, gloomy landscapes of lands that were once inhabitated, but had to be left in a hurry during the evacuation in 1986. Radioactive Red Forest, underground laboratories, military complexes full of treasures (and enemies)? These locations and many more awaits the player during their journey.

Variety of enemies and weapons makes the whole experience even more immersive. You will find various people during your journey, and some of them are going to be hostile towards the player. Apart from them, there are many various types of mutants (starting from mutated dogs, and ending with mutants capable of using psionic tricks). That's why it is important to wander around unknown places fully-equipped, with good weapons, armor, decent amount of ammunition and medical items. Game offers enough of these items to choose from to fit the way you, as the player, would like to play this game. Not to forget about artifacts that are harder to get, but provide valuable bonuses that might be crucial in some cases. You are playing as a stalker called the Marked One, after all. Your mission is to find and kill a man named Strelok in such dangerous place as the Zone. No one said that it would be an easy task.

What can be said more? This game is a classic, so writing much more stuff won't be necessary. There won't be added anything more than what has been already mentioned in many other reviews. I can only say that I highly recommend S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl. It's definitely one of the best and the most original shooters that still, despite being quite old (this game was released in 2007, after all), can bring a lot of fun to many players.

I also recommend checking out many mods that are availble for Shadow of Chernobyl. If you don't like to play with modifications, then I really recommend at least installing Zone Reclamation Project mod. It doesn't change the game much, almost not at all, however it provides a lot of bugfixes.

That being said, I can only add one thing in the end of this review: see you in the Zone, stalker!

I'll just write a short review here since I started to have a go again:

It's a half open-world (different areas which unlock in time) survival shooter. You have limited carrying capacity, EVERYTHING has weight, and you constantly need to be on the lookout for radiation and anomalies, which are strange phenomena that will kill you if you do not pay attention. Your mission is simple: "Kill Strelok". But on the way to your goal you will find tons of hostile (and not so hostile) factions who will kill you in a heartbeat if you don't pay attention. Seriously, the game is quite brutal from the start and even with high level gear you can die in a moment if you don't look out. But that is also part of the excitement: The thick atmosphere keeps you on your toes at all times.
Furthermore, there is equipment decay, which means that nothing will last forever.... Which is why I'd like you to introduce you to STALKER Complete: It's a mod which - unlike many others - leaves the base game mostly untouched, while improving graphics, fixing bugs, and adding one great feature: The ability to repair equipment. That way, you can keep your favourite items as long as you like without ever having to worry about losing them. I highly recommend it, as it greatly enriches the experience of the game (Of course, if you're into this sort of thing, you can still install the mod but ignore the repair feature).
Download it here: https://www.moddb.com/mods/stalker-complete-2009

P.S.: In case of shadows looking weird https://steamcommunity.com/app/4500/discussions/0/846964363995893047/

I've completed STALKER: Shadow of Chernobyl a few times since I purchased it back in- I want to say 2011, maybe 2012. I just completed it a fifth time, this time getting the canon ending again, except this time I did it on the hardest difficulty, which was a little challenging. While the graphics haven't aged well, the story is just as good as the first time I played it. I wasn't using any mods and somehow it only crashed on me once my entire playthrough.

I don't want to post any spoilers regardless of how old the game is, but I do recommend playing through this game at least once or twice. Easiest difficulty or the hardest, it doesn't matter to me, just give it a chance. I think you'll find yourself interested in the people you meet along the way, the factions, the mutants, and you may even find yourself getting immersed in the scenery that is the zone. You might even find yourself chuckling at the kind of jank that these semi-open world environments can create on a whim, too.

Does Shadow of Chernobyl have buttery smooth gameplay and execution, or even good graphics? Not exactly. But what it does have is a sense of atmosphere and fear that's hard to beat, resulting in your butthole being thoroughly clenched for a good chunk of the game. In the above ground sections, the mix of enemies and anomalies will keep you on your toes, and when you venture underground or into dark science labs, the game kicks it up a notch by becoming pure and effective horror. The sense of mystery draws you into the story, and never lets up.

Depending on the difficulty you play in, this isn't a game where you can carelessly approach combat encounters, otherwise you will die repeatedly. I played on Stalker (a.k.a. Normal) and had to adjust by being methodical and careful with my approach, using cover smartly, engaging one enemy at a time. Resources can become scarce if you're careless.

In fact, my main criticism was that towards the end, when you enter the point of no return, if you're low on healing and radiation-curing items like I was, the last section of the game becomes a real nightmare to deal with. What could have taken a well stocked player maybe 30 minutes to an hour to beat, took me nearly 3 hours of trial and error. Not enough of a reason to dislike the game, but new players should watch out for it.

Overall very worth it, even for someone that never played the STALKER games until recently like I did.

Being a Far Cry fan, this game was initially a disappointment. The further I progressed the more addicting it became. Granted, it is an older game so one has to compare apples to apples.  That said , the game has it's pro's and cons. 
Pros: 
The AI in this game is nothing like I have experienced before. The enemy are smart and unpredictable. At times they swarm you and at other times they are sneaky and will wait until you pass them. They don't kill easy. Head shots are best. 
Has a good story line, but that is subjective to the player.
Plenty of supplies abound . You're going to need them. 
Has a fast save feature so one doesn't have to redo the entire sequence. Gonna need those too. Save often. 
Alone those lines, you can save multiple saves and if you don't like the progress, can go back to the auto saves.
Cons
Poor weapons to start. Have to come quite a distance before you get some decent ones. 
You have a weight limit so you will be dumping a lot. 
Too many side missions to distract and some are on timers.
I got spoiled on fast travel locations. There are none here. There are levels and when one has to return to a specific place they will be fighting their way back. Gets tedious. 
The PDA and Map could be better. Hard to follow.

All in all, not bad. Mostly because it was on sale and runs well on my older graphics card. 4 out of 5 for me.

This is a pretty good game riddled with bugs.
I played using the zrp mod (which mainly fixes bugs in the vanilla game without altering it), and yet in my 21 hours of gameplay I spent a not trivial amount of time trying to work around several problems.
The first major problem I encountered was that trying to start a new game would crash at the starting cutscene EVERY SINGLE TIME. I tried looking for solutions online (none worked), tried skipping it (crash), tried removing the mod (it got even worse), and in the end I managed to 'clear' the first cutscene by playing around with the graphic settings and finding a configuration that did not lead to a crash.
The second major problem occurred every time I started the game for the first time in a gaming session and loaded a savefile (all savefiles had this problem). The game would appear to be 'fine' for a few seconds, then the game freezes and crashes shortly after. I found no actual solution to this problem other than restarting the game an average of 3 to 4 times, after which the game managed to survive without crashing, allowing me to play it for as long as I didn't close it (in which case I would have to repeat the cycle of start->crash->restart again up to 4 times).
These 2 were the major problems I encountered. There were also some minor problems (enemies attempting to shoot you through walls when there is clearly no line of sight, an npc that you have to escort that decides to get stuck on a door and at the same time 'jams' that very door with his own body making it impossible to go back inside and help him out, a few occasions of the audio bugging out, etc...), but these are 'manageable' at least.
You might ask me, after all of these problems, why am I recommending the game if I had such a bad time with it? The answer is: it is worth it. 
I love this type of game.
The game encourages you to be precise with your shots, to not be a loot goblin (limited amount of inventory space + big debuff in stamina consumption if you carry a bit more than the limit), and to progress in the game (better gear and artifacts the more you go north). I actually think that the secondary optional missions are almost always superfluous since you get much better rewards by just progressing in the main story and they don't seem to add anything to the plot.
The story is peculiar and made me go from 'weird' to 'crazy stuff' to 'wtf is going on' by the end.
I love the mood that many locations have, especially the 'darker' ones (I don't want to spoil anything).
I give this game a nice 7.5/10. Without all the bugs it would have been much better.

As someone who actually slept on this title for years and years and knowing it would be a game I would enjoy its taken me all the way to 2022 to play this cult classic. Having thoroughly enjoyed games in the similar vein such as System Shock 2, older thief titles etc it took a case of COVID for me to give this a chance and I must say colour me surprised I really enjoyed this game. Definetly a game of its time with no fast travel lots of survival mechanics and walking around a huge amount, its also an incredibly steep learning curve and the start of the game is borderline unfair, getting hold of some god guns and armour is essential. But anyone great title really enjoyed it through the lense of a few generations ago, AI is on point a lot as well, looking forward to the announced sequel later this/next year.

(dont mid the fake played time I have at least 200 hours of play on this gem),  such a great game  but to enjoy it at full you MUST get the mod pack "Memories of the Zone"  trust me its a full  fix and overhaul to the game without change the original source.
Copides and pasted from the modpack webpage:

the mod contains the following:

- OGSR x64 engine for enhanced GFX and performance (Note: the mod uses an older version currently).
- Zone Reclamation Project for further bug fixes.
- Absolute Nature texture pack.
- Absolute Structures texture pack.
- Photorealistic Zone 2 texture pack.
- Original Weapons Renewal 3 for better weapon animations, textures and models.
- STALKER Weather Overhauled v3 for enhanced atmosphere and climate.

+ a number of tweaks, additions and personal fixes (for example, working EAX without the need for a sound card! Try it out, its great).

In addition, there are various Gameplay, Sound and Visual addons available in the Optional folder for you to customize the experience further to your taste. Want to be as vanilla as possible? Going for your first playthrough? The base install will suit you just fine! The only optional I would suggest then is the Clear sky Sidorovich. Otherwise, it's all up to you! Options have been provided to give returning players some extra challenge without going over the top.

It's janky, rough-looking, and still has bugs. But it's a solidly fun survival-light/sci-fi/horror/shooter with pretty satisfying gun play. You take missions from various other Stalkers, from primary missions to small jobs like clearing out mutants from an area or finding items and returning them. There are even some dynamic missions that can appear during travel, such as helping out a Stalker camp under siege by bandits. All of this building toward one of seven different possible endings. Meanwhile you traverse the maps and scrounge around for loot (and there's quite a bit of it), and manage inventory.

I think the thing that makes this game special is the thing you see a lot of people mentioning: Atmosphere. It's gloomy, desolate. Gray clouds often rolling across the horizon. Sometimes you hear the call of a mutated creature in the distance, or a man screaming and gunshots popping. The music is low key and really lends to that atmosphere. During underground missions/exploration, the game can become full-fledged horror.

This first entry in the Stalker series is genuinely unique.

The Industrial Revolution and its consequences have been a disaster for the human race. They have greatly increased the life-expectancy of those of us who live in “advanced” countries, but they have destabilized society, have made life unfulfilling, have subjected human beings to indignities, have led to widespread psychological suffering (in the Third World to physical suffering as well) and have inflicted severe damage on the natural world. The continued development of technology will worsen the situation. It will certainly subject human being to greater indignities and inflict greater damage on the natural world, it will probably lead to greater social disruption and psychological suffering, and it may lead to increased physical suffering even in “advanced” countries. The industrial-technological system may survive or it may break down. If it survives, it MAY eventually achieve a low level of physical and psychological suffering, but only after passing through a long and very painful period of adjustment and only at the cost of permanently reducing human beings and many other living organisms to engineered products and mere cogs in the social machine. Furthermore, if the system survives, the consequences will be inevitable: There is no way of reforming or modifying the system so as to prevent it from depriving people of dignity and autonomy. If the system breaks down the consequences will still be very painful. But the bigger the system grows the more disastrous the results of its breakdown will be, so if it is to break down it had best break down sooner rather than later. We therefore advocate a revolution against the industrial system. This revolution may or may not make use of violence; it may be sudden or it may be a relatively gradual process spanning a few decades. We can’t predict any of that. But we do outline in a very general way the measures that those who hate the industrial system should take in order to prepare the way for a revolution against that form of society. This is not to be a POLITICAL revolution. Its object will be to overthrow not governments but the economic and technological basis of the present society. In this article we give attention to only some of the negative developments that have grown out of the industrial-technological system. Other such developments we mention only briefly or ignore altogether. This does not mean that we regard these other developments as unimportant. For practical reasons we have to confine our discussion to areas that have received insufficient public attention or in which we have something new to say. For example, since there are well-developed environmental and wilderness movements, we have written very little about environmental degradation or the destruction of wild nature, even though we consider these to be highly important.

I don't mind the crashes, with the (deceivingly shallow) ambiance and setting striking a chord with my aesthetic preferences but I have to drop this on account of the balance. Normal mode feels like what Nightmare mode would be on most games in the genre and while I thoroughly embrace a challenge, Stalker is all unfair and no fun.

You don't really notice it in "dungeons" when it's only you and a couple of enemies at a time but even then the enemy AI can (and will!) spot you from miles away and hit you with pinpoint accuracy (even behind cover!) when the weapons they're using (which you can later grab) cannot hit a sitting boulder if it's farther than ten inches away when you are wielding them.

Upgraded weapons, 500% health increase through anomalies, sturdy armor - all the RPG mechanics available at your disposal and enemies will still nearly one-shot you from far away if they score a headshot, even when you're behind cover. Then you can empty an entire magazine on a single enemy, aiming for the head and you're lucky if that kills one of them.

Again, this is not all the time but [i]so many[/i] areas of this game, both mandatory and optional, are you against a dozen enemies coming at you sometimes two at a time, sometimes all of them in a wave or two - this is when the AI cheating becomes painfully obvious and you need to cheese a fight by using a dozen bandages and med-kits while in active combat. The game will make the baffling decision of sometimes giving you like, two friendly allies - who every time will go down within 20 seconds of an enemy wave showing up.

It's terrible. This is fine as a Nightmare mode but not Normal mode, even for someone like me who in 2 hours of play got a whole bunch of some of the rarest Steam Achievements in a popular arena-shooter on Steam - and while sure, Stalker is much more of a slow-paced military shooter than an arena-shooter, my complaint here is not about the difficulty but the inherent advantage (cheating) the AI has even when you have better weapons, armor and artifacts, while you have to fight against dozens of AI units on your own, frankly all of the time.

Some of these areas are optional, yes but Stalker is a largely linear game so these optional areas are meant to be balanced for your current gear, not something you "keep in mind" and come back to later on when you're stronger. This isn't an open-world game. And, again many aren't optional and the gameplay and balance is still the very same. It gets tiring very quickly.

The aesthetic of the game hit close to home for me and the graphics and soundtrack do their job more then well-enough to deliver one-of-a-kind ambiance to put Bethesda's Fallout games to utter shame. The problem is that it's all skin-deep: NPCs serve only as bullet sponges and item buyers; lore comes at a paragraph-worth for each 10 hours of play; the world is dull and void (which borders on parody once you start opening containers in any area that has them, only to find literally all of them completely empty).

If Bethesda Fallouts feel hollow compared to the Black Isle Fallouts, Stalker feels hollow even compared to the former. At least Fallout 3 and 4 have unique, interesting locations with great care put into environmental storytelling and even easter eggs - sure there's a lot of filler and reused assets but Stalker's world feels like the cutting-room floor of Bethesda's content. While the ambiance is sublime, realistic and dark, the world itself is a barren and ugly wasteland.

The most you get out of the world are scavenger hunts you unlock when looting certain enemies - and that's great, really but it fails miserably as an alternative for an interesting world with unique locations and mechanics to discover. Artifacts (anomalies) are literally scattered on the ground by the side of the road. Very few are placed intelligently in a way to reward world exploration and almost all that are, are just the hidden stashes that I mention.

With only combat as the "fully-fledged" content here, the complete lack of proper balance hurts that much more. If the combat was serviceable I would recommend the game for the world exploration alone but with one being deeply flawed and the other being terribly shallow, there really isn't anything here for anyone looking for actual substance to sink their teeth into.

And if someone says "what about the horror", I am literally going to scream. Stalker can be tense and dark and moody but it's not a horror game, it's a military shooter going through an edgy phase, is all. Resident Evil and Silent Hill could get my hands to shake and force me to take a break to catch my breath - Stalker can give you a scare or two but in general it can't even up my heartbeat in its darkest moments... except maybe in the befuddlement  of restarting a gunfight for the twentieth time when only luck, not skill or tactics, will decide whether I win or not against normal-mode AI that are better at FPS than any human I've dueled.

Pro tip: turn off music in the settings for full S.T.A.L.K.E.R. immersion.

I really love anything relating to the Chernobyl meltdown, it fascinates me.  S.T.A.L.K.E.R had been on my gaming bucket list for a while, and I finally took the time to get into the series.

It's a good game, I enjoyed it.  It is a bit rough around the edges, which is understandable since it's the beginning of the series made by a small studio back in the 2000s.  It feels sort of like if Fallout 1 was made into a 3D title, while not as deep in terms of dialogue choices.  I really wish you could get some kind of backpack to increase carry weight, because I found myself constantly going over the carry limit. Even on Stalker difficulty, which is this game's "normal," you die very quickly.  Weapons operate realistically and have very poor accuracy.  Your weapon will jam after you've hit an enemy with a couple of shots, and they will blast you in the face with no remorse to punish this.  Most of the time that's fun, sometimes it's really annoying depending on how much patience you have to keep reloading that quick save.  Thankfully, the game doesn't overstay its welcome if you're just doing the main story, so this hardcore difficulty won't become a migraine if you're a seasoned gamer.

The story's ending went right over my head.  I thought I understood generally where it was going, but the end cutscene throws a curveball and I really didn't understand what it meant.  I feel like a bit of a dunce but they really don't spell it out to you.  I'm honestly not sure if this is due to poor writing or because I missed something.  To YouTube I go! ------ Edit: I wasn't aware there were multiple endings until I looked into it.  Apparently I got the "you did too well" ending, which is kind of funny in retrospect but also a bit weird since the ending is received as punishment for being wealthy.  I don't like that the true ending was hidden from me just because I had a certain quantity money (about 100k).  I mostly stuck to looting, only buying ammo in a pinch. The game doesn't really push that saving money is bad.  If anything, it encourages it.  Weapons and armor are extremely expensive, and the goal of a S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is to find wealth and riches.  So, that gets thumbs down from me despite it being cheeky with proper context.

The game's levels are well crafted, especially [spoiler] Pripyat and Chernobyl Power Plant [/spoiler].  Walking through those areas was really, really cool.

If you have the patience for hardcore FPS gameplay where you die a lot, I'd recommend S.T.A.L.K.E.R for its great atmosphere and engaging world. Just remember to practice thorough save scumming.

Did you ever hear the tragedy of Darth Plagueis The Wise?
I thought not. It’s not a story the Jedi would tell you. It’s a Sith legend. Darth Plagueis was a Dark Lord of the Sith, so powerful and so wise he could use the Force to influence the midichlorians to create life… He had such a knowledge of the dark side that he could even keep the ones he cared about from dying. The dark side of the Force is a pathway to many abilities some consider to be unnatural. He became so powerful… the only thing he was afraid of was losing his power, which eventually, of course, he did. Unfortunately, he taught his apprentice everything he knew, then his apprentice killed him in his sleep. Ironic. He could save others from death, but not himself.

Picked the bundle up on sale cuz it looked like an interesting shooter. It's extremely fun and well worth the full price they ask, but even better on sale. Here's the TLDR breakdown, tho i haven't beaten it yet, I feel like I am at least half way thru.

Pros:
- surprisingly immersive
- interesting story
- Classic weaponry 
- RPG like in that you can play like a jerk or a hero who solves all the people's problems
- Huge Modding community
- PC controls feel great and required minimal set up or keybinding

Cons:
- Weapons are very inaccurate early on but later weapons do/feel much better
- Autosave frequency is ludicrously spaced out so make your own saves, there is a quicksave/load
- I had 1 crash and 1 game breaking bug so far (dropped a piece of armor and it shoved me, trapped into the floor) both only set me back a few minutes so take that how you will
- older graphics but if this is a deal breaker on a fun game than are you really a gamer?

All in all a very fun game that's well worth the $20 or whatever they ask and even better for $5 or whatever I paid (terrible memory + zero fact checking = 100% accurate as far as I can tell). Seriously tho any cons I can get over and I can't wait to play more of this, the other 2 older titles in the bundle, and Stalker 2 coming out Dec/2022.

An absolute classic, even over a decade later I can still find myself repeatedly drawn back into this trilogy. It might be janky, and the graphics might be dated by today's standards, but hell if it doesn't cook up some great atmosphere and fun, sufficiently challenging gameplay. There's fun gunplay, surprise firefights, environmental anomalies beyond physical description, creatures twisted by an omniscient psychic alien force, a sky that wants you dead, and this is all not even mentioning the lore and storytelling which pays homage to the classic science fiction novel Roadside Picnic. If you are a fan of horror, PVE, shooters, and science fiction, don't hesitate to throw the guys at GSC a few bucks. You will not regret it.

I played this when it came out and back in those days and still have the metal box disc version, the game was actually very heavy to run on the hardware of those days so it was even way more janky then today. 
Now i can say this game aged very good and its great to run it on todays hardware and it runs without any problem on Windows10. 
Highly recommended and there is not many games out there like this one. 
Controls are less tanky and graphics are much better then Fallout. 
Use quicksave allot if you dont wanna lose allot of progress because the game does tend to crash once in a while just like it always did back in the days. 
Also because of the hardware back in those days it was very laggy and janky to play it and now it really is the way it was meant to be played and much more fluid and enjoyable with full antialiasing and max anisotropic filtering it actually is a beautiful game for its time and still pretty damn creepy at moments.
