This game has a steep curve to climb over. I nearly gave up the first quarter of the game simply because the story moves super slowly and is pretty dull. Sticking with the outdated gameplay and graphics was well worth it as I approached the half way mark. 

STALKER is an amazing game well worth the trouble of putting up with. I fell in love with the mechanics as I realized I am supposed to be suffering with inventory management and not in a Bethesda like way. This game tries to mix fantasy with reality and does both super well.

I highly recommend playing STALKER if you're looking for a compelling universe, story and gameplay to immerse yourself into. Supposedly the game can be completed in 8 hours though it took me 44. Perhaps some of that could have been idling or my dilly dallying with optional side quests. The side quests are pretty pointless unless you enjoy the mechanics of the gun fights. You won't need them for cash as the game provides you plenty of loot along the way.

Don't take my word for it. The game is cheap on sale and off sale. Try it and give it a good six hours before you give up!

I came to this game with very little expectation. The whole series was on sale for the cost of a cheap gas station sandwich, I've heard of the title before, and it has really awesome reviews.

After playing it I can see why it's so beloved, and it's so impressive to think something like this came out in 2007. I'm also going to be putting it down after 4 hours, because I can also see just how much games have improved in 15 years. The UI is wonky, the AI is silly, and the gun-play is unresponsive. 

Worst of all, and probably the gravest sin any game can commit - the danger in the world is unexplained and ethereal. Of course I know to avoid the [spoiler]giant floating mystical wizard-like weird-orb-thingies that make my screen go fuzzy and beep and then explode and hurt me, but I don't know what they are or why they're there (besides a vague presumption of[b] super spooky [/b]radiation even though they don't set off your geiger counter).[/spoiler] What just ended my fun was a very interesting interaction with a [spoiler]humanoid entity at the end of a tunnel that blocked my path, did 1/3rd my hp in damage every 3 seconds by putting me into a repeating cutscene of zooming in on its (ironically ethereal) face, and appeared to be immune to bullets... [/spoiler] although in fairness, most enemies in this game act like they're immune to bullets until they just spontaneously drop to the ground dead. I died and reloaded about 4 times, dying the same way with zero indication from the game of what I was doing wrong or what I should do to either get past the enemy or kill it before I realized I hadn't had fun in about 30 minutes.

TLDR: Shit aged homie, we're a lot better at making games now-a-days! Maybe fun for the nostalgia guys, but there's a lot wrong with the game.
Simply put > this isn't for me.

Honestly a great way to get into the series if you know nothing about it. Can be a bit of an Experience if you are used to other FPS games where you are near invincible at times. This game is not a merciful world, you can die of many things and at any point. The world, even if destroyed and barren, is full of life. Sitting amidst the fire and listening to a Stalker play the guitar gave me the unique feeling that this experience is, mostly, about those moments. No one enters the Zone without, somehow, seieng beauty in it. For me, the beauty was that.

I do hope people play this and have moments of that type of significance, that whatever drew them to the Zone shines through the dread surrounding the place.

[u]Story:[/u] Main storyline will take 10 hours to get through, but there are also plenty of optional side quests (mostly cash rewards) that can consume hours, as well as sheer hours spent on exploration in atmospheric, immersive world.
[u]Gameplay:[/u] The game slides between post-apocalyptic science fiction thriller, nerve-singing survival horror shooter with very realistic weapons and exploration of abandoned territories as well as complicated human behavior keeping you constantly in a state of hesitant wonder.
[u]Graphics:[/u] The graphics, though dated in places, builds a sense of enchanting mystique of realistic post-apocalyptic surroundings. Very realistic sunrises, rainstorms, and NPC battles occurring outside the sphere of player involvement produce a disarming atmospheric cohesiveness. Attention to detail in all the game's cityscapes and fields triggers a subtle sense of familiarity.
[u]Sound/Music/Voice:[/u] Sounds are quite good, particularly the startling cries of the various mutants and the piercing ambient howls that float across The Zone from time to time. Weapon sounds do a great job of immersing you in the environment, effectively conveying a sense of the firearms' power. You'll find unexpected extras packed in as well, most notably a surprising amount of guitar songs and jokes that you can hear when you sit with other NPC stalkers in front of a flaming barrel.

[u]Optimization:[/u] Good (old game), runs well on low-end PC.
[u]Bugs:[/u]  Some bugs, crashed a few times.

[u]Singleplayer:[/u] Yes (solo only).
[u]Multiplayer:[/u] Not worth it (very unpopular).
[u]Player Count:[/u] Low.
[u]Pay to Win:[/u] No (no DLC, no lootboxes, no microtransactions).

[u]Comment:[/u] Played with mod - STALKER Complete 2009.

Worth playing, but it is very much a product of its time. Playing on Win10, I had to pick the beta (1.007) to be able to use the mouse and keyboard in the menu, and had to install the ZRP mod (Zone Reclamation Project) in order to fix some annoyances. The first and last levels are ridiculous in terms of difficulty, but the other parts are way more balanced. This is mostly because you start with awful weapons that can barely hit or kill anything, and the last level suffers from "we gotta make the last level hard and intense" syndrome. Despite all this, it's a fun and atmospheric game, very reminiscent of Fallout, F.E.A.R. and Half-Life.

I haven't felt adrenaline like this for a really long time. Just got done with the section with the scientists which, pro tip, buy the shotgun cause you'll be fighting pretty creepy mutants in close quarters. 

The atmosphere is oozing and the gunplay is janky at first but really tightens up when you spend your life savings on a gun that shoots 7.62x54 rounds (SVU for this kid) and a handgun that shoots .45 rounds (USP). 

If your having trouble with muddy textures and bugs then get the starter pack mod. It has the zone reclamation project installed which fixes the issues and provides a smooth experience. 0 CTD on my playthrough. 

Long story short: if you like RPG type exploring games with a tactical edge then play S.T.A.L.K.E.R. 

Ps, I'm playing on Master and it keeps the tension high. Luckily you always die from mistakes you've made and not stupid B.S. (screw you Souls types auto tracking). Take things slow when enemies are on your map, use the lean feature in cover and death should be a rare occurrence. The A.I. can't seem to aim that well when you're not standing in the open.

An extremely engaging and exciting game that gives you a lot of options, although somewhat random, for different weapons and playstyles. It gets better as you progress, but it can be a bit overwhelming or underwhelming depending on the situation. I will say it's a hard game to follow the story of and is non-linear for most of it's gameplay until the end when you get forced to commit to the story and then have no way to realistically go back and retrace your steps like in the old game. It's kind of annoying that it throws a lot of stuff at you you can't expect, like randomly enemies with psionic powers that never come back in the game, or random situations you have to memorize but will never need to understand again, and situations with seemingly unlimited amounts of enemies you can barely fight through out of nowhere. Things just... sort of happen in the game and you have to deal with it. Make sure to save and save often as you can die from as little as one hit in this game even with the best armor.  

Monolith by the end is an exciting challenge, but it's obnoxious in that you don't get a chance to get more ammunition, get new armor or move backwards, with moving backwards more or less killing you with radiation or sheer numbers of guys, and the fact the game expects you to move forwards, so you are stuck finishing the game on whatever you brought. It's really frustrating in many ways in that ammunition hardly ever drops and you find yourself either getting the wrong ammunition, or not enough and are always just scraping by, and if you store up a lot of ammunition you run in to weight issues. You learn to hope to find supplies along the way, but man the game gives you just enough to complete it which is hair-splitting, and too much in other areas. It's also a bit annoying that certain options are never explored, for example there is only one SMG and one of the most common ammunition types in the game, or 9mm makarov, is useless outside of a few pistols rather than a makarov submachine gun showing up. It would be really simple to combine 9mm makarov or 9mm parabellum ammunition together as the same ammunition which would also be realistic as the russians eventually switched to 9mm x 19mm as their main ammunition, and having to sift between 5.45mm which dissapears entirely and then comes back right at the end is more than a little frustrating. I left my best 5.45mm rifle behind and could never go back and get it which had me pulling my hair out the whole time. The game forces you to carry everything you need but gives you no vehicle or cart or something to carry it, which is annoying. You can also only sell weapons to three vendors in the game which makes it hard to grind. It's overall very tedious and time consuming to get certain things done in the game while others are lightning fast. You end up losing access to a certain type of ammunition choice in the game, only for it to come back in huge droves and you lose access to what you just switched to with no idea this would happen, meaning your stockpiling of resources is basically useless, and you end up having to fight an insanely huge amount of guys. 

The weight limit is both the most fun and frustrating part of the game. It's an exhilarating experience, but only in that you are always just around the corner for death and are fighting tooth and nail the whole time. I wouldn't change it ,but I will admit it had me extremely frustrated, more than other games at certain points. Most the bugs seem to be worked out in the game and I think the updates have done this. I'd like to explore all the options in an easier format with more time, which is why it's a bit painful you don't get to do this. By the end, it's actually a bit disappointing. It's also annoying the game changes things on you with no notice. All in all, I'd have to say it's one of my favorite survival-horror games of all times, with a very realistic and fun feel to the combat that's honestly very fresh, and with a lot of weapons and equipment and a lot to explore in the game. I imagine you could play it through a few times and still not find hidden goodies that barely pop up in the game. All in all, I'd give a positive review, but make sure you you know what you're getting in to, it is a very, very frustrating and addicting game, which will make you go through hours of it in the first week. I played it almost 10 hours a day every day for a week. Definitely better than fall-out.

Хороша гра

OVERVIEW 

S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Shadow of Chernobyl is a post-apocalyptic after explosion on Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant ,CNPP. Bringing moody, survival  and no chance to bring humanity back.  video game also about a guy who lost his memory and found around a death truck, doing his mission to kill a guy named Strelok from his PDA..  

THE GOOD

The story is great, it brings multiple endings based on the way you play. The atmosphere is logical where science friction and modern met after the explosion in real life reactor number four CNPP. To make this game more interesting, around 2006 the second explosion occurred due to secret experiments from laboratories around the exclusion zone. Anomalies can be found here. A articats brings you power and more value than your life. Since then, The people who were in the zone called themselves as S.T.A.L.K.E.R.  They are doing it for money, for a specific purpose or to make a new life here. At least weapons still use bullets to kill people instead of lasers in 2006. There are a lot of secrets that are hidden and never been told unless you figure it out by yourself. Basically a  door that brings you to explore more about the S.T.A.L.K.E.R Series. 

THE BAD 

Bugs, it is necessary to install mod. At least to reduce instability and bugs in the game.. ZRP mod is recommended.  Enough said.


THE UGLY

The gunplay is hard, you’ll die more even though on easy mode. It's necessary to have high end weapons and armour to beat many enemies especially on the final mission. Overpowered  gear is not a sin but crucial. Your enemies will kill you no matter what you did even though both of you are fighting against mutants. You’ll easily fatigue because of the horde. It is not a zombie horde, but deadly mutants and enemies. It is not weird when you are fighting more than 20 enemies at the same location and fighting it again at different locations after escaping from that horde location. Let's say, you are escaping Agroprom after fighting a military attack and going to Agroprom underground, you will fight another attack from a group of Bandit and Bloodsuckers. Be sure to mentally and physically prepared before jumping in this game. 

CONCLUSION 
The game is wonderful, I recommend this game if you are interested on survival first person shooter genre. 

TIPS 

Collect as much as possible the artifacts around anomalies, stashes and do optional tasks to get more money. Sells artifacts to Professor Sakharov in Yantar Bunker. Then, buy an exoskeleton suit or any equivalent suit from barkeep and use some artefacts to gain advantages before entering Pripyat . Get weapons from dead Freedom, Duty or Monolith to get high end ammo and guns. Pickup gauss rifle if possible. Do guide mission and doctor mission then follow up those missions to get a good ending. Loot for each dead body.

When I first beat this game back in 2007, it was in my top 3 games of all time. After 14 years it still is. For reasons I'll never quite understand this game isn't for everyone. The good thing is though, you'll know within 10 minutes if The Zone is for you or if you're an idiot. Buy it and give it a shot.

This game has an omnipresent atmosphere that's heavy and foreboding yet not overly oppressive... you'll never want to escape this game, let's put it that way. It's very balanced in that regard. You feel isolated and in danger most of the time but also at peace, surrounded by beautiful places to explore. You can play at your own pace and approach most situations from multiple angles. It isn't a huge open world, but a series of interconnected areas that are big and varied enough to make you feel small. With no vehicles or fast travel you are encouraged to explore, which is good, because there is plenty going on in The Zone without it feeling crowded. There are also lots of weapons and items to find that actually offer a pretty varied experience, so take your time and look around. Check anomalies and talk to people. You will have no trouble looking for (or avoiding) fights and there are plenty of side quests to keep you busy. The weather and time cycles keep it varied too.

Enemy AI is actually pretty good with use of cover and lots of movement. You'll find that you're being flanked quite often if you don't maintain situational awareness. There are mechanics you can take advantage of, sure, but overall the combat is engaging and fun. Taking cover, having good aim, and ammo management are important. Luckily you can loot bodies.

Don't expect cutting edge graphics. Rather, soak up the charm of the dated visuals because they were done right with plenty of foliage, decent lighting, and excellent building models and textures. Take in the whole picture and it's beautiful from beginning to end. I recommend playing it vanilla your first time, save for one mod: Increased grass draw distance. After that I recommend re-playing with Autumn Aurora 2.1 as it improves the overall appearance, doesn't change the core game much, and performs very well.

S.T.A.L.K.E.R Shadow of Chernobyl is very, very dreadful in the best way possible.
It actually gets quite scary in some sections.

 The gunplay does look extremely janky and the controls are quite cumbersome, and it is, but trust me, as soon as you get the hang of things, this game gets very intense during some gunfights in old ruins and underground exploration skirmishes.

Set the game to highest difficulty. It makes accuracy higher or all the weapons in the game, which makes it a bit more manageable. What's seen as the lowest difficulty is actually the hardest difficulty, because you have the hardest time hitting anything.

The mechanics are very realistic mechanically. (not visually. This game came out in 2007 after all.)
Get used to crouching behind cover, leaning out of corners to avoid enemy fire, compensate for bullet drop for targets over long distances, and tossing grenades around dark corridors to get rid of potential human and supernatural threats. 

Play slowly. Tactically. Assess potential threats from a distance with your binoculars. Always keep a plan in your enemy before, during, and after skirmishes. Grab weapons from enemy corpses and unload them, you are going to need the extra ammunition as resources are scarce in the Zone. Simply being inside of the Zone gives you a feeling of dread unlike any other place you've been to. As you explore it, you will see some things, horrific entities and anomalies that will question your will to keep pressing forward to Pripyat.

This game is really fun, but it's also quite repetitive. This is somewhat deterred by the excellent AI. The AI being smart (when GSC's dynamic A-Life AI isn't bugging out), makes for some really dynamic and engrossing combat situations. Sometimes, when you kill something and leave for a little while, you'll see a dog or a mutant from a nearby nest feasting and dragging that corpse along the ground. Sometimes, after killing a patrolling enemy soldier on the road, the military outpost will send small groups of soldiers along the road to try and find you. Sometimes, after killing the S.T.A.L.K.E.R.S in a certain area, you'll see a lot more bandits in that area afterwards, they might even take over that old ruin that the S.T.A.L.K.E.R.S were bunkered down at.

The AI was groundbreaking for the time, absolutely, there's no doubt about it, but the gameplay hardly has very much variety aside from getting into exploring, getting into gunfights, and getting the crap scared out of you occasionally.

Hopefully, S.T.A.L.K.E.R 2 improves on the variety aspect for gameplay with GSC's A-Life 2.0 AI and a few more mechanics that make the game a bit deeper.

7/10

"Heyyy, stonye boosh!" and "Don't just stand there, I said come in!" echoed around the Marked One's brain, relentlessly and needlessly.

The Marked One had made it all the way to the "special ending" - a scene as romantic as it was welcoming (so, not at all), and after defeating countless foes, finally thought he had cracked the code and everything, kind of, was starting to make sense. The mysterious being spoke so much sense, and the Marked One, with every word, felt like his life was changing.

Unfortunately for the Marked One, it was not due to being enlightened by his newfound knowledge.

Instead, it was due to hunger.

That's right, the Marked One had neglected to eat before "the grand speech" that this mysterious being was granting him, and, with no previous "save point", the Marked One had a perilous challenge. Could he make it through all of what was the mysterious being was saying, before meeting an untimely fate due to starvation?

Well unfortunately the answer is: no. The Marked One could not and this became the sad fate of one of the most talented men to ever grace The Zone. He had faced countless Monolith, bandits, Military and hordes of mutants, but it was this chamber that the Marked One would call his final resting place. The talking and hunger were simply too much.



In conclusion, if you're looking for a great wasteland survival simulator set in a period of artifact hoarding and sausage bartering, this is the game for you. 

You can figure out for yourself if you like the graphics and audio or not, I have no problems with either. If you won't be playing with all of the artifacts that boost your speed, and a combat shotgun, be prepared for a less fun time (and if you don't spam antirads and hotdogs while running through extremely radioactive areas, are you really playing?).

Plus, the AI loves to swarm you shotgun wielding aimbots, so be prepared to sit and cower behind an explosive barrel while the oddly hench Controller mutant arrives. Don't worry, you'll learn to stonye boosh and throw screws into anomalies in no time...you did remember to take cover before quicksaving while in a blowout, right?
It bring old good day to me. 10/10
yes

S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Shadow of Chernobyl is a cult classic for those who dig the Russian/Ukrainian aesthetics coupled with some minor RPG and survival elements. Visually the game can be dated looking and same applies to the feeling of the game with it's controls and UI. To many new stalkers the game might come off as very weird, unappealing, or boring to people who start out for the first time. The atmosphere and world has a slow way of drawing you in slowly until you're deep into the game and it's setting.

The setting and atmosphere is definitely the strongest thing this game has. You explore the outskirts of Pripyat and the notorious Chernobyl NPP after a strange second disaster happens and alters the world and defies both science and reality itself with Anomalies and artifacts. The world is fairly decent sized and split into sectors. You'll explore most of them multiple times. The underground labs are probably some of the most horrifying experiences I've had in a long time with the sound design and darkness. 

The gameplay is probably the weakest part of the whole experience. Guns have a tendency to be inconsistent but scoped weapons reign supreme due to how long range engagements can me along with seeing where your bullet went. Bodyshots are easily shrugged off by even lowly bandits so headshots are essentially a must to win. Mutants on the other hand are either weak or bullet sponges. The player character no matter what difficulty is weak. You might have to resort to abundant use of quicksaves and some save scumming since the game is fairly difficult in some sections.

The economy in this game is fairly brutal meaning you'll have to do some jobs and grinding by taking artifacts, loot, and risking your own life to make small amounts of cash only to save up and blow it all on buying that expensive ass new suit with exoskeleton support that looks awesome. Different traders offer different prices for specific items, such as the ecologist paying top dollar for any artifacts or mutant pieces you bring them. However everything has durability meaning when you purchase anything be ready to chuck it away or sell the broken gear for a mere fraction of what you payed for before. The game is also not very friendly to loot hoarders with bullets and all other things that go into your inventory taking up weight. The game punishes you for stocking up on too much gear (such as having like 1000 extra AK rounds) you do not need basically forcing you to take the bare essentials.

Now let me get into the artifacts. These are a staple of the game's experience and what really makes this game from shiny silver to absolute gold. Artifacts are found in stashes you find locations for or inside an anomaly which will instantly eviscerate your character. These things are high risk high reward and you can easily find them with the naked eye. Not all artifacts are good or sell for much. A number of them are pretty much junk artifacts that irradiate your character or offer very little benefit however when you find something like maybe 4 moonlight artifacts you can pretty much sprint infinitely even when you're carrying too much. Some items can effect different aspects of the gameplay such as stopping bleeding, increased resistances, increased health, and radiation removal. A lot of these do come with downsides such as emitting radiation, making you weaker to specific attacks, and overall increasing the bleed out rate.

The story in this game is basically next to non-existent. Like it's there but at the same time it's really nothing special. I know I said the gameplay is the weakest part but I think I take that back now. There are 2 main endings with the one having sub endings based on what you did and yes there is a true canon ending if you go out of your way to figure it out.

NO FAST TRAVEL. Expect to do some walking and rationing your gear alongside avoiding fights from point A to point B if you have to.

I'd say S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Shadow of Chernobyl is a must play game. It might not be for everyone but it is definitely one of the best for what it is. Also if I find someone who calls this game series Russian Fallout I will borderline hurt them.

I have played for 18 hours and I have not even made it through X-18. This game is amazing. I am so in love. It is almost a perfect game for what I want. It has enough depth to not be boring but it isn't overly complex to the point it is overwhelming. 
The atmosphere is amazing and it can be genuinely very scary. There's really no major downsides, save for the bugs, or anomalies, as they say. Thankfully I am yet to have a huge bug, save for some mission objectives not properly showing as completed when I definitely completed the task.

My favorite thing about Stalker is the difficulty scaling. Basically, lower difficulty = more bullets that do less damage. For this reason, I am playing on Master difficulty. It really has not been that hard. Don't let people scare you off with their ravings about the game being too hard. It is hard, you can't play it like call of duty, but you just have to be smarter than your enemies. 
I personally think that a game where many enemies can die in one or two shots is genius. It makes you remember how squishy you and your fellow stalkers are. 

Only thing that's a little rough out of the box is the controls are very weirdly mapped, but this can be changed.

Play this game if you want to experience the day-to-day life of the average Ukranian.
Don't play this game if you're unprepared for glitches and dying a whole lot. But if you want to challenge yourself, enjoy a gloomy yet alive world, and a little bit more realistic combat, get this.

More than 14 years after STALKER was released, does it still hold up?   

I think so... But with caveats...

STALKER is one of those games that you've either already played it, or have always been intrigued to play it. Nobody would ever claim to have been uninterested by the premise.   The problem, as always, is that today we have an overload of survival horror RPG FPS's set in weird and wonderful places. You can play on zombie-infested islands, alien planets, chemical plants, the future, the past, alternative universes and many more. There's even a modern homage called, I think 'Chernobyl'...  So, why go back and play the ageing STALKER?  Quite simply: Curiosity, and the fact that it still stands up as a great game even today.

Firstly, I'll say that the game is large and very detailed for a game from 2007, but looks extremely antiquated now.   The matte textures, though, really allow the core soul of the game to shine through:  You're playing in the wasteland of a nuclear accident, left to rot and accumulate decades of decay.    In that, especially in the later levels set closer [spoiler]and in[/spoiler] to the nuclear power plant itself, it's wondrous to walk around and look at the frozen state of the CCCP of 1986.  Walking around a concrete soviet town, Pripyat, there's a wonderful sense of timeless wonder... How could people live in a concrete town like this?   Having seen East Berlin, it's all too easy to imagine life in Soviet times, dreary, fearful, bland.  

The other levels are also very well designed, and do their best to mask their limited size, placing hills, buildings and so forth in strategic places.   The deserted buildings are dilapidated in exactly the ways you'd expect, and exploring their ruins when surrounded by hostile enemies is extremely nerve wracking, but fun.

The sounds are good, and the game supports surround sound, which is very handy for figuring out where shots are coming from.  In "easy" mode, you might get one or two 'free' shots to work out where they are before you're bulls-eyed right between the eyes. In "normal" mode, if they see you first, you better be wearing armour, or the first shot will kill.  In hard mode, you need to see them first, or you're toast.     This game is NOT for the faint-hearted.  Even playing on 'easy' mode is a real challenge!     F5 (quicksave) is your friend!

The storyline is quite confusing, and it's very easy to get side-tracked.  There are some sidequests that have some world-altering abilities, such as clearing out an area of hostiles, bringing in friendlies, or making a faction hostile to you.   If you accidentally make a faction hostile you can make life quite hard for yourself.    While a legitimate thing to do in the game, making an enemy of one or both primary factions is tantamount to making it damn hard to finish the game.    It's best to be nice to everyone and not take jobs that are obviously going to annoy a faction.

So,  TL;DR time... What makes STALKER still worthwhile to play in the 2020's... Quite simply, only the STALKER games give you dozens of hours of tense, strategic game play in a setting quite unlike any other series.    It also have multiple endings which are quite well matched to what you do in the game.  

IF STALKER's on sale, grab it, and grab the Zone Reclamation Project mod for it to add quicksaves and level-specific saves, which are handy!

A great game in the fullest sense. In addition to being a great gun game, it has a wonderful moody--even mystical atmosphere. If you like scrounging in desolate fields and abandoned buildings with the fear of the next engagement in the back of your brain, this is the game for you. Many mods are available, but vanilla is excellent on its own. Only complaint is the lack of gender diversity. Just a bunch of bros broing with other bros. The game severely penalizes your aim while moving or spraying bullets and improves your aim when you crouch. I was hardly hitting anything until I learned this. Early game is rough so be prepared. You will likely die a lot until you acquire good gear so save often. I started on veteran difficulty but eventually bumped it up to master. Master is the recommended difficulty setting as it forces you to take enemies seriously, plan your attacks and utilize cover--which is what you signed up for. Despite this, it is not overly difficult or frustrating. I did not have prior experience playing keyboard and mouse FPSs and I'm doing just fine.

Guys, I have no idea, why y'all like this game. Right off the bat, you are thrown into the world, where nobody explains shit. You don't know, what you can and what you can't do, how to use medkit, whether you even have it or not. I had no idea I had a whole pistol and a knife until maybe the frist 30 minutes of this game. You don't understand, who your friends are, who your enemies are, whether helping others matter or not - nothing. The story is very unengaging.

The combat system sucks so much ass, it's unbelievable! The pistol does very little damage to the enemies, the headshots are useless, the bullets sometimes don't even reach them. And this game came 3 years after Hald Life 2 and 7 (!) years. 

The locations are absolutely not fun to explore: they are basically just empty boxes made out of cheapest polygons ever. There is no need to go anywhere because you won't find anything there.

Overall, this game is extremely outdated and not fun. Guys, don't buy this game and just play Metro instead.

Decided to buy this in a bundle when I was having a little craving for nostalgia. The game didn't disappoint. It is still, despite its aged outlook, one of the best games I've played. Back when this came out I didn't even know there were "secret" endings, so I got something new as well! They added so much depth to the story.

If you're new to this game and don't know much about it, and can overcome the dated outlook and occasional hiccups in the game play, I can wholeheartedly recommend this masterpiece.

Fun game, but here's some recommendations.
-Play the game on stalker difficulty or higher; any lower and you'll be shooting paper bullets instead of rubber.

-Try to avoid other stalkers until you get a decently lengthy rifle, they'll otherwise cook you like tourist's delight.

-Save. At. Every. Interval. Possible. You don't want to walk that much. Trust me, you don't.

-Max out your pistol ammo at about 600. Ammo weighs you down a lot more than you think it will. (Or don't carry a pistol because it doesn't dent anything stronger than a boar, but i like saving my rifle ammo)

-Only use medkits or bandages in an emergency. Otherwise, eat food or wait to regen.

-Pick up surplus weapons in the first area and sell everything you won't use to Sidorovich, i had 14000 rubles before i left.

-For god's sake, SAVE.

I might've made a big mistake by not playing through the game with any mods or fixed installed. Everyone gave it such high praise though, and they said that the game is "a little bit un-polished" without any mods.

The game is literally unplayable without mods. First off, one of the story missions bugged out for me so it wouldn't progress at all. I could still do the story objective but the objective markers and reminders where still bugged so i had no idea what to do and where to go. Second off the combat is one of the worst things i've played. Enemies are bullet-sponges and your guns have accuarcy so bad that you can't engage targets over 6 meters. Seriously. You cannot hit enemies with assualt rifles from medium-range even if you crouch and tap-fire. It is terrible.

Sure, i might have judged it a bit too hard considering it's a game from 2007 and made by an indie studio
but it's still seen as one of the greatest games and gets so much praise, so i was dissapointed when i played it.

If there is anything i'm missing here then please tell me in the comments because i really don't understand how this game can be given so much praise when it plays like this.

You buy the game, boot it up, immediately get yourself killed on the first gunfight, become overwhelmed with the controls, deem this the worst game you've ever played, and uninstall. In the days that follow, the game will linger in the back of your mind, and despite your experience with it being negative, something about the Zone will keep calling to you until you inevitably reinstall the game. This time you play it and something changes. It's true what they say- the Stalker may leave the Zone, but the Zone never leaves the Stalker. You're one of us now, brother. If our paths ever cross I'll buy you a drink and we'll exchange stories of the ones we've lost. But we won't mourn them- we'll pour one out to their memory and laugh about the good times we shared, because such is life in the Zone. And once you get a taste, you'll realize no other life can ever compare.

The idea of fusing first-person shooter mechanics with an open world is a tantalizing one. In GSC Game World's long awaited S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl, such an experiment in genre cooking has produced some great results. The game offers significantly more content than any other FPS out there, but struggles a little when it comes to the open world. What remains consistent throughout the experience is the compelling atmosphere. The gnarled trees, bleak skies, and rumbling thunderstorms of The Zone grab you firmly by the ears and yank you across irradiated wastelands. In your first hours expect to be filled with an intrepid glee as you acclimate to the game world. A little while later, you'll likely realize the environment's limitations and yearn for more.

Events kick off with your character, known only as the Marked One, tumbling off a death truck on the outskirts of The Zone. You soon meet up with a man named Sidorovich, who hands out your first tasks and introduces the fiction of the environment. As the journey progresses, you'll move through the game's various self-contained zones that together make up The Zone, from the relatively placid Cordon to the war-wracked Army Warehouses, Pripyat, and finally the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant itself, from which all things sinister seem to emanate.


S.T.A.L.K.E.R.'s main story missions provide the most engaging experience, as completing the challenges sometimes bestows useful rewards, opens up new territory to explore, and advances the mysterious plot. It turns out the Zone's NPCs aren't the best storytellers, so to more accurately understand what's happening you'll need to regularly check your PDA; the Marked One turns out to be quite the diligent note taker. Though some of the story's twists and turns are interesting, the pacing and storytelling methods could have used some refinement. Be sure to get one of the two true endings to fill in all the plot holes. The five false ones explain very little.

In a strange twist, several of the main story missions take place underground or indoors, shifting the aspects of gameplay toward that of a traditional corridor shooter. If you really want to test out how S.T.A.L.K.E.R.'s open world elements work, you'll need to embark on the many side quests The Zone's NPCs offer. Sadly only a handful of them are truly interesting. They mostly offer simple tasks such as kill a single target, wipe out a camp, or retrieve an object. The more involving ones toss you into battle with A.I. companions, though there are too few.

Cult classic, deeply flawed but with lots of style and grit. The community of modders will see this game live on for forever and a day. Very unforgiving, you'll find F5 and F9 (quick save, quick load) will be heavily used. Difficulty is implemented oddly, the modifiers for things like accuracy and damage are GLOBAL; if you lower the difficulty, not only will the enemy have a harder time killing you, you will have a harder time killing them. If you are thinking of picking up just one STALKER game I'd suggest Call of Pripyat as it's generally more polished then Shadow of Chernobyl or Clear Sky and is the host to Call of Chernobyl, a mod compiling all 3 game's maps. Goes on sale all the time.

S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Shadow of Chernobyl is a true classic. It is the spiritual predecessor and inspiration of the Metro franchise and most survival FPS games such as DAYZ, Escape From Tarkov, etc. With brutal and hardcore FPS mechanics the player needs to be careful in every battle, since loosing focus or ignoring an enemy for just a few seconds can mean a quick death (enemies 2-3 tap you). Inventory management, choosing the right ammo and the correct way to approach an enemy means the difference between winning or loosing a battle. The "open world" S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Shadow of Chernobyl offers is pretty empty with some relics and random encounters filling it up. But the open world, story and combat mechanics are secondary on a S.T.A.L.K.E.R game. The real beauty and value of all the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games is the impeccable atmosphere they have paired with an amazing sound design they make the player feel like they actually are inside the exclusion zone of Chernobyl. The developers actually went into Chernobyl and replicated almost every single building to perfection, which gives this game a really authentic feel. The lighting, footsteps, original Russian dub, mechanics, inventory management, brutal and unforgiving combat experience and eerie atmosphere is what makes S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Shadow of Chernobyl such a great game and why even today it is considered a cult classic and it is the inspiration of most hardcore/tactical FPS games. This game delivers a tense, frustrating but overall rewarding experience, a feeling only the Metro franchise manages to replicate (and only partially). The game has a lot of issues being mostly age related issues, being an old game, the mechanics are old, the graphics are old, the dub is extremely scuffed, the animations are clunky, the story is mediocre, the is no fast travel at all (some quests make you run across the whole map just to get one item and then run all the way back for a few rubles), combat is completely broken (you can waste 2-3 mags on a enemy or 1 tap him, and enemies do the same to you, it works on a randomized system with horrible bullet deviation and recoil mechanics), and finally some areas are either extremely easy (Garbage) or almost impossible to get over (Chernobyl Plant). I played on maximum difficulty to get the authentic experience and I recommend it. Somehow the charm S.T.A.L.K.E.R. has is precisely its extremely weird mix of hardcore FPS with clunky and outdated mechanics/graphics.
Overall S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Shadow of Chernobyl is an amazing game if you have no problem with older games and a few bugs. It delivers a fun and rewarding experience for any Metro fan, hardcore FPS fan and/or player who loves to experience older games and cult classics. Worth it for its full price 100%, but sales are very common and you can get all 3 S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games (Shadow of Chernobyl, Clear Sky and Call of Pripyat) for under $20

Stalker Shadow of Chernobyl is pretty well done survival shooter game, the basic tactics (Distracting with grenades, luring enemies, proceeding carefully otherwise your dead), manuver of the enemy AI taking advantage of their numbers (The Ai will not hug into one space, they use their numbers to cover both sides of cover; left and right of it, to attack you) and the weapons were well done, the only few complaints I have is the very lack of lore outside of the story (Its a shame you can't learn much of the lives of people during the soviet era of the 70s/80s or the much about the factions; establishment, history, individual stories,etc. ), the end game (Seriously do not proceed with the endgame, its unnecessarily hard and consuming of all your supplies to the point you have to cheese the game by loading saves alot in some sections to glitch it out when it spawns enemies), the inaccuracy of guns (Even the best ones somehow miss at point blank range), hunger (Why the heck does the game have it when there is no hunger bar and most of the time you don't need food but when you do you probably have no food), the respawning of enemies (They either spawn in the same place or at a loading zone, 90% of the time killing you with bandits or soldiers), flawed story (Ok seriously, its a weird plot, you have to go to point a to point b majority of the time in the story and in order to get access to some better gear you have to proceed with the story but you unfortunately can't use them after completing the game and explore the rest of areas that may have been difficult early on). 

Overall the premise of the game as a survival 'realistic' shooter is great but there are flaws in the game design and story.

I bought the game on the winter sale. I can understand how others can like this game. It represents a gaming style that challenges a player and offers less direction than more modern games. This type of game can be hard to do well and is likely a matter of taste while touching on nostalgia. My experience with STALKER for one who has never played it before was open-minded. The game is interesting enough to finish. However, I do not feel that it was an enjoyable investment of my time. This was because of: bullet spongy enemies, poor in-game supplemental lighting such as through night vision goggles, mediocre "story", and poor atmosphere for horror.

Bullet spongy enemies: I play on hardest difficulty. While some bullet sponginess is to be expected, this leads to me getting killed by enemies that should have been taken out ages ago.
Supplemental lighting: the night vision with the Stalker suit is poorly calibrated. It does not really help see at all and needs its brightness to be increased.
"Story": the game feels extremely linear, even in its open world. The side quests do not really contribute anything so I have chosen to skip them. The actual quest starts with an interesting premise, but nothing comes of it even 8ish hours into the game. I more so moved forward with the game to see it through its conclusion than I was enjoying it.
Poor horror atmosphere: the mutants were freaky and got a jump scare initially, but became tedious and not really that impressive. Per the story, overall everything I faced was a bit of a slog.

I personally would not recommend the game, even on sale. When playing an unmodded game, it has not aged well and many aspects of it need improvement. While this is likely touched on by mods, I am reviewing the game and not the mods. The game may be worth it for those playing for nostalgia's sake, but for those new to the STALKER series, it was not anything special.

You already know this game is good so instead I'll tell you a story...

Rather than play the game on normal I immediately set it on the hardest possible difficulty, and didn't stop to wonder why a dog took up two clips of my pistol. Rather than learn from that, I came upon a group of stalkers about to charge into a bandit camp and said to them I will do it solo, after all I realised that the knife in this game was op... That was a mistake. 
Stealth works as much as it does irl if they can see you or use there super hearing you bet your damn life you will die because playing Johnny Rambo armed with only a knife doesn't do well in a gun fight especially when a gun pointed directly at you acts as a shield preventing you to get close enough for it to even connect to their hit box. Reloading I begged the other Stalkers for help and then looted all of their bodies as both stalkers and bandits wiped each other out.

As I learned more about the games aiming mechanics that the closer you are to mother earth the more she blesses you with accuracy rather than admiring your gun by looking down the sight, I decided to attack a group of screaming bandits. Why were they screaming? I didn't know but all I was thinking was free money. Coming up on the bandits one charged me and was swept up by a vortex, then I realised what the screams were. Laughing at this stupid bandit I was quickly beset by the rest of his gangs and decided to run. Behind me there was a vortex. I died.

After this I tried making friends. Other stalkers will like you more if you help them especially when you give them first aid kits as the writhe in agony on the floor. I did this to veterans and you have a stalker killer machine as your friend, then I watched as almost instantly a large ravenous horde of hungry dogs arrives and kill said new friend.
Get the hell under ground to get away from said dogs, realise the horror of your decision while you nearly crap you pants as a screaming deformed mutant pops out of no where and has only tentacles for a face, try to assure yourself its okay. Call yourself a liar as another decides to use you as a rag-doll with its psychic powers. 
Shaken, pop up and realise you are under a military base. Feel good that you've come a long way from getting wiped out by bandits as you wipe out the soldiers and 'acquire' their hardware. 
Leave to a new area and get swarmed by a massive group of dogs and die before relaxing at the bar.

And all of this happened in a span of 5 hours.
Game crashes a lot but its amazing, I can get lost in the Zone for hours.

I trust these ladders with my life and you should too; worth purchasing at full price.

I'm writing this review on completion of the game's story line with games with a main story i wont write a review until i have finished it to add to authenticity to my review i finished the game on veteran second from the highest difficulty. There will be no spoilers in this review so people that haven't played are safe :) so this game is simply amazing at first glance it looked like a normal retro FPS with not much to expect from gun play and AI but ohh buddy was i wrong about that. This games gun play is really in depth for the time period it was made in its flush, smooth and easy to get used to you have the ability to peek left and right around corners which comes in handy a lot in this game as sometimes you have handfuls of enemies coming at you in tight fighting areas like hallways, rooms, and staircases but there is a fair amount of fighting outside as well you get two weapons to have on quick bar at all times your pistol and your long gun (Assault, Sniper, SMG) but you also have a inventory you can keep other guns in as well but you have a weight limit like any RPG game there are certain stash boxes in places you take missions from to keep all your weapons in they will not delete and there is also a trader in every major spot to sell and buy goods from as well as for the rest of gun play you have a basic crouch walk and then a full crouch to get even lower behind cover if you need to which also comes in handy a lot there are few different ammo types for each pretty much every gun. As for types of guns there are plenty to choose from there is many different pistols, assault rifles, and sniper rifles so there is lots of room for mixing it up and finding your perfect gun combinations for your play style i played with pistol and assault most of the time but i actually waited until later on to make a final decision on what guns i wanted with me for the ending of the game which happened to be a G-37 and a 45. Caliber pistol and a sniper to back it up which was a VSS. Grenades are very handy in this game and you have a couple different types of frags no flash bangs or stuns. AI in this game from what i seen was really done well they fight like they are really in a gun fight using cover constantly and shooting precisely but not all the time to where its unrealistic aim from the enemy the AI in gun fights is really great and fun to fight there are many different factions in this game so your not fighting the same group of people all the time it changes quite a bit so it wont get stale the two main fractions that war with one another is Duty and Freedom which there is missions surrounding that war which makes for good side fun the AI acts like they are actually in gun fights and make smart decisions they will activity stalk you and try to sneak up on you to kill you which they will sometimes and it just makes you become more aware of your surroundings and watching your back becomes a normal thing which i find really cool that the enemies are smart so all in all i say a 10/10 on fighting the AI's. The missions are in depth and tell a lot of story which the story in this game is really good there some cut scenes but mainly in the main story but i'm not gonna tell any of the story and spoil it for new players there is really good RPG elements here where you can ask multiple questions sometimes and find out more about the story in depth sometimes you have a handheld communication device which hold things like your map, diary, tasks, and general more in depth explanations and lore on areas, anomaly's, factions, mutants etc etc  etc. the graphics are very good for the year the game was made in they are not top of the line either but its not terrible you can tell the devs put a lot of time and creation into every area of the map there are serious fallout vibes with this game as well but its not so much to where it still is its own game within its self but Fallout fans will get what i'm talking about here its completely free roam and there are plenty of side missions to do and great rewards for doing them and also extends the story on top of a great game with a great story which i really really like i recommend doing as much side activities as you can before completing the whole game because once you finish the game you don't go back to playing the game unless you have a save game before you beat the game and like i said doing side quest will get you better weapons, gear (Armor) and let you get enough money to outfit yourself with med kits and anti rad med before doing major missions i also recommend playing the game on veteran the second from the highest difficulty for people that want a solid challenge while not over doing it. This is very important the game's auto save feature isn't the greatest and don't auto save as frequently as it should so you could be playing a mission and get hella far and die then have to go way back and do it all over again so i recommend saving often manually so that don't happen that's the only bad thing i have to say about the game as for bugs surprisingly there isn't much to speak of which is always a good thing all in all i recommend this game to anyone that is looking for a solid story, Fps, and role playing all in the same game the story is 10/10 forsure and i will be purchasing the other games to see the rest of the story before stalker 2 comes out in 2022 solid gun play, story, side stories, AI, map and RPG elements in a post apocalyptic setting i recommend this game to any gamer that loves first person shooter RPGS once i started playing i couldn't stop until i beat it which not many newer games can do for me now days great job to the guys that made this game and can't wait to see the brand new one coming out in action thanks steam community for reading hope you guys had a great holidays and have a happy new year!

December 2021, that's when I decided to try this fairly ancient game which had been in my library seemingly forever. I heard it was good from a friend, and there was a sequel using UE5 coming out and that was about it.

This game is a masterpiece. It's immersive, unpredictable, tense, violent and deeply rewarding. There are certain mechanics here which I'm shocked and saddened haven't been copied in more modern games. Once such mechanic is are the permanent corpses on the ground, which can actually be a half decent way to store items and equipment too heavy to carry, but too valuable to not stash away and grab later.

The world feels genuinely alive and populated with individuals, all with different agendas and behaviors. Taking a life carries a lot of weight somehow, even though the NPCS lack a little visual verity, I can only put that to the masterful world building and atmosphere.

The starting weapons are a bit naff, but the progression from wasteland scrub to unstoppable killing machine is a journey which is as riveting today as it probably ever was. Something has to be said about the horror elements at play here as well, I don't want to spoil anything about it but I'll just say there were many sequences in this game which had me jumping out of my seat, fumbling my controls and staring at the screen in bewilderment.

The only negatives I can think of;
- The map is clunky by today's standards.
- Some side questing can be a little underwhelming. There are some repeatable side quests which, while totally optional, aren't always clearly explained, and the trudging round the map backwards and forwards won't feel like a great use of your time. I'd say go for the unique side quests, but if you never do any of those repeatable quests you won't feel like you've missed much.

This game holds up really well up for a 2007 game.  The combat is fun and engaging, the missions give you something to do and there's tons of weapon and item variety. Basically kind of like Metro Exodus but with an entirely open world (which is amazing for an 2007 game!). I was also surprised that this game does in fact support ultrawide resolutions and runs really well on my modern hardware

 However, you have to keep in mind that it still is a 2007 and a jank game, which definitely gives you the following flaws:

- The game is "figure it out for yourself" which might be good or bad. Modern games seem to hold your hand a bit too much, but retro ones do it too little sometimes, however in contrast to other games that had this issue, the objectives of stalker were pretty clear to me and I only got very lost one or two times in labs in opposed to *cough* some other games
- Furthermore, the story is completely nonsensical, apparently there is a story if you decide to talk to some guy named the Guide, but this is never hinted at, and is just randomly placed in your mission list. I recon most people will not figure this out. And the ending you get is really really stupid if you don't figure this out.
- The AI is both wonderful and awful at the same time. They dodge grenades, push in groups, etc. and seem to possess some kind of intelligence.. until they dont and just stare at you
- The voice system is fucking awful, if you go near some guy he will literally repeat the same voice line a million times and my god its annoying. If I hear " I HAVE SOME INFORMATION THAT MIGHT BE OF USE TO YOU STALKER"  one more time I swear I will go insane
- The resources you get are over the top for a survival game, which makes it less atmospheric then say metro 2033, at the ending I had like 3 end game suits of armor, 4 guns and 1000 rounds and a ton of grenades, healing, etc. It really takes the "stress"  of you if you can just spam medkit of radaway constantly without any consequences

A bleak, absorbing sandbox survival FPS worth playing if you're into that sort of thing. Or if you're obsessed with eastern European culture. 

If you're going to get this, you'll want to install the Stalker Complete 2009 mod. Improves textures, stability, and allows you to skip the opening idents and cutscenes. But even with the mod, you might still get some occasional issues. Also, the lower the difficulty the more damage the player and enemies can take, and vice versa on higher difficulties.

This is my review but over all as someone who just beaten it and someone who loves wasteland type settings and more. This is hands down a most for anyone who loves single player games and who wants something more from Metro(I beaten all of the games and now I'm reading the book slowly).

It sucked but it was worth it to play it all the way and experience the game fully for what it is.

Even with as much fun as I've had with this game, I cannot recommend it.

The base game is broken. You will install it, you will make some headway and progress, you will enjoy yourself and then it will crash. You will load it up and play for five to ten minutes and then it will crash. You will load it up and it will crash. I've been told the reasons behind this and I understand them wholeheartedly but I will not give this game a passing grade.

Then I found that there were several patches that could fix up the unstable engine and not only make the game playable but with even better gameplay and better graphics - Considering how awesome the game was otherwise, I was willing to go in for another run. I installed the Memories of the Zone mod and had a phenomenal time.

Then I got to the endgame. I did everything I could, handled all that needed to be handled and got ready for either an epic showdown or an unraveling of the mysteries... Instead, I got two back-to-back countdowns til death. One was on a direct timer, which I believe was originally cut out but brought back in by the mod - This was fine. It was close, required quick decisions to be made but I made it. Then there was an indirect timer which used the game's radiation system. Unfortunately for me, there were three areas since the last trader I encountered and all of them were packed with radiation hotspots. So, I rush through this area, unable to take in the scenery as I'm going from body to body, scrounging for items to heal radiation and health where I can and I come to the first area that actual through me into the first tangent I'd had since before patching the game. I'd already been informed of the fact that there were multiple endings and had followed the questline down to a tee. Unfortunately, the path to following said questline is hidden away in a dark corner that you'd only be able to see if you took your time to observe your surroundings like you could with the rest of the game. After several deaths by radiation, an accidental starting of the bad ending, taking a moment to confide in my roommate's cat and looking up a walkthrough, I found it.

After that, the fun gets back on track. I go through an area, the gunplay is back to an all-time high... then I'm suddenly playing a slower-paced version of Portal. Weird and it's giving me the same negative vibes I got from Black Ops 3's ending, feeling like I've been completely disconnected and left out on why I'm doing the things I'm doing... and then it crashed. I cursed before sucking it up and loading my last save saying that this happens. Then it crashed again at the same spot. I saved just before then and I'm suspicious. I load the save, I go to the area and it crashed at the exact same spot again. I don't know the issue and I do not care to solve it anymore.

In short, I gave this game more chances than any unstable game I've ever played because I've found it to be very legitimately fun. But the repeated crashes and a lackluster start to the true ending has absolutely killed any desire to see it through. I wanted to experience the ending with my own eyes and see the journey through... but even though I must have been less than a hundred yards away from that point, all of the duct tape that I had to apply myself, provided by a third party who I think were more dedicated than this game deserves, wasn't enough to keep it together.

In summary, if a game's going to crash and break at the most pivotal moments, why does it have to be so damn fun and leave me feeling so empty about being unable to complete it?

Just finished my first play-through, and it is an amazing game. The graphics could be better, but it's a game from 2007, so you can't really ask for much. First, I don't like the gunplay at all. Enemies do not react or give an indication that they've been shot, leaving it as a guessing game of whether or not you're actually hitting your shots.
Second, it doesn't seem like the game is actually "open world". I finally realized this when it said "move on to next level". Very disappointing.
I don't like the bullet sponge enemies. Couple this with the fact that you cant even tell if you're actually shooting the enemies, and it makes a very unpleasant combat experience.
Other than that I like the atmosphere of the game, and the graphics are really good.

Was not expecting to have as good a time with this as I did coming back to it after all these years.
The opening of the game does start pretty dull and dry, however the longer you play the more you start to notice this fascinating, dynamic experience of an every changing in-game world. Sidequests will fail out of the blue because someone you were supposed to meet just happened to die on the other side of the map, but that doesn't really matter in the end, the sidequests are all irrelevant in the grand scheme.
What does matter - is the story, and the story IS the setting, this grim, sad world of dark wonder and painful fantasy.

A game oozing with atmosphere. Set in the distant far off year of 2012 in the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone. You will contend with Mutants, Bandits, Anomalies, and a living Artificial world. Kill a camp of Stalkers and they will stay silent until the stalkers send in a new group. Factions control many parts of the zone. Further you will have to contend with getting The Marked One food and water, keep your rad count down, and survive the many battles you will have ahead of you. 
8/10 Stars

First read about STALKER: SOC in an old gaming magazine.  I remember the release postponement drama and the game gaining a reputation for being on the same scale as "Duke Nukem Forever".  And when it finally came out, it was panned for being a bug-ridden mess, if it would run remotely stable.  Disheartened, I forgot about STALKER for a bit.  But then I got a copy for free several years later in a MaximumPC(?) magazine (disclaimer - I re-purchased on Steam some time later).  Tossed it aside, finding it another year or two later while cleaning and decided to install it.  Found the patches.  And from then on, the STALKER franchise has held a special place in my heart.  

The atmosphere, the music, the authentic visual assets make it a masterpiece.  But the sheer danger that the world poses your character, and the resultant feeling of 'blood-chilling survival exploration' is something that makes it a sub-genre of FPS all of its' own.  Escape From Tarkov derived significant spiritual influence from STALKER.  But STALKER still stands firmly on its own.  I highly recommend checking out the modding scene - you will at minimum find 'community patches' for issues never addressed by the developer.  At maximum, you will find total overhaul mods like the 'Lost Alpha' mod, weapon packs, graphical enhancements - the list goes on.

I first played it back in 2007 when it came out, my first ever horror/open world game and I remember just being terrified at every single noise while I was out wandering around in the zone. It's not an easy game and it takes a ton of patience but it was like the disfigured-at-birth cousin of Fallout3. The Ukrainian development house had a ton of resources to draw on and they made a game that's incredibly dark, horrific and frustrating especially as you get closer to "ground zero". This is based on a real life source so as you wander this wasteland you can't help but remember that real people were actually there after the accident in 1986.

You turn up on the edge of the zone, found by a group call themselves STALKERS, they prowl the zone around the old power station and even venture in, making a living scrounging what they can and containing the mutated beings that are there. You start working for a greedy dirtbag who live sin a bunker and you work for people, make contacts, build relationships and so on. End goal is to get into the core of the old power station but trust me that's a long way off to begin with you have a ton of work to do to get good gear ready to even get anywhere near the outskirts of Pripyat. 

That's one of the cool things, way before Bethesda started banging on about how great their IA was ( which sometimes it's not! ) this little team from the Ukraine were wiping the floor with their US counterparts in terms of AI. This game will punish you hard if you go it alone, it won't stop you but you will find it harder to fight the AI but that's the cool thing you have the choice. Just like life, you ignore people then life gets harder than it should, but you have the choice, you always have the choice.

A lot of good memories of my first real 3D open world/apocalytic horror game, still a landmark game and 15 years later, still very much worth playing,

=============
One bug that hit me was no sound. Took 5 mins to fix. Search for "OpenAL Soft", download the ZIP, extract the Win32 folder and rename "soft_oal.dll" to "OpenAL32.dll", copy that file over the top of the same file in the game's bin folder, problem sorted for me. ( FYI, original game file is about 40kb updated files is about 2Mb )

And the truth is, if you play for the first time, the game seems a little raw, but remember where and how the game was made, After all, it was transferred several times, the publisher THQ drove the developers to quickly release the game and the fans who hoped to see the promised masterpiece were already tired of the endless transfers of the game. But nevertheless, the game turned out to be not bad for that time, especially for a small, unknown, Ukrainian company. For example, the A-LIFE system, which made it so that the NPC did not spawn just like that somewhere in front of the player, creating a pseudo-living world, but actually simulated a real behavior. The stalker could spawn on the outskirts of the zone, go a long way ... and so, he sits in front of your fire and sings songs ... In conclusion, I will say that the game is worth passing so that they will delve into the world of this game.

While playing the original S.T.A.L.K.E.R. of the trilogy series you'll experience an expansive, dynamic and living world. A-Life as was coined by the developers (GSC) is an integral part of the dynamic world you'll find yourself in. S.T.A.L.K.E.R. SOC features a system of life simulation and can accurately be described as as the glue that holds everything together in the exclusion Zone. You've got a huge and dangerous environment to explore, other S.T.A.L.K.E.R.s to interact with, secret post Soviet labs to explore and anomalies to discover.

Under normal circumstances this would't be very interesting if the game ran on rails and if everything was scripted based on your current progress and particular location. This is where A-Life comes in. It's a system that controls everything in the game that lives and breathes. It also ensures that no two games of S.T.A.L.K.E.R. will play out in the same way.

The second you start playing, there are hundreds of other characters (from fellow S.T.A.L.K.E.R.s to mutant bloodsuckers) in Chernobyl that are going about their daily business. Your presence in the game alters this life cycle just because you're there. This change isn't for better or worse, it's just a change and things will react to your presence or they won't. 

Bandits, anarchists and hordes of mutants roam the land and attack each other while you roam the radiation soaked Ukrainian landscape. On the surface this might seem random, but should you decide to kill a pack of mutated boars, for example, it might have larger ramifications later on. The mutants might have originally wandered into an enemy camp and inadvertently killed a few bad guys thereby making your job that much easier, but now they're mutated worm food so this won't happen.

There's an ongoing persistent life cycle happening in the Zone and you're just a visitor. So come on in, don't stand there and come discover the secrets of the Zone. 

On a final note whether you're a rookie or a Zone legend let's all just pray to the Monolith that the long awaited sequel to the series: S.T.A.L.K.E.R. (2) Heart of Chernobyl, lives up to it's predecessors and that the AI and A-Life 2.0 can be revolutionary like in was in the first 3 S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games. 

Good hunting S.T.A.L.K.E.R. and may the Zone never claim you life.

STALKER: Shadow of Chernobyl is slavjank at its finest. While the game has aged relatively well, one must still keep in mind that this is a game produced with shoestring budget and had a somewhat troubled development cycle. The caveats in mind, STALKER is an excellent semi-open world shooty-survival-y romp with a decent story to it. The story is told through a few cutscenes, but mostly through either someone radioning you and telling something has happened, or through a dialog box before or after a mission.

At its core, STALKER is a shooter leaning more into survival and methodical play, rather than fast paced action. In the Zone, a few shots can drop you, but the enemies follow similar rules. The only thing that gives the enemies any kind of advantage, is their numbers and their uncanny ability to throw grenades. The game does not really have a stealth system, but you can equip a silencer in your weapon and pick off a few enemies before the rest notice that something is amiss.

The game's age shows mostly through the slightly muddy visuals and many aged systems. For instance, you cannot repair your weapons or armor without the use of a mod that enables the functionality, which means you will be replacing your shooter and suit frequently. Thankfully(?), there are no upgrade systems either, so any suit A is going to be equivalent to any other suit A.

There are a number of things I would recommend you change if you are just getting into STALKER: firstly, I would suggest getting the Complete mod or something similar, as they fix a number of issues and bugs, and add some much-needed quality of life features, like repairing gear at Barkeep. Before that, you likely won't need to repair your items, as you will be rapidly acquiring better weapons and protective suits. After that, the rate of acquisitions slows down and you will find yourself sticking to one or two weapons and one suit for an extended period of time. In addition to the mod, you may want to look into tweak guides that allow you to get rid of the absolutely horrible headbobbing, and allows you to improve the visuals/performance of the game.

STALKER is definitely not for everyone, but for those whom this style of game appeals will love it, and revisit the Zone for years to come even in spite of the flaws and shortcomings of the currently released games. One can only wonder how STALKER 2 will be like. Keep your Quicksave button close at hand, and get out of here, STALKER.

STALKER, put simply, is Fallout, but for the cool kids.

(Scrolls down for TL;DR)

It’s a solid FPS, with light RPG mechanics and an interesting progression cycle going through the game, where you have to FIND better stuff to use as opposed to upgrading it with items and skills. The survival elements are practically nonexistent so if that seems off putting, don't worry. The horror element, although enjoyable and atmospheric, is sort of hit or miss. The story was surprisingly intriguing and helps push you into new areas without completely limiting your options to explore.

The beginning of the game is the most difficult if you’re a new player, and the simple reason is they give you the worst weapons ever put into a first person shooter. Your pistol is painfully inaccurate and the shotgun feels like it doesn’t have as much kick unless you’re breathing on the enemies. It’s not until you begin to transition into the mid-game and acquire the military’s weapons until you really start to get a feel for how satisfying the gun-play can be. And it’s not until the late game that weapons start to feel overpowered. But by that point enemy density and AI makes up for the insane leap in weaponry. Speaking of AI, it's not as legendary as most make it out to be. Yes, if you stand still and try to pick fights at range, enemies will flank or just plain outgun you. The key is maneuverability and learning to close the gap by running between cover like trees and hiding in bushes. That sort of trails off once you enter the final level where it devolves into a painful corridor shooter, where enemies can be stupid enough to funnel into a choke point where you dome them one by one as they line up behind one another. 

A few (sort of essential) gameplay tips:
--CTRL+SHIFT, crouch, is the best way to shoot your weapon, as it maximizes character accuracy.
--Remember to move forward behind cover, crouch, and lean with Q and E to utilize cover
--Always aim for the head, its the difference between 1 bullet and 20 to putting an enemy down
--Always quick-save BEFORE and AFTER a combat encounter. After a few hours you sort of get a feel for when they are so be aware of when you last saved, the only time AUTO SAVE is utilized is transitioning between areas. Hell, Save DURING encounters, it helps to have a checkpoint at difficult points in the game. QUICK-SAVE is F6, and QUICK-LOAD is F7 (at least those were my defaults), just make sure you know what your key binds are before you start the game. These will save you a lot of time.
--SAVE GAME in the pause menu I would recommend for major points in the game, such as primary quest line steps, since QUICK-SAVE only saves 2 files in between each SAVE GAME. Just be aware of what’s what.


Now bugs. For my first play-through, I had a relatively smooth time, only crashing once, and sort of tuning out frame stutters as they don’t bother me too much. My second time through, more became apparent. Sometimes after killing an enemy they clip into the world objects or ground, and will occasionally beat you to death with their ragdoll stretch, it's annoying, and frustrating, and why you should always QUICK-SAVE when possible. Frame stutters were common again, but I don't mind them. Other times I would need to interact with an NPC during a quest and they would bug out, after I turned in a specific quest step, they would repeat they’re scripting until I loaded a previous save or sometimes it would fix itself if I ignored it long enough. If any of this is a deal-breaker, I'd highly recommend a mod fix/ patch. I’m yet to use any of the recommended ones, so explore among the community or reviewers for specifics. 

Lastly, I wanted to touch some of the items of the game I really enjoyed that I can't really fit anywhere else. I’m a real sucker for acoustic guitar so when I found that other stalkers in game would frequently sit around fires playing guitar, I found it not only sleuthing, but enjoyable, and fascinating world building, and immersion. Some of those Stalkers play absolute BANGERS, and I was always delighted to take a break from stash hunting or side quest grinds to just sit and enjoy the tunes. It really was a highlight in my experience.
	Another that really should have been mentioned earlier were artifacts. This is where the light RPG mechanic comes into play and I found them really cool. So essentially throughout the zone strange ‘anomalies' as they’ve been dubbed, spawn artifacts that allow the user a statistical buff when equipped. They’re small boosts to almost any stat in the game but at costs to other stats. So the hunt slowly becomes this sort of build crafting of what your favorite combination of artifacts are. Yes, objectively there are the best ones, but unless you frequent the wiki to figure out where to find them, most of the time you will be juggling a lot of buffs and debuffs which adds an interesting dynamic to the game beyond “guy shoot gun, guy gun shoot guy, win game”

TL;DR: Stalker is an interesting take on the post apocalypse genre, and is one that oozes creativity, talent, depth, intrigue, atmosphere and artistically one of the most sound games I’ve managed to play and enjoy thoroughly in the past few years. I highly recommend it to those looking for a fun shooter with a decent story, interesting light RPG mechanics, and enjoyers of batshit crazy awesome Russian tomfoolery most have come to recognize in gaming.
