SPOILER FREE
PROs and CONs

Pros:
- Despite looking aged, it does build ambience well for any given area.
- Some enemies in the game can legitimately feel intimidating, even if you know how to deal with them, even the "creepy" ones.
- Events in the world around you make the game feel more like you're part of an evolving world, you're not the world itself.
- You have to make decisions on what you should take with you to avoid being overencumbered, especially if looking for loot to sell or use. Quite realistic in that regard.
- There "technically" is a way to bank items, though I think it's unintentional, so you can keep gear you think you may need later.
- The cutscenes genuinely look good, probably amazing at the time it was released.
- You can use 6 to interact with anomolies by throwing a bolt into them and sets them off before your proximity alert pops up. Especially useful in dark areas or at night.
- The presence of anomolies gives the feeling of danger and caution in conjunction with radioactivity, more so when you hear their respective sounds either in tandem or by themselves.
- Some mini-games are fun, but can be easily completed once you understand how best to fight an enemy.

Cons:
-It's easy to over or underestimate enemies or areas, leaving one feeling like the game is too easy or hard.
-You have to grind to make sure you have enough money to get decent gear or other items.
-"Miniquests" are worse in terms of rewards compared to fighting hostile enemies and taking their gear to a trader which becomes boring quickly. 
-Said miniquests have timers to complete them, including returning to the quest-giver. Even if you do the quest, you'll get no reward if you don't return on time.
-Some "critical" NPCs can die when you may need them for longer quests, instead of being incapacitated, as expected for critical NPCs.
-Unique gear can often feel redundant to stuff you can buy, especially with the hauling gear tactic.
-Some scripted events can become confusing, especially with one mutant that you can't escape unless you kill it, which with what you see, you'd not think you'd need to shoot it, which you have to do.
-Saves can sometimes bug, changing reputation is the most common bug the game will do, usually defaulting to "Terrible"
If you're going in and doing the same mentality as mine, "Lets play blind, no mods". You'll be disappointed. Not only has the game aged badly and has a lack of choice (which some mods can create 
 more of), but there are glitches that can soft-lock you or if you dare to open GeForce Experience, it'll crash the game. ALSO, as a side note, if you do decide to get this game, get mods like Anomoly or other game-enhancing things that allow joinable factions, better indicators and statistics, retextures and lighting. There are a good portion of mods for this game, so if you do play, use mods and not spend 30 hours with a game that's aged poorly and can be improved upon via mods.

For instance, at one point in the game, someone will block a door (even random NPCs can just stand in your way unless you walk a fair distance away from them), despite whether or not you try to get them to move, if that be by talking to them, pointing your gun at them, moving away from them, leaving then returning to the area, reloading a save. Nothing. The only thing that fixed it for me was a random gunfight somewhere in this location and he went into combat mode and stood aside.

Talking about the combat, the game makes enemies feel like spongy. Even dogs can take many 7.62mm bullets like a slap. to paraphrase; someone identified that in the code, the damage to the body is very little, even with late-game weapons, but headshots with most weapons - even lower "tiered" ones - will one-shot kill in most cases.

Enemies do make an attempt to take cover, which I can commend, in groups they will often be able to pin you down and in the early game they'll just sit there and wait, step out so you can get some shots in and vice versa, then back to cover. I'm not sure if it's intentional just early game to get you used to using your own cover and other mechanics, but later on enemies will, in groups, will advance towards you, this did backfire on them once as they all clumped up into a doorway and all I had to do was duck out of cover, precisely toss a grenade and wham, a good portion of them died.

The game does a piss-poor way of telling you how weapons scale and doesn't actively encourage experimentation outside of "Find gun, fire, does it feel good and/or has good stats compared to your gun/s? if not, drop, if good, keep and find ammo". The latter of the two can be problematic early game as most ammo for some guns can only be found in later on as well as armour. Whilst it gives descriptions for the armour, it never tells you any stats, like radiation resistance, bullet armour, et al. The guns get a slider of 4 factors: Damage, fire rate, accuracy and handling. There are no numbers, just the slider. you just pick your poison; fire rate but less damage? poor handling over great accuracy? (As a side note, handling doesn't "feel" like it does much outside of 1 or 2 weapons. It just reduces your DPI, easily solved these days). 

I think this game was more directed towards Russians (As they speak Russian, despite being set in Ukraine). A lot of the dialogue outside of some important stuff such as main story dialogue, some particular encounters and "come here I'm an important NPC" is in English, but only a small handful of ambient stuff is in English. Most encounters, including combat, are strictly in Russian, so it's hard to tell what's communicated outside of one specific route I took where the enemies were in particularly hard areas to see and allies called them out to me, which was very useful. I was hoping it'd be the opposite away around but in English also, even if it was just insults.

There are also times where NPCs will repeat the same phrase over and over to the point I will take my headphones off. Particularly one fellow who says "Get out of here Stalker". If you stay in the same room as him, he won't fire, but he'll keep saying it every few seconds or so. This also goes with Russian dialogue (I only recognised it from being present and hearing the same words repeated). It's also a damn shame that there are no subtitle options.

The story left me a bit non-plussed. Especially how it was encouraging me to push further into the later areas of the game, yet one of your "constant" objectives is to find someone and kill them (Not a spoiler, literally one of the first things you have assigned on your tasks list). So I was pushing into "The zone", as it's called, but kept going back to do this objective. Unfortunately the game suffers from a big "okay now find it or use a guide". But a lot of games in development back when it was made had that sort of mentality anyway.

As a result, this "Kill this guy" quest-line gets shoved out the way quite easily unless you're constantly recalling it. I imagine if I played it again (which I "maybe" will do, but with mods), the story would be a little more fulfilling.

Similar to games like the Metro series and Fallout, the game's ending will differ depending on the actions you take, though these are very specific and rely more on very narrowed-down. For instance, one ending I got is considered the "Negative" ending, which requires that you have a "terrible" reputation, though I was pretty sure my reputation was "excellent". (EDIT: My save bugged, I would've gotten the "positive" ending otherwise)

Final Verdict.
Ultimately, I'd say not to buy this game to play it in it's "vanilla" way (again, I can't recommend it modded either since I've not done that yet), but I imagine that, even with mods, it might not be en par with even Fallout 3. I am amiss to say it's an "okay" game due to this. If it's on sale for something like a mere £5, go ahead and try it with mods, but for the sake of a more interesting game, use mods.

As I was playing the last mission I was about to leave a negative comment on the game out of frustration. I think though that I made a few mistakes out of my walkthrough that made my time harder. First of all, look up how each difficulty works because there seems to be this notion that the "easiest way to play" is master difficulty. There is some truth to it but not completely. Also spam save if you dont want to be stuck in the same gun fight for an hour.

Now for the game itself,
The story is really basic and the way the game is structured makes it really hard to understand and you need a lot of commitment to understand the lore (not just the main storyline). The start of the game sucks ass because of how shit and inaccurate all the guns are. The gunplay certainly gets more tight.

The world of stalker is really interesting and really vibrant despite how gray and dark green everything is. 

I think the game shines in various moments and aspects but the side missions ,  and the beginning and end of the game are too frustrating to call even remotely worthwhile.

The progression feels good as you get stronger and stronger but so does everyone else. But just so you know look around carefully as you can find a lot of loot that can be important for progression.

I believe some of my frustrations are due to my mistakes and lack of proper searching for better equipment but the game lacks any proper indication of lots of its mechanics and you will have to end up googling everything. For example, boxes contain very good loot but you might be playing for a while before finding out... and lots of other things

I will give it a thumbs up mostly because of the midgame which obviously can last a while if you choose to stick around.

This game is both great and bad at the same time, although its greatness definitely outweighs the negatives for me. I played on master difficulty with the Zone Reclamation Project mod, which, as far as I know only does bug fixes and retains the original vanilla experience. The atmosphere is great, it creates a really tense mood, and I was constantly on the edge of my seat in the underground areas in particular. I am very impressed by the lighting this game has, it really holds up the graphics that have otherwise aged quite a bit, I especially like how NPCs cast dynamic light with their flashlights. The combat is really tense, but I wish that I was able to hear human enemies' footsteps, because they took me by surprise constantly around corners and slow walk everywhere, it would just help to increase combat awareness if I could hear them move around. I also like the way the story is paced, they give you very little story initially so you can focus on exploring the world and overcoming the initial difficulty curve, afterwards they start to give you the story to propel the plot forward. It's worth noting that this game is absolutely brutal in its difficulty, especially at the start and the end. The start is hard because you just don't have weapons accurate enough to consistently land headshots, and the end is hard because it just throws droves and droves of enemies at you and forces you to heavy radiation which is just annoying. If I counted how many deaths I had, it would probably be in the hundreds, and you will probably die a lot as well. I highly recommend this game, but I can't ignore the problems this game has, so beware of them. It's definitely worth a playthrough though if you can handle the bad aspects.

S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Shadow of Chernobyl, where to begin? 

Well out of all the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games to own, this is the one you must have above all else, the others are good but this one is the OG. Younger gamers will probably notice that it's dated more than those of us who have the pure nostalgia from 2005 and this dropped, however note that there are alot of mods, both visual and gamewise which can improve the experience for you. A personal favourite Mod for me was the Arsenal Mod which gave a much wider variety of firearms and mods. 

However, even vanilla and without any gun mods, this game is a must have because of the storyline. There is a reason this game enjoys 'cult' status and why people like myself and many, many others who have literally tripped over themselves to drop over £100 on the top edition of the long awaited S.T.A.L.K.E.R. 2 Heart of Chernobyl that drops in April and drags this game into the modern times. 

I'm not going to give you any spoilers reference the story, just know that it captivates you and consumes you, like the ZONE consumes S.T.A.L.K.E.R.S who stray into it. 

Don't be put off by my measly 113 mins of game time logged on steam.....I've played this game through more than once, including all the side quests on the boxed edition. 

P.S. Don't think that you can get away with just playing Metro and think you've got the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. experience, I love the Metro series but it's just not the same in any way, shape or form.

A glorious and abysmal masterpiece of both visionary narrative and an abortive failure of execution, "S.T.A.L.K.E.R. SoC" is a remarkable example of truly great storytelling and immersive atmosphere saddled with a god-awful combination of everything else in the alphabet from 'Aim' to 'Zone'. I have never felt so polarized in a gaming experience or wanted it to be better than it was so much, but to quote Melisandre from 'Clash of Kings' [i]"If half an onion is black with rot, it is a rotten onion."[/i]

I want to start with the the feature that is really carrying "STALKER" which is the story and atmosphere. I won't repeat it in full here, but will say that I found it just as compelling and immersive as the most adoring fan of the series. The Ukrainian Zone of Chernobyl is the perfect dichotomy of despair and opportunity, artfully crafted and fully alive. The original story in the game melds perfectly with the environment, although the plot becomes a little too eccentric and quirky by the late game.

When the protagonist, named the Marked One, first sets out on early missions in the world it feels just like the moment in "The Elder Scrolls 4: Oblivion" when the Hero leaves the Imperial Prison to realize they are inhabiting a fully open world in a beautiful and atmospheric meadow. It's a limitless space filled with opportunity and wonder. There are artifacts for collecting, factions for joining and betraying, causes to either support or curtail, and guns...lots of guns.

This euphoric moment is the start of a long trend downward that begins immediately and doesn't end until the player finishes the game. First, you start to meet meet the NPC characters which differ from the environment in that they are pixelated and grainy creatures with odd gestures and only a rudimentary dialog tree (for reference, TES3: Morrowind released 2002, TES4: Oblivion in 2006, STALKER SoC in 2007.) Nearly every character in the game is just filler with useless dialog who are co-located with the few characters of some significance. For example, I learned from dozens of these NPC's that a noted STALKER named Otter had died several days ago. I expected some quest or additional lore about Otter to materialize, but it's just chatter that had become repetitive, like the popular meme "Have you heard about the High Elves." Nearly all dialog, both important and trivial, are delivered through lengthy and tedious text boxes that should have been retired by this year in game development.

Let's also take a moment to discuss the game's other real opponent - the inventory system. Without mods, the game allows the player to carry up to 60.0Kg of inventory or 70.0Kg with a fatigue penalty in extreme instances (i.e. the whole game.) Guns, ammo, artifacts, medkits, food, and even Vodka all add to carry weight, and it is extremely hard to do the weight/reward math in the field, especially when standing on an enemy spawn point (more on this later.) The loyalists to the STALKER brand will tell you that this makes the game more realistic, but I disagree. My job in the Accounting department is realistic, but I don't do it everyday for the authenticity.

There is also a perfect lesson here on Soviet money, which is that money isn't important. Nearly all goods that are sold (like guns and armor) are often found on enemy corpses and in stashes throughout the game, so you don't actually need the rubles to buy the best inventory in the game - what you need is the inventory space to carry it back, which brings us back to the original point. Long story short, money doesn't matter very much.

A text-based inventory system (a la Fallout 3) would probably have worked better than the grid-based system. Many guns look similar and I sold a valuable unique gun twice thinking that it was a more common variant. Also, the grid can reach further than the end the screen and keeps snapping back upwards, and moving multiple inventories is a chore. You can't move 'all' of one-type of ammo for example, so have to keep double-clicking to individually move 1,000 rounds of shotgun shells in 10 unit boxes. This could have been significantly improved with a little effort.

There are a number of places where the game is not shy about dropping you into an enemy spawn point, so the Marked One is in immediate mortal risk of pop-in bandits. In fact, instant death is around every corner so be sure to Quicksave often (but not too often because Quicksaving at a spawn point can also ruin your save in the worst way). There are actually some places on the map (like the Train Depot at Garbage) that function as a virtual Valhalla, in neverending conflict with spawning enemies for all time - don't use these locations to stockpile valuables.

There is no XP or leveling in the title, but the protagonist does grow stronger with added weapons and armor during the earlier levels. It is refreshing to take down those challenging bandits with ease, but there is an upper limit to this and almost no preparation will make the late game easier. This is where "STALKER SoC" becomes unforgivably difficult - the final stages nearest to the Chernobyl Reactor are what flipped my review from a soft positive to a sharp negative. The Monolith elites from the last few stages are not humans - they're bulletsponges built atop aimbots. The Marked One can only approach the final objective across a field of hyper-accurate snipers and rocket-launching helicopters who always know where the player is. There is no strategy to accomplish this, only lucky breaks that sometimes occur in 1 out of 100 attempts where a path opens in the field of fire, rewarding the player with even more corridors of elite bruisers who can shoot through walls and don't feel pain or lose accuracy even after a shotgun bolt through the nose. I was never nearer to throwing my keyboard through the wall than near the end of the title when the challenge rose to 500% and the drops became sparse. Here's the math: If every opponent costs 3/4 of player's health and 40 rounds of ammo, but only drops 10-15 rounds of ammo or a medkit 10% of the time, how do you keep playing? Only by hoping for perfect accuracy, hit detection and satisfactory drops from every body.

To fully compound this grueling and unsatisfying experience, I eventually survived to see the end of the game after hours of work from Pripyat. I actually did not pre-plan my ending to experience it without spoilers, and of course received the worst of several endings. All the sidequests I performed, factions I supported, and justice I had meted across the Zone mattered less than the fact that I had too many useless rubles in my pocket. It was a disappointing end to an experience that had been disappointing since after the Cordon.

There are mods out there to fix these and other issues, but purists will tell you that the mods are cheating and that a 'raw' vanilla experience is the way to play the game. These people are lying to you and not your friends - the game is unplayable without mods. I played with the 'Complete 2009' mod, but in retrospect I should have used more for just about every facet of the title.

I may actually come back to "STALKER SoC" with the right combination of mods that make the game tolerable because the story and world are just that appealing. But the gameplay and mechanics fail completely and I wouldn't wish the end-game on someone I especially despise, it's just too cruel. My opinion is in the minority of course because the title is 'Overwhelmingly Positive' in many review aggregators. I wish I could share in this general enthusiasm, but I physically feel years older after trying and failing at the ending chapters, only to eventually make it to the final objective and then learn that my real failure was starting in the first place. What the Marked One should have done from Sidorovich's bunker is immediately leave the zone, go to University, study tractors, and have children like Father always wanted.

This game does a few things exceptionally well and that is why it has stood the test of time and become a classic. Published by the late great THQ,  they recognized a diamond in the rough and stuck with GSC through an ambitious and troubled development cycle. This game is built on an In house engine - not unreal, unity, etc. There is dynamic lighting and enemy AI that puts modern titles to shame. There is a robust modding scene that has increased the longevity of the game. In the era of brown and bloom, this title stood above the rest because it does not insult the players intelligence. Instead they hand you a pistol and unleash you into the zone to discover the horror for yourself. Obviously its a 15 year old game, things aren't going to have the  triple A sheen and samey look and feel as modern shooters have but I guarantee this game will surprise you at least once. Stalker 2 has some incredible shoes to fill.

This will probably be the most in depth I will ever get for a review, but if you want to find out if this game is for you, this review might really help you out. I would recommend this game to a very slim group of people, I'll get into it more below. Also because this is to kinda help out new players, ill keep it spoiler free. I will mostly be talking about drawbacks for the beginning, since its hard to find a solid honest critique of the game. I feel if I had some of these downsides mentioned, I might have liked the game a bit more.

Anyways, I really wanted to like this game. I love post apocalyptic games, I love Russian themed stuff (I mean, look at my name), and I especially love a well crafted game play experience that tells a great story. I had a friend recommend this game and when he explained the premise to me relating to all the stuff mentioned before, I thought it would be a perfect match. 

[u] Difficulty Meter [/u]
The bull shittery happens before you even get into the game with the difficulty meter. The difficulty meter is not 100% truthful to the point where the easiest difficulty is technically harder than the master difficulty. This is because the only change difficulty does is add more health to you and enemies. This sounds great at first, but then you realize that enemies will take 2 full mags up close from a rifle on easy to kill them and because you can only carry so many mags because of the carry limit, you will run out of ammo even before you get half way through a short quest.

[u] Intro [/u]
Anyways, starting the game I just want to say I like the intro a lot. Its not high quality but it sets you in the mood and it doesn't need to show you much to let you know how fucked up the "wasteland" is. Its so good I think it almost sets your expectations too high for the rest of the game. Right off the bat, all you are given is a shit pistol and you wont be able to kill consistently with the exception of blind dogs. And before I get ahead of myself...

[u] Bugs [/u]
The bugs. Holy fucking shit the bugs. I cant believe that almost no one in the reviews is talking about this. One of the most common bugs is a crashing bug while interacting with someones body. If you eat, bandage, or do anything other than take an item from a dead enemy's inventory, the game WILL CRASH. This is so annoying and let me set up a little scenareo just incase why you dont see this as a major problem. You are on your way back from a mission and your inventory is full and you are happy. Then you realize your character is starving to death (There is no hunger bar in the game btw) so you start to panic. But just then, as you are running down the road, some random dude starts shooting at you so you kill him. And just your luck, he has a loaf of bread! So you open the loot menu right click their bread and click eat. The game crashes and closes itself. You probably didn't even know it was your fault the first time you did it too, so chances are, you will try to eat or bandage yourself with in the same way mentioned above. You might ask why I wouldnt pick up the bread and carry it around til I need it, but the reason is that bread is heavier than some boxes of bullets. Not even going to get into any other bugs, just know there is some stuff you will just need to know happen and avoid doing them.

The game has fps fluctuations like crazy. Its not even that my computer is bad (I can run GTA V max settings just fine) its just certain areas tank like crazy. It doesnt happen all to often, but it happens enough that it deserves a little mention.

[u] Da Guns [/u]
I love weapons in video games, so here is a special little section just for them.
Firstly, the weapon selection is very slim for this type of game. There is only one sub machine gun in the game (The AKM-74/2U doesn't count as one) and the assault rifles are somewhat plentiful, but there is really no variety. All the people in one area will have AKMs and in another they will all have M4s.
Weapon jamming I think is actually a great addition, since it encourages swaping around guns more and stuff, but the gun seems to jam even if the gun is pretty new, and from what I can tell there is no way to repair a gun.
I dont know if this is the engines fault or what, but shooting in this game is fucked up. Sometimes an enemy will just not get hit by bullets, even at point blank. I have seen other people talk about this one so I know its not just me. This wouldn't be too much of a problem, but playing on the only usable difficulty (master) you can get one shot from a mile away while you cant hit them at all. Also, tap shooting doesn't seem to work consistently for me but most of the guns are so inaccurate you wouldnt be able to hit them even with the burst fire accuracy.

[u] Sound Design [/u]
The sound is bad, but not terrible. I just want to say this right off the bat, but this game uses stock sounds quite alot. So if you like to watch a lot of movies or... you know... play games, you will recognize quite a few of the sounds. Its really hard to get immersed in the game when your trekking along in the wilderness and then hear a stock sound used in ed edd n eddy and you get insta whiplash. Im exagerating a little, but I think you get my point.

[u] Story [/u]
And finally, the story. I couldnt help but want it to be like Fallout: New Vegas in this regard; shitty combat but good story. As you can already tell by the block of text under this, the story sucks. All I can say is that the story is just stale and predictable. But, as I said above, I wont spoil any of the story so consider your self lucky game. But to sum it up, you dont do any investigating yourself to progress the story, there are just a bunch of fetch quests back to back and you just have to run a mile to a lab, grab generic documents, and run back. About 10% of the story get explained throughout the way and then there is one guy you can talk to in the end that just tells you everything that happened and that one guy literally tells you what feels like 90% of the story. Without spoiling it and cutting the story segment short, the story is so dull and predictable, I figured out the only plot twist of the game on the 2nd major quest.

[u] Quests [/u]
The side quests are terrible. They add nothing to the story, and the characters that ask you to do them usually just have one line of diolauge and ask "Can you get _____ for me?" (Yes or No) and if you actually go through and get them the item, they will give you so little amount of money it might not even pay for the bullets/medical supplies used to get the item. I can say comfortably that I made more money picking up guns from the people I killed to complete the quest than I get from the guy giving me money to do the quests.
Did I mention there was no fast travel? There are ways you can make yourself sprint longer. (Also you cant say you cant be driven by someone in a truck to a major town because you are literally in a truck in the intro. No excuse.)
One last thing that's worse than all of the quest issues combined, all of your quests have a fucking time limit. Yup, one ingame day and you will have to walk your sorry ass back to who ever you got that mission from to get the mission again. Fuck that.

[u] B-B-B-UT YOU FORGOT TO TALK ABOUT THE MODS [/u]
Yeah, I know there are mods out there that fix most of the games problems, but that's one thing that really rubs me the wrong way. Just like any single player game, I could install more mods and triple the games file size and make the combat a hell of a lot better. But let me ask you this, does that mean the game is good, or does that mean the modders are fucking insanely talented with coding and game design, even arguably better than the developers at times?

[u] End [/u]
Although I shit on this game a ton, its not too terrible. Id be lying if I said I never enjoyed it. Sure there are a ton of things wrong with it, but again, not every game can be the best.

Don't know how to say this game is as great as it is. It has the feel of an open world sandbox. It has kept my interest even after playing since it first came out and every play through is as exciting as the first and never feels the same.

As this hasn't been remastered, and the original is still being sold on Steam for €16, I guess I'm just going to review it like a normal game. I picked this up wondering whether it was worth playing through the old games in preparation for the new one coming out next year but unfortunately I really can't recommend it. I never really played it when it first came out, so I don't have any nostalgia attached to it. I've tried to play it three times over the last few months, but it just really doesn't feel worth the effort given it's age. Movement is clunky, the controls are bad, the UI is horrible. There isn't really anything drawing me in to discover what's happening.

[b]Cons[/b]
- Really low quality graphics (presumably on-par with the release date)
- Voice lines from the same NPC interrupt each other and cut out
- When you start a new game, there's basically zero context to what's going on
- Bad movement controls
- Combat is really REALLY dated
- Buildings are empty with nothing interesting to discover

This game is definitely a cult classic for a reason. It's atmosphere is oppressive and incredibly unique. The world feels full of danger everywhere you turn, but that makes the friendly faces you find all the sweeter. 
The combat is a bit hard to get used to though, and starting you out with the least accurate weapon in the game probably wasn't the best choice, but it does get a lot better. You will mostly be fighting other humans, but the encounters with some of the more rare mutants are definite highlights.
On the bad side though, the game can be a bit unstable. Most of the bugs I found were more bewildering than annoying, but the game did crash quite a few times.
In spite of its flaws, S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl is a real gem that is well loved for a reason, but that gem does definitely need a bit of a polish.
